content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I actually wrote this, hoping to try and get some sort of suggestion out.. The game itself.. Is pretty nice, however.. You've got to admit that it has loads of flaws in it.. And one of them starts to shine through best when you try and play in hard mode. Makes it (almost) impossible to get off to a good start in that game mode, and will really start to have you wondering exactly how stupid your hearthlings are...Anyways.. the game needs some sort of way to prioritze things.. No.. I'm not meaning the little switches that say "This person should do farm, while this person builds." I'm meaning "Hey you stupid piece of meat, go pick up that herb. RIGHT NOW so that I can make an Herbalist or a potion." Without a way to give some sort of priority to what your hearthlings will gather.. Those who like to setup their villages to have a lot to do, won't usually have very much fun in hard mode.. If you try to plan too far ahead, the game will punish you greatly. As there doesn't seem to be a way to instruct your hearthlings to even drop all of their current queued projects.. And that is probably the most simple way to fix the issue.. It would suck to have to command your hearthlings to get back at it.. But It's better than having all of your starting hearthlings die, because you instructed them to build a house and they don't want to stop building that house to go get a herb until they're dead...For crying out loud.. I told them to go gather some wild herbs, and had a farmer working on growing some herbs, and he ALMOST finished growing the herbs by the time my gatherers brought the herb into town... But to my surprise, they STILL WOULDN'T GATHER IT!Either the AI need improved to recognize that a lack of items is bad, and make it so that getting items that are currently set at 0 is more important than carrying back the wood that you have 500 of or there needs to be a way to prioritize certain tasks.. Like by holding shift and telling them to gather this item.. They know that is more important to do than anything else.. Or even a way to over-ride it and say "This needs to be done first." Alternatively.. Like I said.. a way to tell your hearthlings to stop EVERYTHING. could work as well.Maybe some of this is already in the game and I'm just not seeing it.. But before a hard mode can really be explored too much, little simple things like this really need to be fixed.. Even if there is a way to clear all commands.. A priority system would go leagues and bounds beyond it.. and make the game feel more professional as well.

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								The dev team for this game are very good - the best ive seen for this genre of game. Development is promising, and the game itself is continually growing. I love this kind of game, however, in its current state, stonehearth is probably worth between $5 and $10.The game is very easy - I've so far been able to repel every attack, destroy every enemy base etc with two soldiers (I might have been overdoing it adding the second soldier, too!). Building is very bugged - I've had to cancel innumerable buildings as my villagers couldnt construct certain things or have gotten themselves stuck whilst trying. Being able to watch individual pieces on your building be placed by your citizens is cool but has lead to so many issues when actually performing this key functionality.Progression is basic and unfulfilling - you are a fully self-sustaining within 1-3 days of in-game time. Sure, this might not be a problem, as the game may intend to focus on thriving rather than surviving. However, thriving is impossible as the game cannot seem to handle having >12 citizens (at such numbers, you will see a lot of idling, and citizens with professions flat refusing to do their allocated job whilst there are other things to do - and no, the citizen management screen does not resolve these issues).Keep it on your watchlist, but unless you are looking for a very surface-level experience, steer clear until further down the development cycle.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you are into city buidling games, farming,  creating your own army, job management, etc, this game does a very well job presenting the genre of city builders.  The art style has a very cartoonish feel, at the same time giving the game its own charm; style that cannont be replicated by any other city building games out on the market right now. There is a lot of flexibility on how you want to manage your new village/town/city/empire and however you want to play it. With the plethora amount of new villagers coming into your town, you will find that there are many jobs that you can assign each Hearlthing. Build your own army to fight off hordes of Goblins and other such monsters. Loot from your enemies after you slay them and use the resources to help further expand your empire. There are also a variety of landscapes and even races of humans you can choose from; even more hours to explore how you want to play. While the idea of all this sounds great on paper, Stonehearth manages to crumble all those dreams.  Yes you will have fun playing this game and yes you will enjoy the many hours playing this game. However, the one thing this game suffers greatly is the amount of bugs and gamebreaking bugs this game has. It gives Early Acess the perfect meaning of unfinished game, but somehow manages to make it even sound worse. The major bugs I have encounter mostly revolves around trying to build houses. More specifically customized buildings you try to build are very much broken and have been since the start of this game. Builders will continue to remove and build ladders to reach higher areas of the buidling, and be in an infinite loops doing this. Sometimes they will continue doing this until the building is destroyed or if you somehow make the AI build other buildings instead. Also you cannot destroy certain buildings, it doesn't even explain why it cannot be destroyed. It could also be because the way customizing your own building could be broken as hell.One of the most essential mechanic of this game is broken and that's where I draw the line. A game that focus primarily on creating buildings is broken. Instead of the developers trying to fix this, they release more updates on combat and focusing so much into that. It is quite sad actually, made me not want to play this game for a while. I even contacted the developers about this bug, and they know it exists, they just dont want to do anything about it for now. Many other players also complain about this same exact bug. The only answer they gave me is to use console and to type in commands to instant build and instant destroy. Using a game's console to play a game, to even enjoy it is quite appalling to even hear, but that is the ONLY way to play this game without ripping your hair out of your head.I've had a few problems with combat, but it mostly had to do with the Battle music playing in an infinite loop. Other than that the combat is fine and I have no problem with that. Farming, Smithing, Crafting, Etc. are all fine as well No problems there. StoneHearth is a great idea, I really really really really want to say this game is a Great game. I wish, but this game is not great, this game sucks, this game is garbage. this game needs hate rather than love to show the developers they need to change and fix their game. I always look at this game every week to see if there is an update, JUST MAYBE SOMEDAY THIS GAME WILL WORK PERFECT. Don't buy this game until the bugs are fixed, don't even recommend or even mention this game to anyone. This game has the potential being the New way of playing city builders. The Next grounbreaking sim city game, it has that potential, THE DEVELOPERS NEED TO CAPITALIZE ON THIS GAME. I know this game has the potential to have a large following, just fix the game.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a game that has a lot of sources of inspiration, most noticeably Dwarf Fortress, but also old RPGs like Final-Fantasy-Tactics. Stonehearth wears its inspirations on its sleeve but has its own unique charm and play style.Stonehearth is, as is described by its creators, "a game about exploration and survival in an epic fantasy setting where your job is to help a small group of settlers survive and carve out a place for themselves in a hostile land". In other words, your goal is to help a group of settlers (or "hearthlings" as they are called) to create a colony. You are the mind beyond the operation, you do not control your hearthling directly, you lay out the general plan (mine, build, etc) and your hearthlings commit your plans by themselves. There are also a few RPG elements in the game, like a job three, levels, stats and percs.Two things that i really like about the game are the art style and the emphasis on modding. The devs of the game have built their own game engine with emphasis on modding, which can only increase the lifespan of the game. The game has a really easy to use, and nice looking GUI. the animations are cute and i really like the character design. there is a lot of small things that makes the style of the game charming. The last thing i would like to mention is the awesome community that as been created around the game. since the kickstarter days the game has come a long way, the devs are active in the forums and are actively engaging with the community, they even stream the game development 3 days a week on twitch! All in all the game is very promising, and even though it is missing features it's very fun in is current state. it has a long way to go but I'm really hopeful for its future. if you like what you see give it a try!

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a highly enjoyable, in development, town building game. I have spent many hours building towns, learning the game, and enjoying the new game aspects they are adding from patch to patch as well as the bug fixes.With all of the good things however, there are a few bad.- The map generation takes quite a while per map roll (time consuming when looking for specific setups)- Save files are not compatible with updates, meaning you will need to restart each time there's an updateThese two things are not game breaking major, and they are wanting to implement the backward compatibility with save files, to prevent the need to constantly restart with updates, so it should no longer be a problem when they implement it.This game offers unique textures and means to build your town as well as prevents the need to have them always be building whatever is placed, which helps prevent accidents. This lets you build roads, houses, and other structures the way you want it. Do you want a flat area? Doable, do you want a roof-less house? Doable. Multi-structured mansion? Doable. Throw your guys in a hole and never able to get out? This can also be done, and those who are fans of the Tycoon games, such as Rollercoaster Tycoon, you will be familiar with the ability to trap your visitors where they cannot leave, or killing them with rides. Make this your own experience with the city and enjoy yourself as you do so.I will modify and go into more detail with this review as time goes on and as the game develops.Update 11/27/2015:This game has received quite a few updates since the original review. They have added the ability to create multi-tiered structures in the game, however this feature is a bit wonky and not 100% working in my opinion, as the settlers will often fail to build the bottom half of the house before the upper half or not build the building at all. They have also improved the errors that may happen in the game - if something were to bug out, it is no longer in a nasty developer box, but rather something a bit more user friendly to understand and depending on what fails, offers instructions on fixing the issue.There are some present AI issues in the game that can make it a bit frustrating to have a large amount of tasks, I've been able to circumvent this issue in the developer versions of Alpha 13 - which is said to fix the AI issues in regards to building, etc, but may not be 100% done yet - by removing the request and redoing it or suspending/pausing the task then resuming it. Assuming there isnt still a ton of things already requested for them to do, they often figure out that it still needs to be completed. The game is still very much in a playable state and I still highly enjoy it and my original review still stands at this point in time. They are making progres toward finishing the game and adding features. Please note that at the time of this update, that saves are still not backward/forward compatible. And my original con of the map generation taking a lot of time still stands as well, but it feels a bit faster than it once was.A few other major things they've added are a new style of settler and a new map biome type - the desert and raya's children. I've been able to play around with them in the developer build and its a very interesting change of pace to the normal gameplay that I had grown to love. This in combination with new professions and crafting systems in place permit for a more diverse and intricate creation system, making it feel like the crafters actually rely on each other to make the final product rather than it being a one man army. They have also vastly improved the game experience with making it run faster on my machine, and offering various options to help with slower/older machines as well as bug fixes. I haven't had massive bugs in regards to the UI or other pop-ups outside of one where I was clicking on buttons rapidly.So let me mark off my cons at this point in time in regards to Alpha 12/Dev Alpha 13:- Some AI issues in regards to tasks where they fail to complete (see above for my solution and some info)- Map generation still takes too much time- Save files are still not backward/forward compatibleThis said, let me list some pros of this game thus far- Multi-tiered structures- Intricate crafting system- Ability to trap your settlers- Aggressive (normal surviving) & Peaceful mode (for building)- Various travelling merchantsThere's a lot more as well that I would list off but this review would end up to be too long.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth seems (even after about a year) very much still in the concept stage.  There's not much game here yet, but you can tell the devs are seriously devoted to making Stonehearth the best they can make it.  Even in this early stage you can tell it's the most charming, enjoyable 'concept' of a game out there (check my hours, and that's just through Steam).The devs work closely with the community every step of the way and are immediately responsive to most all bug reports and suggestions.The only caveat I can think of, is that it has been a long, long time getting to even where it is now, and it still has a long long way to go.  I do think it will get there and I have the utmost faith in the devs, but don't expect it in a mere few months.Your money invested here is not to have a fleshed out playable game today or tomorrow, but to help ensure the devs can make Stonehearth all it can be.  You won't have a game you can play day in and day out... just yet.. but it will happen and it will be wonderful.Edit:  I've changed my recommendation to NO for the time being.  There's just too little game here for the high price they're charging.  That high price was fine for kickstarter where you were investing, but now they're selling it on Steam and there just isn't much of a game here for that kind of money.  I also have concerns about how long development is taking.  Don't forget, this game has been in development for two years before it hit Steam early access. Over two years now and frankly, not much has happened for such a long dev cycle.  I honestly think the devs have gotten in over their heads and don't quite know how to dig themselves out of this hole.I'll happily change to Recommended when I see this game kick into high gear, but for now, it's 'wait and see'.Update:  I have to say after ANOTHER YEAR, the devs continue to dig themselve into a hole over their overly complicated approach to hearthling building process - to the detriment of the rest of the game.  The devs seem not to know they are fighting a loosing battle with the manual building process they've tried to implement.  A process so inherently complicated NASA couldn't figure it out.  But still they persist.I'm afraid the game will go nowhere now.  All the 'positive' reviews are based on just a few hours play time and ignore the deep-seated issue of a building process in the game that doesn't work.We could have had the nice rolling hills we were promised early on instead of the 'cliff' design we have now because it was easier.  If all the dev time was applied to landscape rather than this sink hole they've gotten themselves into with building, we'd have a glorious game by now.  And a finsished one.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game for alpha. yes bugs, yes some people have crashes, thats all expected. But i'm afraid for myself personally, that after night 10-15 I've run out of anything to do. You build houses, and then........ um..... well thats it. Even on the "survival mode" you can get by the entire survival mode with 1-2 warriors. Or just build a wall or a fence and you've outsmarted the game.Only thing i've found lately to make it a bit more challenging, is to increase the number of goblins or undead attacking me to keep it difficult. After about day 15 or so the workers kind of stop caring as much about getting things done, they also seem to get confused with where their food is even when theres a stockpile next door to them. I'm personally having a hard time with the food concept of the game, and NO I dont want it to be a sim. But why do I need 18 acres full of food to get one more person? No one eats much but for some reason I need SO MUCH FOOD. I feel like this game doesnt have any point after you made your first couple cute houses and made room for all the food you will need to get more people so you can...... so you can have more people to.... to build more houses.. well you get the picture. Can't reccomend in current state or for that price. Look forward to see what's on the horizon for this game. I hope it doesnt end up like Castle Story.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Oooooookay!!! Here is my review, I'm very torn over this game and its for this reason. BUGS. The game isn't "broken", even in pre-alpha. It is a very playable and fun game IF you can make it long enough without a UI or engine crash, Bear with me as this is kind of long, but very worth the read if you want an HONEST review of the product youre buying Pros:*SUPER FUN- Ive played many RPG's, RTS's, etc. but this game is one of the most mind numbingly addicting games I have ever played.*Complete Sandbox- Like Minecraft, but better.*Ranking Systems- Hearthlings rank up in their profession, giving them cool perks.*Versatility- Plotting out farmland, building houses around designated land, etc. You build YOUR town how YOU want. To a point at this stage in the game.*GEAR- I love love love the armor and weapon progression for your soldiers*Custom building- You arent stuck to templates, although they are provided. Cons:*BUGGY AF- Remember, it's still in alpha. However, nothing is more frustrating than getting so far into a game then recieving a pop-up "UI Crash" report. Seems to happen every hour. Villagers glitch into walls, they wander off miles just to collect random sh*t on the ground, usually dying in the process. They sit and DIE when being attacked. Guards don't wake up from sleep to respond to threats.... this is a big deal when invaders come at NIGHT only and all of your guards are sleeping. Needless to say, the bugs make the game frustrating as hell at times. Once, my entire village got stuck in defense mode, starving to death looking out for enemies that weren't there. *LACK OF EDITING- after or during building process. This is probably the single handedly most frustrating aspect of this game. If you design a massive, beautiful building, spend the time and resources to build it, then realize you fuzzed up, youre SOL. You have to tear down adn rebuild the entire thing, which can take the better half of an hour.  *Villagers forget/refuse to do assignments. Sometimes it is simply because they have a long checklist before they get to that particular assignment. However, many times, they will just stop building walls, digging caves, or collecting resources. And no matter how many times you remind them, they will sit there and do nothing instead.*Mining is sloppy. There is no realistic ability to build UP inside caverns, you have to always dig down.... which is annoying to say the least. *Lack of defensive features...This broke my heart. Sure you can build a mkaeshift stone wall. Sure you can build a really tall building and call it a guard tower, but in a game where you are attacked by zombies and skeletons every night, this game NEEDS operational wartime structures. Maybe a tower your guards actually post themselves in, or a palisade where an archer <--also much needed--> can be stationed. Especially when you go to war with the goblin chieftans, they attack, steal, and raid you every chance they get. It would be nice to see more organized troop and defense structures, as well as a more convienent way to get up to different floors of buildings. Overall, I still think this game is amazing. Please don't be turned off from my review. I refuse to sugar coat it for you. The price tag is too high to lie to you. HOWEVER, I stand by my opinion that this game is beautiful, the soundtrack is wonderful and overall this piece has some fantastic potential. I will continue to play this game, and I STRONGLY urge you to support the development of this game and buy it. The devs care, releasing updates and bug fixes periodically, Buggy? yes. Lacking? Barely, but yes. But its still in alpha!  My rating comes to an 8/10 in its current state! I think this can and will quickly be a game to watch though, as long as the community continues to support it.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a game that has a lot of sources of inspiration, most noticeably Dwarf Fortress, but also old RPGs like Final-Fantasy-Tactics. Stonehearth wears its inspirations on its sleeve but has its own unique charm and play style.Stonehearth is, as is described by its creators, "a game about exploration and survival in an epic fantasy setting where your job is to help a small group of settlers survive and carve out a place for themselves in a hostile land". In other words, your goal is to help a group of settlers (or "hearthlings" as they are called) to create a colony. You are the mind beyond the operation, you do not control your hearthling directly, you lay out the general plan (mine, build, etc) and your hearthlings commit your plans by themselves. There are also a few RPG elements in the game, like a job three, levels, stats and percs.Two things that i really like about the game are the art style and the emphasis on modding. The devs of the game have built their own game engine with emphasis on modding, which can only increase the lifespan of the game. The game has a really easy to use, and nice looking GUI. the animations are cute and i really like the character design. there is a lot of small things that makes the style of the game charming. The last thing i would like to mention is the awesome community that as been created around the game. since the kickstarter days the game has come a long way, the devs are active in the forums and are actively engaging with the community, they even stream the game development 3 days a week on twitch! All in all the game is very promising, and even though it is missing features it's very fun in is current state. it has a long way to go but I'm really hopeful for its future. if you like what you see give it a try!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is on the road to success. I have been following this game since it was announced on Kickstarter and am very happy with where this game is going. The Developers are very committed to going the distance and listen to their fans 24/7,Now for the gameplay currently it has enough for you to get a basic Idea of what the game is. You will be able to design your own town however you want by gathering resources and deal with goblins, zombies, and Skeletons invading during the night. You will promote your workers (hearthlings) to gain more food or build certain items. Now I know that doesnt sound like much but getting to play with all the different types of layouts, buildings, and designs is enough fun to make you play for hours. Of course this game is not complete so you will find bugs which many of us players have been reporting in.We the players also have the important job of reporting bugs and telling the Developers what we would like to see next. We would love to have you join our community on the Stonehearth discourse website and hear what you would want to see or problems that you are having that should be fixed. The developers are working hard so the game will have big updates every 4-8 weeks which gives you a reason to keep coming back for more.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								First off let me say this: I DO recommend this game, because it's proof of consept is so grand, and it promises everything I have always wanted in a base-building game. That being said the price of $25 is a little steep for a game that is barely playable. I have put about 20 hours into it off steam, and will surely put more. If you are  reading this i am sure you understand the game is in ALPHA and is pretty buggy, however the devs are great at talking to their community and are squashing bugs constantly,There are several Game breaking bugs within the main mechanics that make it unplayable.The building UI is a great idea, however the coding isn't right on it yet, Walls not being build, crashing when creating a big building, hearthlings not building a roof for your house for virtualy no reason. there are ways to make buildings with multiple walls, but most of them are tedious, requiring manual wall building, planning and erasing to get the building to work right, that is if you game doesnt crash on wall building or just make it so that you can not plan buildings anymore without save scumming. Other than the bugs, there are features that are not present (some that they plan to add) that i belive are needed to round out the game and make it playable. I will list them here in hopes of Dev eyes and to establish discorse :D-Stairs (they have already said its on its way, but without them it is hard to make multiple floors, ladders are visualy unappealing and dont support multiple hearthling travel)-Manual Job Prioities (I wish that hauling wasn't a top prioities unless i set it as such)-Underground Walls and rooms (Though possible, it is tedious, anothering on their to-do list)-Better Mining Interface (Wish i could change all three tunnle dimentions)Those are some basic things that i am sure they will add, but without them currently it makes this more of a proof of concept than a game. Here is a list of some otherthings that i belive will make up for the lack of depth-Hearthling Personalities (Other than 3 stats, there is nothing that seperates one hearthling from another, making the game a bit shallow)-Diffrent Starting Zones/Biomes/Varity (These are already on the To-Do list, right now there is almost no varity in starting zones.)Really i had intentions for making this a long review and listing out everything i want to happen in this game in hopes of others seeing it and influencing the game, however it is just to soon to tell, they have so many good things planned for this including Multiplayer i only wish i didnt hear about this until it came out of early access, i yearn to play it everyday in its complete state. So should you buy it? Yes.... Support these great devs.

Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a great game, I have been playing since Pre-early access and have been astounded by the progress made by the developers and their level of community involvment, streams weekly, dev logs, weekly, roadmaps, quick responses on forums etc. Usually I'd steer clear of an Early Access game by a newer or less well known company. However Radiant have proved to be extrememly reliable and dedicated to their game. I would recommend this game, however it is in early access so bugs and a lack of features are to be expected (this is a direct attack of those posting negative reviews stating how is feature lacking - IT IS EARLY ACCESS!). If you are uncertain of whether or not you want to buy it, check out their streams look at some recent gameplay videos.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was fortunate enough to discover and back this game on Kickstarter during the original campaign and I've been hooked ever since. It is worth noting that I'm writing this review during alppha 10 and so many features are missing still. However, Stonehearth has evolved from being a very basic townbuilder game into a rich environment with many, many features (and many more planned). Some of my personal favorites are the richness of buildings that can be made and the burgeoning job system.It's also worth noting that the developers are very keen to support modders. They have made the game from the ground up with an extensible framework intended for modders and is how they are adding some of their own content as well.Finally, the developers are very active with their community, doing multiple streams per week as well as religiously posting blog entries on at least a weekly basis. They're very friendly on their forums and are regularly interacting with their supporters. I 100% recommend this game, even with the missing features.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Too many bugs to play a file reliably. You build a pathway, some times it bugs out and can't be removed. You try and build under ground to reach the tunnels/dungeons, the camera can't turn the proper angle to create proper tunnels. Constant bug notifications pop up on your screen, some times crashing the file itself. Buildings still don't function properly. The soilders bug out in the middle of the fights if they try to haul. If your civilians all have 'mine' set on, they'll get stuck in a hole forever. Miners can't reach directly above their heads, causing them to get stuck forever if you don't click in a methodical order. If you don't do clean mining strips then you'll have messy blocks sticking/floating out and there's no way to fix it. Sometimes you civilians stop building, mining or doing a task with no reason.The most annoying thing by far is that these games always fall for the same issue because the developers balance this game by being "arm chair scientists" rather than playing their game legitimately (without cheats/commands). This is a problem in every single game like this I've played, whether it's Banished or anything else I've unistalled. This problem amplfies the longer you have a file, and the more you develop a file. Your units need to eat, and sometimes while they're half way in to completing a task or walking to location. The result is an endless loop of them trying to complete/reach the location before ending up getting hungry and cancelling it to walk back to the designated 'eat spot'. This is a completely fatal issue, there's no way to combat this until the developers add in proper inventories so your peoples can hold some food in their bags. Assuming you manage to dodge the bug fest and end up creating a big town, the civs will get hungry just by travelling from one side of the town, let alone exploring tunnels or hunting mobs on the map.Stoneheart is the only game from this genre that I enjoy and look foward to seeing developed. It's zelda-like elements and potential make it endlessly replayable once the content rolls in. However once the developers start ACTUALLY playing their game and realise their are some fatal bugs/issues like the 'Food Loop' they completely give up and open up the mod workshops *cough* Banished *cough*. So lets hope it doesn't go down like that. However, this game is pure Alpha, or even closer to Beta. Don't buy it.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Long way to go, but even if i looked at this game in its current state, only consider all the bugs that it has polished, i would give it thumbs up. So since there are regular updates and fixes i have no reason not to recommend this game. Not all is great but i believe that it will be polished on the way.Digging up and down is badly done, needs re-thinking. The whole way how to look thru the ground in various heights is pretty badly made making it very difficult sometimes to see what you need to see when you ve been digging quite a bit.There is no way how to place dirt blocks back, they make no drop, no resource, so if you accidentally dig away something, you can only "build" a piece of stone back, but in x-ray view you will always see it there. There is no way how to make the your folk stop picking certain stuff up. So if your warrior dies in a gnome camp, your minions will keep running there to pick up the sword after the dead body, dying one by one. Sometimes they appear to die for no reason just like that, since the game doesnt tell you what happened you are just left wondering. I only played two games but there seems to be some sort of randomisation in various jobs position in the job tree, sometimes its the potter that is below the mason in the tree and sometimes its viceversa, this left me quite confused. The building system as a whole is a bit strange, i managed to design my stone tower, placed it on the ground and ordered start of construction, but nobody did anything and i didnt know why. There isnt enough of information about things, sorta ingame wiki. What does affect the sattisfaction of shelter? Food? Which food is the most sattisfactory? Optimization is another issue which surprised me. When you town is population 15+ the game will start somewhat lagging. Sometimes re-loading the game helps, sometimes it just stops on its own, its weird. But on my high-end PC its defo not a HW issue.There is a whole lot of things id like to see improved and i have no doubt that they will get improved. It already is very pleasant to play, has nice music, nice graphics, nice gameplay. Its very similar to game called Gnomoria, only with nicer graphics and heading in a little bit differend direction, direction that i like more.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								The short: A fun, cute, and refreshing civilization builder in the essence of its age-old predecessor: Dwarf Fortress.The long: As a avid fan of civilization sims and a old school fan of Dwarf Fortress 2, I bought Stonehearth on a hunch that it might be a aptly port to the 3D plane. In return, I was award with a different experience all together. Normally, I am a hard skeptic when it comes to Early Access titles and new wave Indie games. I am proud to say that this is a, currently, diamond in the rough.One of the first things I found with this game is the adorable graphics and artwork, which really appeal to its style. Everything looks nice and has a charming nature, even in the enemy designs. Gameplay-wise, Stonehearth serves really well as a civilization sim. Everything seems to mesh well together and controls are extremely easy to use. While earlier I ran into problems with the building controls, the recent alpha stage has fixed most of these problems and makes building and designing an awesome experience. Progression is very straightforward and aptly spaced parallel to your own speed. Combat, while simplistic, is easy to follow and pushes you to focus your troops into more diverse roles as your settlement grows. All in all, a very entertaining experience that makes me hopeful for a quality game the more it develops.While the current stage has not as much content as some would hope for, the team working on this has been effective at maintaining an open discussion with its playerbase. They have also been very well timed in releasing updates on development as well as new alpha builds, which is something I hope to see with any Early Access game. As with games of this nature, the time old expression of "What do I do?" comes to mind for those who aren't well versed with games such as Dwarf Fortress or Gnomoria. However, the game is very easy to follow and figuring out your way is not as hard as such games mentioned.Basically, if you enjoy games in the nature of Dwarf Fortress, but aren't ready for the complexity of such a title, Stonehearth is the game to play. Adorable, addictive, and a fresh take on civilization sim.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I was an original Kickstarter backer back in mid 2013.The development of this game has long passed estimated release times. It still gets updates but they don't add much. Save games aren't stable between versions. Mod support has still yet to surface. OSX/Linux versions are on the backburner and may never come yet they were one of the first stretch goals. According to their own Trello board on their website both are "to be done in the far future."The game itself is hardly what I would call playable. Here's a list of the many things that go wrong:* Construction of buildings stalls. This means they never complete a building, which is a pretty important aspect.* Villagers consistently fail on their tasks meaning you have to re-task them. Again, and again, and again.* At random points the AI just stops doing things. It's probably the same issue with the former mentioned construction issue.Anyone comparing this to Minecraft are the people that think all Voxel games are the same.I do not recommend the game as early access. One day if it gets a full release then maybe I would recommend it. It has potential but the developers don't seem to prioritize work on the game.

number of helpful: 64 of 122 people (52%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Written on 16 Nov 2015:Well when the game works it's a fun game to play, but if you are a Windows 10 user, you might want to pass on this game for now.  It took me an hour to get the game going in the compatibility section of Windows and editing the "user_settings.json" file.  Even after I had the game running, it crashes every 30 to 60 minutes.  There is also a User Interface problem that keeps showing up that prevents you from clicking on GUI buttons and makes the game unplayable and prevents you from saving the game.This game is early access, but for $25 dollars I feel it should be more playable.  If it was selling for $10 these issues would be more forgivable, but not at this price range.From what I see on the forums non-Windows 10 machines have much better luck running this.  I would recommend Windows 10 users waiting three months or more and then checking the forums to see if these issues have been resolved.  It really is a nice game, but it's not stable enough right now.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have been following Stonehearth since Alpha 10 and after 17 hours of game I feel confortable enough to share my opinion with you guys. I'm going to do a list of Pro and Con, I hope you enjoy it.Ps:. Remember this game is in ALPHA stage so I can't avaliate everything, because it is constantly changing.Pros:- Game is constantly updated (weekly);- You can follow the game's development in Stonehearth's Website, Twitch Tv or in their Youtube Channel;- The team is always helpful and you can contact them in their own Forum or in Steam's Forum;- The game has an original cube style which is kind of criative and cool;- Stonehearth is pretty complete for an Alpha version;- The game has gorgeous graphics for an Alpha state;- The animations are pretty good;- We have nice bosses and monsters;- Building mechanics are good and you can basically create everything you want;- You have a lot of crafting options ( Carpenter, Blacksmith, Herbalist....etc). Therefore you need to update them;- The furniture of the game is just amazing;- You have three different difficult modes (Peaceful, Normal, Hardcore);- The game is always challenging although you play in normal mode; < Disregarding the Peaceful mode.- Hardcore mode is really amazing and challenging; < ( my favorite part )- You have a nice story although it's kind of silly;- The combat in the game is really nice. You have 4 different classes in combat ( Tank, Ranger, Cleric, DPS );- You have 2 biomes to play ( Desert, Florest ) and they are creating more + season system;- You have at now 2 different "races" to play;- The game's community is active.Con:- The game still having some bugs(Buildings/Combat), but it's in Alpha stage. It will change with the time;- The music is nice, but after a while it feels monotonus. I hope they put more soundtracks soon;- The combat's system is really great, but their auto-attack make it harder to play. I hope it's just a question of time to their change it;- The "races" seems predetermined for each biome which is a pity. Maybe they can change that;- The citizens also delay a lot to build something;- By the way, the game is not really optimized which means more work for your hardware(>> RAM <<);- Water bugs <<< It's really annoying but I bet it will change with the time.It's everything that I could see about this game. The game is fantastic, I personaly love it. I would recomend it for almost everybody. But remember, this game is Alpha Stage which means that you will find bugs. I recommend this game for people that have patience and understand that this current stage is going to be improved slowly. Ps:. Before you buy this game give a look at their website and on their development map. So you can catch up what they are working in.My Opinion:The game have a great potential for turn the best sandbox construction game after Dwarf Fortress. I personally had a great time playing Stonehearth. Building your own castles, Keeps, collecting resorcess, constructing a solid economy and defending your town against strong Trolls and goblings is pretty nice and cool guys! I had played other games before Stonehearth such as Towns, Craft the World, Terraria, Timberstone and Dwarf Fortress. I can assure you guys that no game is like Stonehearth. No game mix RPG + RTS + SANDBOX so well as this game and this is because I love it!Ps:. Remember this review was wrote in Alpha 17. So, the game can be better or worse after some updates.Ps2:. The game is on development I can't review it completely for that.

Early Access Review
								Stonehearth, is a stoned survival and exploration game in a epic fantasy world, where you settle a town of hearthlings while defending agens invaders.The games layout, animations and sounds are really great, specially the way we can build the houses and duplicate our buildings on the ground, for each pieace. We can design everything from: Window, floor, door, roof, flags, fire, beds, and more. On the path while playing the game, people will visit your town and you can sell / buy upgrades. The atmosphere of the game is really nice, and you getting hooked really quickly.Be aware! They need some fixes aswell. Please keep in mind that this is Early access, and it's not finished. Check out my and others suggestions here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/253250/discussions/0/594821545179359856/Don't be a fool and think it's not worth it because of the missing features or sometime crashes with 5.273 error messages.If you search a relaxing and interesting stone, exploration and survival game in a fantasy world with invaders either in creative or survival mode, then this game is for you.Here is some old gameplay footage from june:

content:
Posted: January 12
Early Access Review
								Holy crap, there's an actual game here! After ages of being pretty boring, buggy and unplayable, I was able to play for about 6 hours straight the other day with no hiccups, crashes or incomplete buildings. I was rewarded with a rich town builder that, while still missing some key features, is surprisingly deep. As a Kickstarter backer, this is a huge relief: most Early Access projects don't get nearly this far, especially in the town builder/management genre (example: Gnomoria).Furthermore, the team responsible for the game, Radiant, was recently acquired by Riot (makers of League of Legends). The team here is dead set on getting this project right from day one. Even though development has been slow, updates have been solid and have steadily built on themselves to create a game that is finally beginning to take definitive shape as a fun and unique take on the Dwarf Fortress genre. Keep an eye on this one, DF fans. It's going places.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth (Alpha 10) can be best described as a pretty, easy to use, and lightweight Dwarf Fortress for the masses. None of what I just said should be taken negatively. It's a great concept. I absolutely can't wait for final release, because I'm convinced the devs are going to make it happen and hit a home run in the process.As the game stands, it wasn't until the latest Alpha release (alpha 10) a couple of weeks ago that Stonehearth actually started to feel like a game. So giving a fair review is hard to do. Let's just jump to whether or not you should buy in to the game as it is now. If you are an indie supporter who likes to see a game evolve and support a project early on, then yes, it's a great buy. Also if you are content with what amounts to a sandbox that is still very much a trial run of the features in the design doc but are OK with may features still outstanding, then certainly dive in while the water is relatively clean. The game is being made by great team that stays heavily connected to the community.If you are looking for a game that is near feature complete with only minor bugs, then perhaps it's worth waiting. If I had to guess, Stonehearth is at least a year away from being ready for final release; so if you don't have the patience to wait until the features you want are in the game, then you may want to wait. Perhaps the Early Access money from Steam will afford a larger team and speed up the development...In the end, be sure and check out the games website and watch some YouTube videos to help with your decision.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I spent a small amount of time playing Stonehearth and with a brief summary can say this game is the future Gnomoria. It does everything a simulation civilization survival game should do. It has a bit of leveling up, looser micromanaging, customizing buildings, unlockable classes, and a better feel of the open world. When your Hearthlings get hungry and you ask them to harvest berries, they don't starve themselves on a job and wait for another job class to go do it, they stop everything and grab some wild berries. I will say Gnomoria has a leg up in terms of making your own classes and uniforms but I'm sure as this game progresses it'll have the same options if not more that Gnomoria had to offer. The music isn't half bad and is soft however it does keep reminding me of the little mermaid...It is an EA and like all EA's theres errors but to have the game working on the day of steam release is a first +1 for its score, having a few options +1, having a save and load function +1, having most of the key features working in-game +1, having a balanced and playable gameplay +1, and finally I only encountered 2 bugs that have already been reported the headless bug and the red error box when making a custom house, neither were game breaking or that annoying due to being able to move the red box and the heads stay on if you zoom out. So for me a personal +1. I also want to wrap up by saying a huge HUGE THANK YOU to both the greenlight voters and the developers! The developers I thank you for stepping up to the plate WHEN YOU FELT READY, taking time to process your game and release it almost stable is a huge hat off to you (even though I don't wear hats).The price is a bit of a shock to those with lower paychecks and what with the economy the way it is don't be to embarrassed to wait. This game has great delivery, great promise, and a great dev team so far from what I can tell at least. I'll wrap this up by saying Steam needs more Indie dev teams like this who wait until the game is stable and has most of its key elements already in game.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a sandbox-rpg town builder with a lot of heart. I’ve been playing the game since Alpha 3 and it’s the only early development game i’ve had zero regrets about purchasing. Community And Developers:The Stonehearth Discourse is full of awesome and helpful people. It’s a very good grouping of gamers really trying to help each other out. Friendliest discourse on the net.The developers at Stonehearth truly are one of a kind. They continue to be very open about what is happening with the game and participate in discussion on the discourse. They REALLY do listen to feedback, i've seen it happen multiple times where the community will spotlight a great idea and it makes it into the game.But the main thing is… they stream THREE times a week on Twitch, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday. Two design live streams and one coding stream. Tony and Tom answer questions accept feedback with the best of them.On top of this, they do a development blog once a week, sometimes twice.Alphas get pumped out one every 6-8 weeks on average. In between that, they update the unstable branch that allows you to play test the upcoming features, and those come pretty quickly after main Alpha releases.Gameplay:The game plays great You set up the tasks and then can kick back and watch as your Hearthlings go to work. Farmers need to direction as they constantly plant, harvest, and replant food. The trapper will automatically head to the trapping zones you set up, survey the lands, and place out traps to catch small game. And one of my favorites... footman will patrol along your roads and stockpiles, wary for danger.With the Dungeon Master Ai system, it spawns events and campaigns (I won't spoil what) that come to mess with your village. In some cases, you are given multiple options on how to handle it.Overall:I think the Devs said it best"It’s important to understand that Stonehearth isn’t finished yet. Not by a long shot. But Stonehearth, as it stands now, is a game with fun, robust gameplay and plenty to do and explore."Pros:Community ++Developers ++Development Speed +Developer Openness and Communication ++Plays smoothJust good Fun!Oozes Character and cutenessDungeon Master System AICons:Buggy! (it’s alpha)Price is in the mid-high range for EA, but seems right for the final game.Game Still has a long ways to go to be fully featured

If you are an indie supporter who likes to see a game evolve and support a project early on, then yes, it's a great buy. Also if you are content with what amounts to a sandbox that is still very much a trial run of the features in the design doc but are OK with may features still outstanding, then certainly dive in while the water is relatively clean. The game is being made by great team that stays heavily connected to the community.If you are looking for a game that is near feature complete with only minor bugs, then perhaps it's worth waiting. If I had to guess, Stonehearth is at least a year away from being ready for final release; so if you don't have the patience to wait until the features you want are in the game, then you may want to wait. Perhaps the Early Access money from Steam will afford a larger team and speed up the development...In the end, be sure and check out the games website and watch some YouTube videos to help with your decision.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great game. I recommend this game to anyone who likes creative sandbox games and even the casual RTS gamer. Its alpha, so obviously there are bugs being worked out. None of the bugs are game breaking and most can be fixed by simply saving and reloading. They also make console commands available as a work around for some bugs. Its great for releasing your inner creativity. Think of building something in Minecraft or Terraria, except not having to place each individual piece yourself. You design the building in a design mode and when you are finished editing you hit the build button and then your people do all the work. This makes building larger more complex structures much less time consuming. There is a building template saving feature so that your creations can be saved for other games. If you make a massive structure simply save it and you can copy paste it to another world, all you need is the materials. The combat is fun as well, but can be turned off if you wish to play in the sandbox mode. Being able to assign units to gaurd (footmen) roles and creating/finding better gear for them to use. The game gets progressively harder to a point then seems to level out and nothing can defeat your footmen. But again its alpha and the combat was only just released so its basically there to be tested and tuned.Multiplayer has not been implemented yet but it is planned in the future and I believe that this game has some great potential at some fun multiplayer gameplay.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a sandbox-rpg town builder with a lot of heart. I’ve been playing the game since Alpha 3 and it’s the only early development game i’ve had zero regrets about purchasing. Community And Developers:The Stonehearth Discourse is full of awesome and helpful people. It’s a very good grouping of gamers really trying to help each other out. Friendliest discourse on the net.The developers at Stonehearth truly are one of a kind. They continue to be very open about what is happening with the game and participate in discussion on the discourse. They REALLY do listen to feedback, i've seen it happen multiple times where the community will spotlight a great idea and it makes it into the game.But the main thing is… they stream THREE times a week on Twitch, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday. Two design live streams and one coding stream. Tony and Tom answer questions accept feedback with the best of them.On top of this, they do a development blog once a week, sometimes twice.Alphas get pumped out one every 6-8 weeks on average. In between that, they update the unstable branch that allows you to play test the upcoming features, and those come pretty quickly after main Alpha releases.Gameplay:The game plays great You set up the tasks and then can kick back and watch as your Hearthlings go to work. Farmers need to direction as they constantly plant, harvest, and replant food. The trapper will automatically head to the trapping zones you set up, survey the lands, and place out traps to catch small game. And one of my favorites... footman will patrol along your roads and stockpiles, wary for danger.With the Dungeon Master Ai system, it spawns events and campaigns (I won't spoil what) that come to mess with your village. In some cases, you are given multiple options on how to handle it.Overall:I think the Devs said it best"It’s important to understand that Stonehearth isn’t finished yet. Not by a long shot. But Stonehearth, as it stands now, is a game with fun, robust gameplay and plenty to do and explore."Pros:Community ++Developers ++Development Speed +Developer Openness and Communication ++Plays smoothJust good Fun!Oozes Character and cutenessDungeon Master System AICons:Buggy! (it’s alpha)Price is in the mid-high range for EA, but seems right for the final game.Game Still has a long ways to go to be fully featured

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have a few things to say about this game. It has become one of my favorite pc games ever. No joke. It has unique gameplay and a very nice plot. It even has story progression for once you get to about the second in-game month, goblin camps start appearing. The game itself looks very well made and polished but even for this game, it has got PLENTY of cons.First off it is highly buggy and mainly when designing or building a house. Sometimes building the second story wall makes it two layer and overlap leaving it unable to undo or do anything otherwise without restarting the game. The AI could also use incredible amounts of work. They don't build under bridges of any kind and they need to be specifically ordered to do so or they will never get anything done. There is a feature that needs to be added single-handedly and that is making it to where the AI always run back to headquarters. Everytime there are mobs coming out and chasing after my Hearthlings, do they go towards the footmen who could kick some goblin♥♥♥♥♥ Nope. They run out to the woods to dig their own harty graves. That's not all for I have had to start my game over far to many times due to the poorly-made engine failing from doing simple tasks.But the reason why you see this thumbs up on this review is that this game overall has massive potential. And since I adore early-access games so much, I have gotten used to these bugs. But, then again, when the developers ditch the game to run off with the thousands and millions they make, then it is a big thumbs down for me. But greatly enough, they are still updating it. Maybe a bit slow at times, but they are still producing the game towards better recreational fun. I do reccomend this game and it is worth every penny you buy it for.

								Aslong as the Devs keep updating it and don't leave it for the great Early Access Graveyard, Stonehearth has ALOT of Potential, and hope to see it progress.Pros:--  Its a nice game visually, Despite being voxel.-  You can make your own buildings (needs more options than just Wood and Stone though, like making the floor out of linen and having it any colour you want)- Plenty to keep you entertained for a good amount of hours in its current state- I'll say it again, this game has so much potential in the long run.- Like Banished, another great title, but more forgiving, and no teen pregnancy.Cons:-- Occasionally, the Hearthlings can be moronic- Combat is a little lacking, Most of the time 1 Footman equipped with a Boneclub can scare away a group of 4 Goblins- No way to remove ghost furniture when dumb Hearthlings don't Place the item thereOverall I've really enjoyed what Stoneheart has to offer so far, and hope the Devs keep working on such a fun little title, I hope to see the Magma Smith and Geomancer and Bunny-Human pictures from the Loading screens ingame one day.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I sit here in my desk chair, 3am on a cold Scottish morn. Listening to the gentle hum of my PC as I watch my little hillside hamlet of Edoras expand, 4 houses, a public feasting building, a guard barracks, a blacksmith and a completly filled food storehouse. Every little hearther is happy, at peace and happy in life as we press further into the hillside, ever expanding, handing out food to passing merchants - we have plenty- in exchange for fancy chairs and rustic fire pits for the long houses. We gather to eat and jest, then sleep in simple beds with roaring fires to keep us warm.This is simple. Peaceful. This is Edoras.Ok, I'll be truthful, i was expecting a quick hour or so to get into it, set up farms, housing... basic stuff then just steam roll it for a half hour then refund it cause i wasn't enjoying it.But no, Stonehearth has this... charm to it that i just can't pinpoint. Maybe it's the building system - you have a few preset designs and the rest you can build using a fairly simple but effective system of drag selections and semi voxel based building -, maybe it's the constant strive to better your town and lure more hearthers (little voxelly pixelly villagers) into your town for workers.Maybe you just enjoy the sense of wonder of seeing your town flourish by your hand.Stonehearth is probably already worthy of a release, i don't even begrudge them £18.99 because the game is truly extremely fun. BUT One problem is... The AI... the hearthers are a little... single minded, monkey see, monkey do sort of thing. Like place desings for a house... they start building. Good. Place designs for another hosue and a... idk, a storehouse, and sometimes theyll  all flock to build the storehouse and begin construction. So that house you placed first unless you reinstate the build order, will become last priority. Not bad as such, just a little... irritating seeing half built buildings (storehouse and blacksmith in my village) being used and slept in with no roof, half a wall missing, and no door.. :pPersonal peeve and i'm sure others will feel the same way...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								A very enjoyable sandbox game. Want to lay back in your chair, tell the hearthlings to build templates, grow large farms and just enjoy watching them... This game is for you... Later when Oggo's army comes, you can see it burn down. :)Are you a stratigic mastermind looking for a challenge, wanting to build large cities and castles and fight off evil, and well, build an invicible empire... This game is for you.... And don't you worry, Oggo's army will test how invincible you just think you are. ;)Personally, I don't like it... I love it! You build a city, maybe an economic or a military powerhouse, while a simple but very enjoyable script of events undergoes, and how to tackle them is up to you. Of coursen there are also random events or raids that happen during all of this so you get a little disparity between games.But every game has it flaws, for this game, it's mostly bugs like: During the event of the Goblin chieftain, when you say you're gonna pay him tribute but wait it out and he's asking you for the last time before attacking, you can just press esc and it will go back to the notification bar, until you say "I have changed my mind" or pay the tribute. And the blacksmith leveling process, yeah, I get it's very late game but to mine up and let him smelt literally 500+ ores, just to get him to lvl 4 so you can finally get the engineer and do it all over but with cogwheels... The process gets a bit to  grindy.And for Oggo's army, you need atleast 2 decked out knights (and a max lvl healer), which again requiers a lvl 3 - 6 smith.Now if you should buy this? For me, the price is right, it's a well made (alpha) game and if it will be multiplayer later on.... It's very much worth it.If you should buy this now during early access or later is up to you, if you don't mind restaring worlds that you have built on, then yes. Otherwise wait.I have been playing this since alpha 2,5 came out, and I think it has been a blast watching the game unfold, becoming bigger and more complex for every uppdate and test new things out, so if you want to help the developers and ge tthis feeling, buy it.For you who'll wait until the full release... 1v1 me later when/if multiplayer comes! ;)

								For months I looked at this game on Steam and thought to myself, "Hey, that looks kind of neat, seems kind of fun, and I think I'd like to try it sometime, but there's probably other stuff that I'd rather play first, so I'll just wishlist this and maybe get back to it when it goes on sale again someday."Well, after maybe six months of that attitude, I finally broke down and bought Stonehearth. I shouldn't have waited. Would definitely get re-addicted again. Just one more block. Just one more block. Just one more block...9/10

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been excited for Stonehearth since the Kickstarter which I happily contributed to. I saw a team of people who were passionate about delivering the product they envisioned instead of a watered down version.Two years later I'm happy to see that I wasn't wrong. The development team is very transparent, honest, and are not willing to give up on their vision like so many other games have. Unfortunately, that means that some things take longer to do and have more bugs because the implementations are more complex. I've watched and played the alphas, though, and I've seen fantastic and surprisingly rapid growth so I'm optimistic about where this game will be when it's finally complete.Worth the price, but please remember this is alpha-quality software so there may be some frustrations. Alpha 10 is pretty stable but if you'd like to avoid some of the game-breaking issues that can sometimes pop up I would wait a few more versions or even until Beta when the real bug fixing kicks in.

Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Only five hours in but I'm having a TON of fun, and it's only in alpha.THE QUICK VERSION: Do you like Gnomoria (or Dwarf Fortress)? Do you like Minecraft? If you answered "yes" to either of these, you'll most likely enjoy this game. If you answered "yes" to both, you'll DEFINITELY enjoy this game.THINGS TO LIKE:+ The building system is the most robust of any citybuilder I've seen to date. You not only get to lay out buildings for your Hearthlings to construct (very intuitively, in my experience!) but you get to place furniture within and without at your whim. There's already a great deal of different types of furniture and decor your Hearthings can craft.+ The music is excellent. It's rich and well composed, and it gives the game a very quaint feel.+ Game generation is simple but fun and really makes you feel like you're having an impact on your game before it even starts. You roll a set of Hearthlings, each with their own stats, and can even name them. You also get an amount of gold to spend on a selection of items to start yourself off with. You select your options in storybook form when the game asks you to pick between two types of Hearthlings (one medieval-ish group and one nomadic, desert-like group), two types of biomes (temperate or desert), and two types of game (either you can be raided by enemies or you can't). Then your map is generated and you select where on that map you want to settle. Each region has access to different resources.+ Trade events. Just about every day, a trader will come by offering different deals. You can buy or sell certain goods from some, some will ask you to make them x number of items then come back after a set amount of time to trade you something agreed upon for them... It keeps things fresh and gives you new ways to get resources you maybe don't have access to based on where you settled.+ Hearthling jobs. There are several different jobs in the game and they all feel useful. Every Hearthling starts off as a basic laborer, who can only gather resources, haul them, or build. With items (most of which are constructed by the various crafting jobs), you can promote a hearthling to any number of other jobs such as Farmer, Carpenter, Tailor or Trapper. Every job has levels that increase as your Hearthling performs that job and gains experience. At each tier, a new ability is unlocked. These range from increased speed to the ability to randomly create high-quality furniture that takes on a finer appearance than the base item being crafted. Many jobs are also laid out in a tree wherein you must have a Hearthling of level x in one job to promote to another. For example, Cook requires Farmer at level 3.+ The ability to save your building designs for easy placement later.THINGS THAT NEED WORK:- Currently it's very difficult (possible though!) to build a second floor that functions. I'm sure this will be ironed out as the game plods along in development, though.- A few of the job abilities aren't implemented yet, but this will definitely be remedied later just on nature of the status being "not implemented".- You get occasional errors when trying to do things, pretty much always in regards to building. They haven't crashed the game for me, it's basically just the game telling me the engine didn't understand what I was trying to do.- Sometimes the building bugs a bit, but all that generally means is that you have to cancel building and start designing from the start again. Bit of a pain, but with trial and error, you'll get where you're going, and this is sure to be ironed out in the long term.FINAL VERDICT:It's already an incredibly addictive game for me. In its current state, I'd rate the game a solid 7.5/10. It has the potential to be at LEAST a 9. If for whatever reason you trust my opinion, I'd tell you this game is worth the buy right now. It's one of the sharpest alpha states I've ever seen for a game and there's already so much to enjoy and lose hours in. Five hours in, I've only scratched the surface of jobs and the like and I'm still going strong. I can see myself easily logging over 100 hours in this thing.

Early Access Review
								For months I looked at this game on Steam and thought to myself, "Hey, that looks kind of neat, seems kind of fun, and I think I'd like to try it sometime, but there's probably other stuff that I'd rather play first, so I'll just wishlist this and maybe get back to it when it goes on sale again someday."Well, after maybe six months of that attitude, I finally broke down and bought Stonehearth. And played it. And played it. And still play it. And I love it. Now my attitude is more like, "What in the heck was I thinking when I decided to wait so long? This game is cool!"If you like the 8-bit type them to games, and love the simplistic visual style of old '80s and early '90s games, then you will love this game. It might LOOK simple and basic, but it's actually a VERY engrossing game! But be warned: if you have a life and responsibilities, such as a job, children, spouse or friends, this game is going to start competing with their time. It's THAT fun.I love it. I shouldn't have waited. Would definitely get re-addicted again. Just one more block. Just one more block. Just one more block...9/10

content:
Posted: February 3
Early Access Review
								This is a very satisfying game with a rather cute artstyle that scratches all the itches that towns left me with.Essentially, you indirectly command a small village of settlers to build up a town, attract new residents, and defend your town from raids by wolves, zombies, goblins, kobolds, and all sorts of similarly nasty monsters.The game, unfortunately, can be quite straining on your computer when you have a lot of villagers, but since I've started playing, the game's performance and optimisation have both improved dramatically. When I started playing, the game would get completely bogged down at around 20 villagers and they would stand around doing nothing until they starved, now I can have 30 villagers comfortably and the game only gets a little clogged after playing for several (8+) hours with that number of villagers.The developers are also very communicative and active and chat with the community regularly to take suggestions and feedback. If you enjoy citybuilding and sandboxy games then I really can't recommend this game enough.

content:

Early Access Review
								A very enjoyable sandbox game. Want to lay back in your chair, tell the hearthlings to build templates, grow large farms and just enjoy watching them... This game is for you... Later when Oggo's army comes, you can see it burn down. :)Are you a stratigic mastermind looking for a challenge, wanting to build large cities and castles and fight off evil, and well, build an invicible empire... This game is for you.... And don't you worry, Oggo's army will test how invincible you just think you are. ;)Personally, I don't like it... I love it! You build a city, maybe an economic or a military powerhouse, while a simple but very enjoyable script of events undergoes, and how to tackle them is up to you. Of coursen there are also random events or raids that happen during all of this so you get a little disparity between games.But every game has it flaws, for this game, it's mostly bugs like: During the event of the Goblin chieftain, when you say you're gonna pay him tribute but wait it out and he's asking you for the last time before attacking, you can just press esc and it will go back to the notification bar, until you say "I have changed my mind" or pay the tribute. And the blacksmith leveling process, yeah, I get it's very late game but to mine up and let him smelt literally 500+ ores, just to get him to lvl 4 so you can finally get the engineer and do it all over but with cogwheels... The process gets a bit to  grindy.And for Oggo's army, you need atleast 2 decked out knights (and a max lvl healer), which again requiers a lvl 3 - 6 smith.Now if you should buy this? For me, the price is right, it's a well made (alpha) game and if it will be multiplayer later on.... It's very much worth it.If you should buy this now during early access or later is up to you, if you don't mind restaring worlds that you have built on, then yes. Otherwise wait.I have been playing this since alpha 2,5 came out, and I think it has been a blast watching the game unfold, becoming bigger and more complex for every uppdate and test new things out, so if you want to help the developers and ge tthis feeling, buy it.For you who'll wait until the full release... 1v1 me later when/if multiplayer comes! ;)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is much like a city builder, but with some RPG/Adventure elements in it. The goal is to keep your Heartlings, or citizens alive by finding resources, building houses and defences and fighting off invaders. When I first got into this game I had a hard time getting used to it. There were many game breaking bugs that got your Heartlings stuck or buildings that could not get finished. Most of the bugs have been fixed and you won't run into any for the most part. The ones that do are often easily shrugged off.UiThe game is quite easy to get into. The UI is quite easy to handle and you can easily access any information you might need. Important events like raids, level-ups or traders will pop up and notify you of their arrival. You can "slice" the ground  so you can see your mines underground and the same can be done for the buildings (although this might need some improvement for buildings with multiple floors). BuildingBuildings can be made in any way you want as these can be build much like Minecraft block by block. After you're finished editing your building you can let your Heartlings build it for you. The game also offers some blueprint for you when you don't feel like building houses yourself and these too can be edited to your liking. When building starts your heartlings will get everything they need to build the structure bit by bit. They even build scaffolding to make the building making it cool to see your buildings being build from the ground up.ProfessionsYour heartlings will be able to be given specific roles. Like a carpenter, a farmer or a footman. This will allow them to level up in this respective tree which in turn will allow you more to make and progress your town further. Each role has their benefits and are overall very well balanced out. You will mostly want to have all of them every time.ChallengesWhile supplying your town with supplies is not hard all on its own, it does get a bit more exciting when enemies start appearing. Having to call back your citizens to the safety of your building while your footmen, knights, archers and clerics move in to take care of the threat. Combat is really fun, even when it's this simple it still gets you to hold your breath sometimes when its a close call for one of your soldiers. StoryThe game does not have much story going on yet. But it is easy to see the potential the game has and the devs are working on the story as we speak. Which brings me to the next part.DevelopmentNow, many people have been complaining about how slow the game has developed over the last months. And I can't blame them. But one thing you must keep in mind is that the development team is a small one. Personally I still back the dev team as they seem to actually care about the game.My overall opinionI like this game. Quite a bit. It is a bit like minecraft but more strategy based. Which I like. The game's theme is great. Very cute and playful making even the biggest fights look cute and huggable. The game still lacks some contend but even now I would pay my 30 bucks for it and think it money well spent. I love the system of the game and the way it works. The UI is simple and much to my liking. My only real downside is that I too would wish for more content being thrown out more rapidly. I give this game a 8/10. Some might say this is way too high. But you just cant deny this game is a lot of fun and still has a whole lot of potential. I hope the game gets some big updates in 2017 and I feel like the devs will deliver on this. My advice? Buy this game! Support these developers. It's small companies like these that make the greatest games. If given the chance.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								What can I say? This game is just a ton of fun. I soaked up 4 hours playing this when I first bought it. If you like town/city builders, and like to manage colonies and the like, then this game is right up your alley. I thought that the art style would bug me at first, but to be honest, it is kinda nice. You don't get caught up in the graphic nature being a big point in the game, even though you can make some nice loking buildings and stuff anyway.Stonehearth looks like Minecraft, but plays very differently. It is in a top down-ish format, so you aren't controlling a single character, but rather managing what the colonists will work on. I won't go too much into the mechanics of such a game, as it isn't the first to do such a thing, but it is worth noting that you don't have IMMEDIATE control over what the colonists do, unless they are doing nothing at the time.This is an amazing game. I can only assume it will get even better, and it looks as though the devs intend to stick with it, fixing some annoying bugs already. If you are on the fence, I'd say just buy it, give it the 2 hours to decide, and if you don't find yourself completely wowed by it, Steam will give you a refund. You really can't go wrong here.
