								I've been following Stonehearth for years, and finally picked it up on Steam.  It's a very fun game for passing the time. Buildings can be custom designed as well or you can use some of the pre created cookie cutter models.The game is still in alpha but its looking very good and is very playable as it is.Another massive pro is their support!  I had one issue and they immediately replied and had several team members assisting me.  After some other recent Alpha flops I can't tell you how reassuring that is!!!  Very much appreciated.I hope this game only gets better and better!

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Rewrote this Review due to new updates, current Stable: Alpha 17, but Alpha 18 is playable and looking good too. Previous Review had 4 of 7 Helpful votes.Short Version: It's still a Dwarf Fortress/Gnomoria style game, but less focused on deep digging and more on exploration, crafting, and building. Class System is simple but interesting and more unique than simply assigning jobs, and much more user friendly than most. Don't let the simplicity fool you though, you can pour some fair time into this if you like these kinds of games.Since my previous review, it's still in Alpha, but has resolved or at least lessened alot of the Optimization issues, with more tweaks focused on that to come - judging by the dev blog and their videos, they genuinely care about fixing this, and they should since 2d Dwarf Fort lags up pretty bad once you have a big enough population going, imagine how bad it's going to be in a 3d game like this. Smart focus on their part, one of the rare devs that learns from others' issues, unlike every MMO dev out there.The AI is much better now, though still a little prone to bad decision-making. You can somewhat "control" their pathfinding by building Roads, as it favors those almost exclusively unless no road exists to follow nearby. The Building issues I had before seem resolved for the most part, though I'll still find a ladder or scaffolding stuck floating and undestroyable without using the Console.Combat has advanced by leaps and great bounds since my previous review - many more weapon/armor options, as well as 3 new classes: the Knight, with heavier armor and 1h/shield focus, bonus defense/stats and buff auras for his allies, as well as Taunt skills to protect the squishies - the Archer, your standard ranged attacker who can either slow or burn enemies based on their Arrow Quiver equipped(and double-shot at max lvl) - and most importanly, the Cleric, a Healer Monk who can do melee dmg and defend himself but puts their first priority as healing any nearby units with damage, both directly and through a passive aura. I make 2 groups of 1 of each class and it protects my bases pretty well + deals with the Story armies nicely.The Mining system is a little more controllable now but still not as fine-tuned as I would like to see, and usually see in other games of this kind - there's no Ramps or Stairs to be dug, and manually digging them up doesn't usually work because the AI prefers to build and use Ladders instead of stepping up/down 1 block steps.Overall they're making nice strides in the right direction, and I'm eager to see more.Bonus: There's already a decent-sized Mod community, and they make some pretty good mods so far, from whole new classes and items to entire Biomes(The Archipelago one is awesome)

Early Access Review
								At the time of this review (7-16-2016), I would say the game is already worth the purchase price. There are so many games that charge far more while delivering far less. And this game is only in the alpha stage. As many have already commented, if you like sim games (SimCity, Civilization) and other open-world, crafting type games then this is worth a look. With any sim/crafting game there is a learning curve and there is one here, but it hasn't felt particularly harsh. One thing that really struck me was the quality of the music--it's fantastic. Like, Howard Shore cinematic quality. Well done, sir.

Early Access Review
								While I may not have that many hours for this game on steam, I have played more than 20+ hours outside of Steam and have been following it since it first appeared on Kickstarter. This game is definitely worth your money, it's a great combination of RPG and City building and has many planned features that are currently being added or will be added eventually. Another great thing this game has is its active developers, who have consistently provided updates on the games progress and listened to the communities feedback, so you always know what's going down and will never leave the community out of loop wondering where the games is *Cough* Cube World *Cough*. If you want to see for yourself simply go to stonehearth.net and visit the Dev Blog.So if you're into city builders, RPG's and active developers this game is for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really do love the concept of this game.  The game has settlers left in the wilds to fend for themselves.  They slowly start to learn the basics to create their own city and a home for themeslves.At this point, though, the game is not ready.  The bugs are hard to get over and the game has not been updated to handle 'end of game' content or what happens when you level.  I build a place for everyone to sleep, to eat and then I'm pretty much done.  I have everyone collect resources, but really this only happens sometimes.  My blacksmith or Mason level up to create new things for my settlement, but I'm unable to impliment them, I don't see a reason to use them, and I can't make my own due to glitches.  Now I don't want you to stray from the basic game.  Despite this all, as I frist stated, the game is headed in the right direction and I hope it continues that way.  If the developer can pull this all together I think we'll have a huge hit on our hands a game I won't be able to stop playing.I do think the game is worth a try!  Watch out for the goblins!

Early Access Review
								I love this game, it'll keep you entertained for hours as you build up your town and train your men. Lots of crafting and expansion to be achieved in here. But that's honestly all I have to say bad about it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								StoneHearth has a very "cutesy" and "family friendly" look to it, and has a good and wide range of genres mixed together. its a great game for kids and adults alike.now the game is not "feature complete" or anything like that, it still has a lot of content to be added, but dont worry the devs wont give up, and most certaintly will finish the game.word of warning, the game is still very buggy. but then again that is the entire point of an alpha, squash the bugs and add awesome content. if you dont like the idea of playing a game that has lots of bugs and potential to crash, then this game is not for you. however if you love being right up front helping the devs hunt down and squash those bugs, then i recomend this game.Edit: it's been over a year since i reviewed this game, and i gotta say, Stonehearth has come a looonng way since my original review. the game has a ton of new features: new playable race, new monsters and campaigns, bunch of new classes, perfomrance improvements. and a bunch of other good stuff. and yes, there are still bugs and some crahses, but they'tend to be less frequent as before.so even after a year, i'd still recomend this game to anyone who likes town/city builders, early acces games, finding/reporting bugs, and being part of a great and friendly comunity.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've always been big on strategy games (since mid-late 90s) where you build your base, army, and go off killing those who try to kill me, such as command & conquer series, age of empires series, stronghold series and more.  I saw this game, "Stonehearth", on Kickstarter and just loved the whole concept.  they even had a great goals display to show you what their plans are.  Now I was skeptical to even put my money down because I was afraid they will just stop eventually and disappear like a great game that had potential, (The Stomping Land).I must say I’m very happy to have put my money in and then support them.  I played it since the beginning, even though I only have a total of about 15hrs, I just fell in love.  I stopped playing so that it can come up with better fixes, changes like any newly forming games.  I played it recently within few months and my goodness, it's even better!  they even have a dev map and objectives! I love it!Honestly, I highly consider this game to anyone that likes this whole minecraftish, base building, survival sandbox.  you can wait to buy it later or buy now, still great.  the dev's constantly work on this, they don't quit, they find more issues and fix them. they show videos on what they are working on, their issues they've encountered and so on.  I’m glad I put my money into this game.  i know in few months, this will become better than it is now with the speed and dedication all these workers put in.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the greatest Alphas I've ever seen. Period.Want to hear the details? Well, my fellow offspring of Rayya, sit tight for my story will be a long one.It's hard to begin describing what's so good about the game.Is it replayability?Great community? (and believe me, I don't treat these words lightly)Catchy art style?Responsive and responsible team?Warm and fuzzy atmosphere of cuteness?Before Alpha 16 Stonehearth, while interesting, was a barebone system. Now it's a game, and with the new hard mode it's challenging exactly how you want it to be. With multiple military classes and new difficult enemies able to break through your doors you get yourself dragged into the turmoil of battles trying to keep your little sandbox settlement safe.What games does Stonehearth resemble? Suddenly, Dungeon Keeper. There is no dungeon, yes. But the same "indirect control" and "build your town" principle is still here, and voxel retro graphics gives you the right nostalgic vibe.Thanks to Stonehearth I have discovered Discourse - a free and open-source web 2.0 engine SH forums are built upon.Thanks to Stonehearth I got myself deeply interested in voxel graphics. And finally installed Blender.This game is built with love. But more than that, it is built with extreme mod-friendliness in mind, that, I won't fear to say, I've never seen before. Information is in an easy readable format. For every task, there is a free software available. If there is a downside, it's that skilled programmers are yet to turn their attention to the game.For those who like looking at a pros/cons list (I'm one of those types), here's one.+ Already playable and very enjoyable+ Watch and influence development through Discourse forums, Twitch streams and Trello feature lists (with voting for feature priority)+ Easily moddable (including translations, many are already available - check the forums)+ Quite playable without any mods (unlike that dragon-slaying bestseller RPG)+ Nice, if somewhat simple, 16-bit stylized voxel graphics+ Create building templates, then share them (or not)+ Nice music+ Active development (unlike some other titles, Stonehearth is an example of an Early Access done right)+ Rabbits- BugsBe ready for them. This is, after all, an alpha. While there is backward save compatibility now, I recommend starting a new game with every new major Alpha release. Some bugs have workarounds. Sift the forums. Stick to stable builds if you don't want to risk and make in-depth testing. Report bugs to the forums.- Lacking pathing and priorityThe cause of unfinished buildings in 80% cases is that hearthlings can't get to the next queued block with current scaffolding. Try building more ladders manually. It gets better with every major alpha, but still has issues.- The price is arguably a bit too highI'd like to mention separately some things that are planned, but not there yet:- No water physics- No weather effects/seasons- Some classes are missing (namely Magmasmith and Geomancer - yes, you will be able not only do digging, but raise mountains as well). As of Alpha 17, Engineer is in development.- No multiplayer (it's late in the dev queue). I'm amazed how playable the game is with no multiplayer yet.- Diversity of items is comparatively poor. Will be fixed, but the eyes of the devs' right now remain on gameplay (which is, in my opinion, totally justified). So no Cthulhu... yet. Can be somewhat fixed with mods (but still no Cthulhu).- Building mode is still limited and lacking (gets better with every major Alpha though)- The number of biomes is currently limited to 2 (will be more). You can try fan-made ones.- The number of playable races is currently limited to 2 (will be 3 or so)You may think the review is full of flattery. Your right. Make your research, see for yourself. All and all, with no revolutionary things in the box, Stonehearth can still be your heartwarming casual pleasure. The source of modding frenzy. Or both.The choice is yours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9
Early Access Review
								I want to love this game sooo much. It has so much going for it. There are just a few flaws in logistics that are keeping it from being perfect.The AI is terrible - My workers are currently all standing around "idle" while I have crap everywhere that needs to be collected (ores, wood, wool, farm goods). There is no way to direct them to do what they are supposed to be doing.  I end up having to use the cancel option to permanently delete the items even though some are super rare. Amazing when i tell the workers to delete the item they are all over it....There is no way to edit the land once you have mined it. If you make a mistake...oh well...i hope you are not OCD like me. I currently have the grass layer near my village floating in the sky because either i made a mistake or my workers did not do as they were told.Finally, once food starts going bad in your storage it is a nightmare. Your workers do not remove this rotten food on their own accord. You must manually delete each basket of rotten food. Im at the point now where I literally spend a quarter of my day scoping out the food storage to remove these rotten baskets.This game is definitley on the right track but I would still wait until release to see if these kinks will be worked out. If they are this would likely become one of my favorite games in this genre on steam.TL:DR- AI needs work- Need an option to turn off rotting food or make workers remove it on their own- Need a few more land editing options in case you make a mistake (or your workers)This is a great title and I hope they continue to improve these imperfections. Giving it a thumbs up for encouragement to the Devs!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
Early Access Review
								OK, Where to start.Well the game doesnt have an autosave so my first 3 hours are no longer exsistant. So SAVE REGULARLY. Other than a few engine bugs and trapped citizens the game performs well. By trapped citizens, i had to start 3 different saves as the citizens would spawn in some tress and be trapped up there. Engine bugs tend to happen when i place items into the chests.Its fun to an extent, once you have a knight, invaders are kind pointless as they dont really get stronger, just the same enemies in a bigger group. When you get a cleric it becomes stupidly easier to fend off invasions as they seem to heal only the knight and the knight likes to tank everything in the vicinity allowing for quick easier kills on everything else with archers or footmen.DO NOT BUILD TOWERS IN A HOUSE OR CITIZENS WILL KILL THEM SELVES BY BUILDING THE WALLS AROUND THEMSELVES.Farmers seem to be a bit slow a tending crops as well as having a short attention span, would be nice if you could assign a farmer to a specific group of plot.Altogether, Great game. Would recomend if you like being god.  Just dont build into the mountain side like i did, hard to grow crops under 40ft of stone.EDIT: There is an auto save, im just a ♥♥♥♥ing idiot.

Early Access Review
								I'm going to give a cautious thumbs up to this game. It is still very much in Early Access and it shows. There are bugs, unfinished features, very little documentation...pretty much everything you'd expect for a game still in active development.For all that, the devs are very active and quite open about where they are in the process and what they are working on. Much more than most other developers I've followed. It's reassuring to see things go up on their list and bits check checked off as features are added in.And what it does have already is quite fun and I find it rather addictive. Despite a few crashes and failed villages due to bugs, I keep coming back for more. There is just something so engrossing and relaxing about this game, I can't seem to make myself give it up!Personally I'm quite excited to see where it is going, and I think it is going to just get better and better.

								Sadly rare when a Kickstarter game lives up to expectations, but when it does happen they usually knock it out of the park. content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
Early Access Review
Review: Alpha 10TL;DR:Do you like games like: Cultures The Settlers 1-4 (Before the serie was butchered) Castle Story City/Town Management games Designing thingsThen this is for you.More about the game:This is a sweet little gem of a game. The play-style is very much as a Cultures-like game, where you give your citizens a profession, which they get better at/more experience with. And then they can learn the next step of the profession tree. As an example Trapper(Hunter), who get's the bright idea that, "Hey, i can just have animals in a pen, don't have to run around setting traps". Much like how it works in Cultures, but you do not have any direct control over your citizens besides assigning them jobs. Some jobs, needs a workbench placed (Click on the citizen you have assigned a job to set a workbench), from there you can order items that the worker will make over time. The more they make, the more they can learn to make, some items can also be "Fine" which looks nicer.Any citizen that dosen't have anything to do, will help build buildings, mine, gather items and cut trees if given the general order (You select areas to mine/cut trees, which then whoever got time for it goes to do it). The games building system is pretty smart, tho still needs some slight work. Easy to build, place the floor. Auto-snap walls, auto-snap roofs, manually placed windows and doors. But the game also offers building templates, so just click and drop more or less(Works well if you don't want to use time building fancy buildings).There are currently two game modes, one which has enemies (Normal) and one without any dangers (Peaceful). The game is not very challenging just yet. Tho it might be a good idea to try out peaceful, just to get the general hang of things before heading into normal.The game itself looks great, very aesthetically pleasing, the characters look charming, smooth animations, pretty great character variety, trees have different ages and sizes. Terrain looks nice, eventho slightly plain right now. Will be looking forward to a bit more variation.Currently the game is in need of optimization, but that is something that will come along, especially since this is still in a early alpha. Alpha is all about adding new features and stuff for you to do. Optimization mostly comes from the beta. If you get a low framerate, i highly recommend turning down shadows if you have some performance problems.Conclusion:Personaly i really love it, it is a solid city-builder/managing, with some added rpg and combat. I know city-building isen't for everyone, but this is a great entry into the genre.Worth buying, if unsure, take a look at some gameplays!

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								What to say about this game. First, it has a lot of potential. I believe it takes the best parts of games like Minecraft and Timber and Stone and meshes them together to make a charming little building/simulation game.For now, I'll do 5 Pros and 5 Cons.PROS:-Designing buildings is quite intuitive and easy to use-RPG-ish "leveling system" of jobs for your hearthlings to improve them-Can move your hearthlings similar to an RTS by putting them into parties-Relaxing and charming sound track-Active and determined dev crew that listens to player issuesCONS:-Sometimes hearthlings don't tend to certain tasks and will sit idle (can be bypassed in a few different ways)-Designing multi-level buildings requires finesse and sometimes doesn't want to work the way you hoped-Combat needs a little tweaking. If enemies run away, even if you hit them, they take no damage.-Currently there are various errors and cpu-usage spikes.-All in all, this game is only going to get better and is a perfect fit for anyone who likes to build, create, and/or manage towns and people.

content:

Early Access Review
								8-5-16I've had this game for a very long time and have seen it come a long way, here are my gripes at this point that have prevented this game from being great and finally landing a negative review:They have kept the game "playable" throughout development which was a plus, fixing critical bugs along the way as well but the game, from the beginning, could not function past 4-6 hrs of playing because of poor optimization. This really limits the whole idea of this game and really enjoying the full potential of having your own little town. Another area of "soreness" has been the pathfinding AI, it has never really been great to begin with even with all of the improvements to it over development. The maps are quite small in reality and more people would complain as well if you could play long enough on one without having to restart. Another reason of really wondering where this game is going or what the final product will become.Until huge leaps of optimization and pathfinding find its way to this game, I'm going to have to say wait till a sale or more updates centered around these issues.

content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
My OpinionStonehearth is fun game of Village construction and management. As the Devs said, it does remind me a lot of DnD or other fantasy worlds and universes. The Hearthlings all have their own streangths and weeknesses, but if you have too many they do start to seem quite similar. The building prossess for buildings, wall, canals, and bridges works quite well, allowingyou to build something simple and quickly, or complex and intricate over a period of time. The only issue with it is that on occasion the Hearthlings seem to stop building for no reason, causing you to have to save the blueprint and start over from the begining of construction hoping that it doesnt stop again. Rarely, they might accidentally trap themselves inside a buildings walls and starve to death because of this. Its more annoying then game breaking, but it is something the devs need to fix.The world that the Hearthlings can go to build a new home is quite diverse. Ore dominating the mountains while plants and fertile land dominates the lowlands. It cause you to have to think about where you settle at the start, as you dont want to send your Hearthlings too far from the saftey of your town. Goblins, Orcs, Entlings, Stoneling and more roam the forests and mountasins to attack, set up camps, and steal your stuff, providing quite the challange to defend your Hearthlings and stuff.Pros+Nice art that compliments theme of game+Monsters provide challange untill later game when you have a decent military and can deal with everything thrown at you+Animations on Hearthlings and Monsters make them have personallity and express feelings+Easy to use building system that is an, "Easy to learn, difficult to master" type of thing+fun and easy to come back to gameplay+Really helpfull devs that actually care about their work and the issues their players are havingCons-Building is buggy at times, but it is still in alpha, so this isn't as bad-Hearthlings are utterly stupid and keep putting themselves in dangerous situations sometimes and not at others with the same command issued to them-Mechant stalls only seem to get the basic merchant types and not special or more specialised onesFinalFor a game in Alpha, it is incredibly far along for what it is. Many of the games core mechanics are implamented, and the game is a blast. I personally cant wait for Multiplayer, Magmasmiths, Geomancers, the Expanded story quests, visiuallised travaling merchants, Transportation options, the Rabbit clan, alternate planes, Dwarves, titans, more construction parts and decor, the combat system expansion, and all the other stuff the Devs are planning on adding over the versions. Stonehearth is game game I would reccomend to everyone.

content:
Posted: January 9
Early Access Review
								I want to love this game sooo much. It has so much going for it. There are just a few flaws in logistics that are keeping it from being perfect.The AI is terrible - My workers are currently all standing around "idle" while I have crap everywhere that needs to be collected (ores, wood, wool, farm goods). There is no way to direct them to do what they are supposed to be doing.  I end up having to use the cancel option to permanently delete the items even though some are super rare. Amazing when i tell the workers to delete the item they are all over it....There is no way to edit the land once you have mined it. If you make a mistake...oh well...i hope you are not OCD like me. I currently have the grass layer near my village floating in the sky because either i made a mistake or my workers did not do as they were told.Finally, once food starts going bad in your storage it is a nightmare. Your workers do not remove this rotten food on their own accord. You must manually delete each basket of rotten food. Im at the point now where I literally spend a quarter of my day scoping out the food storage to remove these rotten baskets.This game is definitley on the right track but I would still wait until release to see if these kinks will be worked out. If they are this would likely become one of my favorite games in this genre on steam.TL:DR- AI needs work- Need an option to turn off rotting food or make workers remove it on their own- Need a few more land editing options in case you make a mistake (or your workers)This is a great title and I hope they continue to improve these imperfections. Giving it a thumbs up for encouragement to the Devs!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								So... Stonehearth.It's Early Access, and noticably so. Bugs, the fps drops lower the further you progress, your Hearthlings don't respond to commands, yada yada. Still, these bugs don't ruin the experience. Lower your expectations, it's not a fully completed game.The -in my opinion- biggest problem with this game, is the lack of difficulty scaling. Normal mode starts slightly difficult, but it gets too easy very quickly. There is a hard mode, but it suffers the same fate, except that it starts out very difficult.Once you've set up your farms and hunting grounds, your walls, your houses, there's not much that can hurt you anymore.Monsters don't destroy structures, which is both good and bad.Good, because given how clunky and weird the building system is, having walls get holes in them would be annoying to repair, unless hearthlings do it automatically, and then it becomes pointless. Bad, because they don't destroy anything. Put up some picket fences around a goblin camp without them attacking? Good job, they can't do anything to you now.With having said all this, the blue thumbs up might look strange, since all I've said are the negatives.But now that they're out of the way, I've got to say, this game is fantastic.The things that work, work really well.Having multiple combat squads, for example. Easy to assign, easy to control, incredibly satisfying to attack monsters from multiple angles, with seperate squads. Mining is easy, and the slice system is a godsend (and a necessity) for making multi-layer mines. The x-ray mode (it's not for finding ores easily, don't worry) is also fantastic. Being able to see your structures without all the other stuff in the way, it's great.And there is so much more good to be said about this game.Hearthling (they're the settlers, for clarification) professions are nice, and really allows for a personal story. Have a Trapper who has been there, doing the same work, for al the days he's been in the village? Let him retire, by making him a Shepherd (not saying all shepherds have easy lives, just that the hearthling ones seem to be in no rush, as they slowly walk through your village)!Maybe your farmer has farmed for so long that they've inevitably gotten exquisite knowledge about what they're doing?Promote them to a cook, and let them fill the metaphorical stomachs of your hearthlings!So, do I recommend this game?Obviously. But I also recommend patience when playing it. Everything won't go 100% perfectly, but if you work past the bugs, you'll have a fantastic time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth. Not to be confused with the card game Hearthstone nor the novel Stone Heart by Charlie Fletcher.It's a medieval town building game where you control what your settlers, also known as Hearthlings, do, somewhat.It has a Sims-esque overhead view where you can position the camera to watch settlers eat, sleep, mourn over the fact they ate a turnip raw, or plant the camera into a nearby mountain and see how fast you can scroll out of the mountain.Enough about the camera, what about the gameplay?It does have strong points, the Hearthlings can farm, mine, deforest an ecosystem for a chair, or be threatened by goblins about 1/3 of their height. Hearthlings don't fight back when attacked by monsters. Oh, sorry, they do. They just have to have another Hearthling be killed in order to do 1/4 a heart of damage. Sort of a human shield metaphor going on.The only ones who will fight back before wimping out because they were attacked are footmen, knights, archers, and walking bandages- whoops. I meant clerics. I thought this supposed to be a town building game, not a DnD set up.Before I continue, I'd just like to point out that the "heart" I speak of serve as a HP bar, when there is only one heart.The combat is interesting, albeit unforgiving if you are outnumbered. Enemies will group up if Hearthlings don't kill them fast enough and they will chop at their health like a chef to a carrot.Speaking of carrots, there's farming. It is quite smart to have a rot system on raw ingredients, but from what I know, cooking the food will eliminate rotting and make it an MRE, essentially. But before your Hearthlings can have a nice serving of cold soup, you must have a cook because it seems like the Hearthlings were spoonfed and never learned how to roast a carrot over the campfire you are given from the very start. Oh yeah, there are levels for jobs as well, still leaning to the DnD metaphor, since the Hearthlings get buffs and skills from leveling up. Extra damage, more recipes, being able to herd sheep you pulled from your bum."Ok, it looks like I need an archer and a knight since these footmen are getting destroyed by a sentient stump.""Hold on there! Your footmen are only level 2! They need to be level 3 before you can promote them! Just have them walk in circles around that small farm plot for 4 hours!""That seems easy, 4 hours ingame isn't that long, it's 4 minutes.""No, I meant 4 hours in real time."So I may have exaggerated there about leveling up. The Hearthlings level up their job by, er, doing their job. Farmers farm, Blacksmiths smith, Soldiers stare at dirt.Some Hearthlings level up faster than others because of their special buffs. There are 3, but based on value, the only ones worth having are Body and Mind. Body (health) is pretty straight forward. Mind makes your Hearthlings level faster and create better versions of items.I didn't really understand that. How does a carpenter take the materials to make 1 chair and create 2, while one chair is of higher quality?The higher quality furniture doesn't have any other use other than having a nicer look and a higher gold value. Trading in this game is similar to other games; Vender sells item at a fixed price, you can sell the same item for half. Sometimes you can get specialty deals from wandering traders. While some are good, the others are asinine. Some come along the line of "I'll give you one twig for your 54 baskets of pumpkins!" or "I'll give you 40 steel bars if you show me a smile, you heartless being!" Before you can make this transaction, you must wait a period because, I don't know, the trader has to preform a broadway play or something. Which makes sense, they make a deal which can be done in a minute or in 5 days. Sometimes you can get a trade for something from the other band of Hearthlings, which is nice if you hate seeing the same stalks of yellow vegetables. I couldn't say it WORKS yet, let me find out later, I got an offer for watermellon seeds and it just seems like it took my corn.Deforestation is also an issue. They fixed that by adding farmable saplings. "What? Now it's both DnD AND Minecraft?! It's just a rip!" And that is why those who point out things like that shouldn't make reviews. Wait... Anyway, be prepared to either have a sapling farm that makes 1 sapling every harvest, which isn't a lot, or 200 every harvest, which is just a tad too much.While writing this, I realized this review was long. Before I end this and rethink my life, there are a couple of things.Do I recommend it? Yes, I do. I'd recommend it only to people with beefy computers.What did you mean "control the Hearthlings somewhat?" Hearthlings act like they are their own AI, they run to get a log of wood that is guarded heavily by wolves. They destroy ladders from construction of a building while a Hearthling or 2 are still on the roof. Which, in return, they die from lack of food and things to do.What's a good starting point? Stay in the forests and on ledges, you can dig a trench and monsters won't attack your town (it actually does work based on it's pathfinding).

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has more in it than one would expect from an Alpha game. There is such a huge amount of fun to be had during your first play through, if you don't die that is, while unlocking the new jobs you can assign to your citizens. The game is cute and also quite the management simulator making decisions on what products you need vs how fast or what order you should do them in in order to keep your troops geared and healed to keep protecting your town etc. Overall this game is gonna get 4 big stars from me. The only reason I wouldn't give it 5 is tha the combat is just a bit bland. There are the healers, archers, and melee units. There is no differences between healers and archers they all work the same there is just a slight difference in melee units. All melee you will face only damage 1 of your guys at a time and just have a smack battle to see who dies first the only melee that is different are the giant ogres which have an aoe. So the combat is very cool looking and you have a lot of control as to what your individual fights do but the actual mechanic variety in the enemies is low to non but hey its Alpha theres alot of potential to be had.

content:
Posted: January 12
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a great game by Radiant. This is one of the best purcheses I have made on steam. It's a nice city building game unlike any other! Monsters will attack your colony of hearthlings, but if you're not into the stuff, you can turn them off. The UI is great and it's fun to watch your colony grow to a threiving city. Another really cool thing is that I feel more conected with my hearthlings in Stonehearth then I do my villagers in Banaished or workers in Rise of Nation. They have names, there own look, and you only start off with a handfull so you get to know them very well. Remmeber that the gam is still in alpha, so there will be bugs and lack of content.Good:-City building (I like sandbox city building games)-Can turn enemies on and off-Kid freindly-Nice UI-Can design buildings-If your not gooding at building your own houses, you can use pre-made ones.-Even there it is still alpha, it's not an aboundend Early Access Game like banished and other uncompleted games that are on steam-The devs will sometimes stream them working on the games so they can get live feedback with the fans and can add what the fans want while the fan talks about it.Bad:-It's early access, there are bugs and a lack of content, but they are still coming out with updates to add the contenct. They even have a multiplayer mode planed.-Lack of tutorial so it can be hard for new players, but the games is only in alpha and there most likely will add that later.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								When it comes to voxel games this might be the next holy grail. A sandbox "city building" game with crafting support and basic trading, this one mixes it all into one enjoyable game.Due to its early access phase its not a game I would suggest everybody to play right now. However, if you are not easily aggrivated by bugs in an early access game this might be the one game you have to try in the least.This game has a very active community which can be found trough the discourse Stonehearth website.Ofcourse the quality of the game isn't decided by its community, but the support the developers receive of all the players does help it to get in on track of becoming one of the better games out there. What does make the game so great is that it carries a replayability in its core design that will keep the players coming back over and over to sink more hours into Stonehearth.The music you hear while playing is not distracting and fits the game just right. Same goes for most of the sound effects. After about 15 minutes you'll learn to recognise the warning sounds from when your town is under attack and it feels almost like it has always been that way.The graphics aren't the best but its a voxel game that pushes the feeling of older 8-bit games into a modern 3D game environment. And it does it great, it shows a style that wasn't unique among similar games but if you see video's of screenshots you know that its Stonehearth. Together with the sound and music it just fits.The UI is userfriendly enough that without a tutorial you will learn to use it within the first 30 minutes. A small concern is the usage of the combat menu. You will navigate trough to many buttons in my opinion to react quickly enough to the enemy invaders of your town that there is a higher chance that one of your soldiers wont survive the battle.Also, because the game features your villagers as free spirited enitites, you give them commands that arent't always exact. This will give you the feeling that the AI is not listening or your villagers seem to be complete idiots.This can be very frustrating sometimes and with the early access bugs you will need alot of patience.With everything together I would give the game an 8 out of 10 score and when it comes out of early accesss I'd advise it to any voxel/city builder/strategy lover out there to at least give it a try.

Early Access Review
								TL;DR - If you like sim/survival games à la Gnomoria, Craft the World, etc... This game VERY worth it.This is one of the best Dwarf Fortress clone on the market at the moment. It beats games like Gnomoria out of the water mainly because of slick UI and easy to navigate Z axis for depth mining.There are bugs. But nothing extremely game breaking at the moment, the devs seem to be doing a good job of cleaning up their code.As some people mentioned, VERY CPU intensive. I've noticed that it seems the game has a memory leak problem, it'll run smooth for a few hours, but after 3-4 hours straight in one settlement, it starts to frame lag. Closing the program, waiting, and restarting fixes this. So at least it's not something permanent even if you have 30+ settles and a lot of business on the screen.I love the Tech tree idea, I hope it will come with a lots more jobs and advacements.Building design is HARD! If you're new, don't bother with it, take the default buildings and run with that. After a few games you can start banging your head on the design thing. It's not intuitive, that's the biggest problem, but once you get the functions, it DOES get  quite easy.Pros- FUN! The game might not be feature complete, but it's a hell of a lof of fun- Slick UI and non-confusing X,Y,Z in 3D environment nagivation (not easy to do imho)-Crafting! Gosh I love crafting, and this has already quite a few recipes. Could have a lot more, hope it gets more, but already very satisfactory- Sound and music: bravo- The two different tribes and map types give interesting variation in gameplay. - Some jobs are retro compatible, e.g. cook will keep faming. Which is a very cool feature- There are small quests and bigger mission types to get your town marked with township and such, so keep on going even if it seems you are at the end of progression, some nifty things are coming your way- Nice graphicsCons- Seems the mobs are very scripted, completely not random. Depending on your difficulty, you will always get the same waves at the same time. There are random mobs and spawns on the map, but by now I can already mark down when the first 5-10 invasions will happen in a Mid or Hard game. Takes away from the excitement.- Some bugs. Most annoying at the moment for me is that after level 6 or so while digging, mining highlight do not sticky. The task seems to be set in, but the yellow marker doesn't show. Hard to keep track of where I clicked.- Current soldier AI is not very good. I've had my soldiers die because they completely split up when attacking, specially when chasing Archer/Ranged type enemies, and they end up dying 1 by 1 even at high levels because they just don't work together. Lots of micromanagement needed on your troops which can be annoying.- Some parts of the game are no obvious. Where do you get sheep, or Poyos? Still need to find it out...Suggestions- Give workers levels too. They work so hard, and get nothing for it, poor things. But seriously, it would make sense to have your base workers be able to gain levels and maybe advance in things like: harvesting, mining, hauling (inventory expansions, etc...)- Priority system for the regular worker tasks (see Craft the World)-Allow remapping of the keys! I can't tell you how many times I send my damn tribe in alert mode because I am trying to turn a furniture piece to the left before placement, whoever took R as the alarm instead of ROTATION never played these games before :P- It doesn't seem to have any benefit to level up a class to the max before promoting your Hearthling to the next job. Would be cool if some bonuses would stick. Specially when it comes to the military, as a Knight level 1 might get trampled even if he was a Footman level 6 before.- Would be nice to be able to set patrol areas for your soldiers, instead of having them just marching in the base camp all the time- And on/off switch for soldiers would be great. If not walking/training, they could function as regular workers- Training area for soldiers/archers etc...- MORE MAGIC! Love the cleric, need more- Babies! Marriage, love, interactions, old age?- Fishing!- Multiplayer would be a blast, but I guess quite hard to do with Co-Op mode?- Dyes for clothes, more clothes with bonuses for the various jobs- Bit more functionalities for pets, don't even notice I have any most of the timeSpecsWin 10intel i7 479016 GB RAMGeForce GTX 980

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I enjoy this game for the first 30 or so minutes but you can tell it's still a work in progress. One major issue I have problems with is after about 30 minutes of game time it slows down and starts lagging. I'm not sure of the reason for this, I assume it's because it's loading more of the map into RAM as I explore. So i find that the more of the map I explore the slower the game becomes until it's basically unplayable. Once this issue with lag and RAM hogging is resolved it would be a great game and I will recommend the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DRToo exensive for so little content.In itself the game has a lot of potential. Basically it is a RTS Minecraft more or less. You decide what your villagers build, what furniture or weapons they craft etc etc.Sadly, the content so far is very limited. And it does not feel like there is any progress in this regard.After the first few nights it feels like there is nothing left to do. You have accomodation, a few farms and traps and a small military squad to fend off invaders.From that point onward it is literally just wathing your villagers eat and sleep.If the devs would add more content this would definitely be a recommendation. But in its current state the game is way too expensive.

								One of the backers, here. Game is still in early alpha, but, by this point, has a fair amount to offer. Keep up the good work, Radiant!

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've had this game for about six months now. Enjoyed it a lot ! This game is brilliant and is kind of  defining a new game "genre" with it's unsual mix. Minecraft, Final Fantasy Tactics, real-time strategy with complex economy and yet... a significant touch of RPG. You really have to try it in order to understand the thin line on which the devs are refining the new concept. One of the best thing is probably it's adaptability. The game let you choose without asking or inteferring if you want to focus on building peacefully or on the adventure and the fighting... or both. You don't have to developp and max every job tree available, yet you can try and face a really interesting challenge.BUT... I'm beginning to be bored. Maybe it's the fact that the game developped so fast during the first months... now the last 2 alphas we're about the building system. But everytime I come back and try and lunch a new game to see if the bugs in the building system got rid of... I just face the same fact : those scaffolding are driving me mad ! It's still impossible to build a decent 10x14 blocs, 2 floors house without having those staying on the stairs inside or on the walls or on the cliffs or...whatever... Are the devs going to clear this bug definitely one day ?

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a rather charming village builder. You start out with a handfull of "Hearthlings" to start out your village. By making buildings, gathering food, getting wealth, and keeping moral you can grow your population. I have been playing this on and off for the past year or so and have seen some great improvements from the devs and can't wait to see what is coming in the future. You kind of have to be in the right mood to play this game; sort of in a relaxed, animated fantasy sort of mood. But I suppose you kind of have to be in the right mood to play any game. Today, I'm going to break the mold and start with cons:-It's still in alpha. There are some bugs yet and I have found some in various parts of the game. -There isn't much of an end game. (That I know of)-the bugs that are fixed cometimes create new bugs. Pros:-The building aspect offers some cusomization with custom floor plan, building material, and a bit on roof design.-Depending on which job you give your Hearthling, they will progress in levels and you can promote them to an advanced job or let them increase their level at the current job and be more productive.-You have hard mode which offers a big challenge to your management with planning and managing. -The devs are very active and take in feedback and bug reports and fix them within a few weeks. -The devs also keep regular updates in blogs every other (or every) Tuesday about what's going on and near future plans. -I enjoy the cartoony art style. The Hearthlings are cute and the monsters are kind of ugly but in a cartoon, funny kind of way. -There is a job tree with various different jobs to give your villagers which is still in progress but improving with every alpha release. Hope this helps.

								This game has potential but as of right now I think they are asking for a bit much when it seems they don't have that much yet. The game is super laggy just a couple of minutes in to gameplay even on a monster gaming pc. And the gameplay engine seems very un-optimized when it comes to queing orders of building or crafting. For some reason they just refuse to make stuff for the longest of times and blacksmiths focus more on building than cfrating what you ordered and so on. Doesnt seem to be other players as of yet even ai is only limited too some random single or up to five unit squads attacking, but no bases or ai players to attack or loot. Very small map too. Still I am going to put this as a positive review because of the potential and what this game could be. Please dear developer, don't screw your fans over. You have asked a high price and received it, please live up to the expectations that come with it.But no updates in a long time and to many bus for me to recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Disclosure: I backed this game on kickstarterHonestly, I think this is the most gameplay-filled and most stable "Alpha" I've ever played.  There are some bugs and glitches here and there (Your villagers are REALLY dumb, keep an eye on them or they'll get themselves trapped somewhere and starve to death) but it is absolutely playable and very fun.I would call this game, as it is right now, a very casual version of the Dwarf Fortress/Gnomoria genre.  While it is not nearly as in depth or complicated as those games (yet), it has a great style and good UI that is more approachable than those games.The in game tutorial is brief but really good for easing you into this genre.The building system is also head and shoulders above other games in the genre allowing you to create unique and interesting buildings for your villagers very easily.The two factions campaigns are very short, unfortunately, and after the 30ish hours I've put in I feel I've seen most of what this current build has to offer in terms of prescripted events and variety of activities.  I look forward to more things being added later, but certainly feel I've gotten my money's worth already.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a big fan of games like Minecraft and Civilization I decided to buy Stonehearth even though it is only an Alpha. I am very impressed from playing so far (Alpha v11), yes there are bugs which can be game breaking and there is so much more that needs to be added, but this really has the beginnings of a good game. I've done a couple of play throughs and am getting the hang of managing the little town and it is very addictive. At the moment there is a bit of a lack of things to do at the later stages of the game, mining for minerals has only recently been added and beyond upgrading gear doesn't seem to have much purpose, but I'm sure more will be added.Of course, it is still in Alpha so there are many issues that can be annoying, the AI of your workers can be poor at times and they can just get stuck doing nothing. I think it would really benefit this game to allow some control over individual workers, or at least allow some prioritization of tasks because at the moment it is a bit frustrating when for example you want a worker to pick something up that he's stood next to but he just doesn't do it.These bugs aside the game is very promising and I will certainly be following its development closely. If bugs annoy you then I would wait for the retail version. If, like me, you like the look of the game and can't wait, then I don't think you'll be disappointed.

content:
Posted: January 7
Early Access Review
TLDR:Game I thought I wouldn't like because I've never played Minecraft, but ended up falling in love with it. This game is really amazing and it's still in alpha/early access. 8/10 and worth the price even in Early Access.My Impression:My first impression of Stonehearth after watching their presentation video was that I didn't think I would enjoy playing it. Although I have never played Minecraft, the graphics reminded me of it. I never really got into Minecraft because I prefer single-player games and because of the graphics. I paid $19.99 for the game during the Steam Winter Sale, and I thought I was probably going to refund it due to the game not being worth the price. I decided I would buy it during the sale and if I didn't like it I would refund it. I was wrong, I love the game. DansGaming also had the same feeling as me. He thought it was going to be a mediocre game and was only going to stream it for a bit. He ended up falling in love with it as well.Positive:+ City builder but with a mix of RPG elements and character classes+ Unique party system to manage your civilians easiers+ Multiple races and scenarios to play with+ Crafting and building system are near perfection, well done+ Fun quests and random encounters+ Different modes if you want to just build or battle enemies while you build+ Relaxing gameplay+ Great soundtrack+ UI is aesthetically pleasing  + Overall extremely well polished for an Early Access titleNegatives:- Optimization could be a bit better, depending on how high your citizen setting is at (I found my sweet spot at 22 citizens), performance can be slowed down. Fire effects also slow the game down.- Using the house builder at the moment is very unintuitive and not easily done- Could use more built in premade buildings- Bugs, things you would expect in an early access title- No steam workshop for building blueprints- No cloud saves- Added some suggestions to the developers at ( https://discourse.stonehearth.net/t/suggestions-after-playing-about-15-hours/27403 )Very Good Game: 8/10I have refunded many games on Steam before. I am often very skeptical of the prices developers list their games at, but I can say that this game is worth it's price even in Early Access.

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								So far I can gauge this game being a "Minecraft/DF town sim blend done right". Things that are in the game work well and good (until you meet bugs), and the whole process of managing your town is quite smooth and nice, easily the best or near-best of that I've seen in similar games.So, why it's "not recommended"?At the moment, there isn't much to do there. The amount of content that you can try is extremely low, vertical progression is basically nonexistent - you can unlock all the things that are currently implemented in the game in 2 to 3 game days (that's 1-1.5 hours of playtime at most), and afterwards there's nothing left to do apart from "build more stuff because you can and it's the only thing you can".Additonal grain of salt is the building editor - customizable buildings is one of the defining points of the game (that is, one of the defining points that is actually implemented right now), but the editor is rather clunky and hard to use in cases other than traditional 1-story building (multiple stories aren't implemented at the moment) with simple inner structure and minimal amount of walls. Try to do complex multi-room irregurarly-shaped buildings, however, and you will be fighting the UI much more than actually planning.And finally, the pacing of development is nothing to write home about. The initial plans (from Kickstarter campaign) were to release the game towards the end of 2014, you know. Now it's the end of 2015, and we recently had an alpha version where devs were mostly fixing internals, such as pathfinding. Going by this, it is extremely unlikely that we'll see any reasonably-sized chunk of gameplay - that is, content and actual mechanics - available until the end of 2016, and beta/release stages may follow even later. And that's only if the development won't stop abruptly at some point.To summarize, it's a game that promises really great things, but currently allows you to plant turnips, design and build simple small buildings, dig through mountains, and hit randomly-appearing enemies such as goblins with some swords (archery is not implemented yet). That's all.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								To put simply this game is Age of Empires meets Minecraft. It is still in Alpha, so obviously there are still bugs, however the game is completely playable right now. The only issue that interfers gameplay wise as far as I can tell is building, if you design complex and large structures sometimes your hearthlings (citizens/people) will have trouble completeing it and handling objects. Keeping this in mind you can simply use the command console to instant build the building or just build it in easier to manage chunks, and if there is scaffolding or ladders left up just use the destroy command in the command console to remove them. Furthermore, if you see that your hearthlings have yet to place an item there is a good chance you simply put it ontop of a block above the path they can take, in this case just build a ladder and take it down after the item is placed. I know you may be thinking, I shouldn't have to do this extra junk to play the game, but again it's in alpha still and the "extra work" is like an extra click. All-and-all this is a very fun game that gets even funner as they add new stuff and c'mon if an Alpha version is already fun and awesome then the completed will be even better.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Purchased the game 9 days ago after watching it for months.  It is way over priced at $24.99 for what you get in return.  The game is fantastic up to the point where you get numerous engine error messages.  The game completely freezes up after about 60-90 minutes of play.  No crashing, game just pretty much stops.  Now you can either check on the game every 10 -15 minutes and see if any of the people have moved or start a new game.  Starting a new game just puts you back into the position of having the same freezing game problem in another 60-90 minutes.  I have played on the 11 build and the 12 build version and the freezing problem happens on both vesions.  Hope this will get fixed so the game is playable rather than the DEVS adding in more content.  The portion of the game that I could play was really great, would just like to be able to actually play it longer and see what the people can actually do.This is not on my end as I run an AMD FX 8350  Eight Core Processor   4 GHz  8 GB Ram   64 Bit Operating System  Win 10.  My drivers are always kept current.

								Alright, so first things first.  This game is Early Access.  Meaning that you will experience bugs.  It is unfinished.  You don't buy this game for what it is, you buy it for what it can be. content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hello everybody! I have been with Stonehearth since alpha sixteen, I believe. This game is amazing, BUT definitely get it on sale if you can. I think it may be a little expensive right now, considering that it has no multiplayer and still in alpha and all that. So, here I will make a pros and cons of this game.Let's begin with the PROS:- Unique building system- Minecraft-like creativity- Recent updates allow for more complex structures to be made- Combat- Updated frequently. (Weekly updates/Bug fix updates, new alpha versions about every month or two)Now for the cons...:- Pricey- Buggy because it's still in alpha- Enemies are overpowered on harder difficulties- The game has the basic idea for turret defense but for the price it's virtually useless- NO MULTIPLAYER, something the devs said would be in the game in about 6-8 months, and about a year later it still isn't here.- No memes. (This one is just a joke don't get you panties in a bundle :D)What I want to see as a player?- MULTIPLAYER- Lower pricethats about it :D Keep going devs your doing great.would recommend if you can get it on sale for >$20 :)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wouldn't call this game fun. It's a bit satisfying to build your town, defend it and upgrade everything, yes. Fun? Not really.I've run across a couple of consistent problems, however, across the patches.1- Strongest problem I came across was a bug that kept the game going, but removed all controls but the camera. Couldn't press ESC, couldn't issue orders, couldn't interact with anything.This prevented me from saving / loading the game. I had to force quit.2- A BIG nuisance was that builders kept taking furniture from completed custom buildings in order to build other buildings. Effectively making my town with 11 buildings to have a grand total of 6 beds.3- A functional nuisance I had is that there is no way to influence what workers will do. I kept trying to expand up a mountainside, jut to have all my workers occupied elsewhere and none dedicated to mining.--As of late, I have noticed that most of the workers will pick an item, pick another, then drop the first one, then drop the second one on the spot. They do this over and over and then forget about the issue, setting off to do something else.4- As of the latest couple of patches, farmers will tile about half the farmland area I set, then ignore it and do something completely different and not farming-related.The game becomes generally unstable when the goblin invasions become "upgraded".The game is simple and a bit cathartic, but I can't in good conscience recommend it at this point. A lot of bugs need to be solved, and with the current early access trend, I'm on the fence about this game being abandoned before it's finished.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hey guys! This is my review of the game as a newbie to it. This Is a honest and non bias review. Ok. So. When first starting out you may be like what the hell but as you start to figure out what there is to do and the system it gets amazingly good! At first I wasn't sure if it was going to be worth $20 (steam summer sale) but within 30 minutes of playing I loved the game. It's fresh, intuitive, creative, and seems to be VERY OPTIMIZED for all of you who don't have the $ for high end pc's. I truly believe this game is worth the money and is definite worth a shot! Especially if your into games that involve build your own community, exploring, surviving, and taking care of your little towns people! The only downside I found to this game was that there was really no clear instructions on how to start or even controls, the controls feel kinda weird but as you progress you start to like them since they make building amazingly easier. Also that the game has a full base building system and resource system, caves digging ext. I am very picky when it comes to these types of games but this one was just to good to let go. Definitely recommend it! Worth your time for sure!!!

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Current level of recommend?Strong Follow!If your interested in the game I'd give it a follow and check back in a couple months. Game is still very early alpha and most of the updates are focused on making the game more stable while adding in one thing at a time. In its current state for its price, your looking at maybe a weekend or a couple sessions worth of game time. Updates are a bit slow but are pretty steady in frequency. Been playing stonehearth on and off since alpha 5 and the game does have quite a bit of potential (devs are also active on their forums which is a plus)If you do choose to pick it up just remember the early access tag means early access. In its current state you be able to play around with the basics but will likely run into bugs/glitches your village grows. Also, its a good idea to save before you start a new building that way you can reload your save should you run into any bugs/issues.

content:
Posted: February 9
Early Access Review
								I've waited years to play this since it's announcement solely because I didn't want to be playing a game that isn't fully developed. I was immediately captivated by it's concept because I love voxel-sandbox style gameplay but 4 years later...Fact of the matter is, at this point, anybody playing this game is technically paying the developers to test their game for them. What a way to save money, Every player pays you $25 to do the majority of your QA. Villagers randomly stop performing their tasks, the game progressively gets laggier, large majority of tasks don't have keyboard shortcuts (namely combat), you have to jump through hoops to drink a damn potion, etc.Normally that wouldn't be a problem. But 4 years...? Don't buy games in any testing phase kids.It also means you're risking your money because there is always that chance the game doesn't release.P.S. Shame on you guys for putting Marvel on the chopping block. I can't respect that decision. No matter how you cut it.

content:

Early Access Review
								Purchased Stoneheart about half a year ago when it was still in an earlier phase of developement.Team Radiant is doing good work, the updates are coming steady and the Forums got an active community.The game itself is... from my POV a mix out of minecraft and dungeon kepper.Where you pile up the blocks in minecraft yourself, here you assign a silly crowd of beings to a schedule to terraform the world in a way you want it to be.Design your own Buildings from the very scratch. Or dig. DIG! and build the dwarven settlement you always imagined.Personally, only played in Peaceful mode so far. Reminds of Settlers in the Free Settlement Mode.Hopefully, as its displayed on Stonehearths website, there is a multiplayer support to come. PS: This game is very RAM intensive, and even made a 16gb RAM machine crash once, from lacking memory.

								Game is good. Dont get me wrong its like a way easier dwarf fortress and Gnomoria thing. But heres the trouble, Its been in early access for quite some time and it still has an absolutely massive memory leak issue. After a while of game play usually around 30 mins to an hour, it starts to feel like you are clicking through mud. You'll click something and it wont happen for ten seconds or so. I dont know what it is about this style of engine but it lends itself far too easily to this leak issue. If its a known issue which all of the forum posts about it makes it apparent that it is, then it should have either been addressed or fixed long ago. Im wondering if they even plan to. content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Thumbs up for the game. Style is great, idea is great and gameplay is good. Bug squishing is pretty good (with interim updates for bug fixes between major updates)Progress?Their own progress graph and trello board claims that most of the single player stuff is about 70 - 90% complete? I hope that isn't the case.Having owned this since  the second day of the Kickstarter back in early 2013 I'm pretty underwhelmed at the content in the game. The Legos style building is nice, much better than it was a few Alphas ago, but the gameplay itself is still very under developed.Very few professions, not much threat, not much in the way of resource or tools to manage them.Even on hard level this game shows you everything in a few hours.As of Alpha 18, (September 2016) playing all this game has to offer currently, and seeing all there is to see -  will take you half a day at most. Taking the two "races" and exploring the 2 available biomes is a very similar experience after the opening 20 minutes of play, that might turn half a days entertainment into a day? Ok I was hoping for a well realised Dwarf Fortress with a decent voxel art set and a good UI. Not the full depth of DF of course, but at least on a par with what one man teams did with games like Gnomoria and Towns. At least that much depth given the backing and the much larger team involved.Sadly this isn't the way Stonehearth is panning out.It's more of a kids game. Very simplified. The complexity comes with designing your own buildings, and that is a great feature, but serves no gameplay purpose at all. It's like"Here's an abstract building game like DF, Prison Architect, Clockwork Empires Gnomoria, Towns etc.And here's a architectural Lego gameLet's put them together and errm? Well you can build big buildings on the map - and then imagine that their is a reason to do so - because in reality there is none."Then you are left with a virtual lego set. Which is nice and all, somewhere to express your imagination.But big buildings that have no purpose other than to exist? That's not really a game -  and I'd rather do that with a real lego set than in here.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								A couple notes on playing the game; Have at least 1-2 Farmers. Once you make one of them a cook, they help harvest, but you still need them to plow the fields. Workers are VERY much so necessary. Although the carpenter, potter, mason and other occupations do help build/haul, you're going to want to keep the people with low-ranks down on the worker size (1, 1 and 2 for the body/mind/spirit; Keep them a worker) Fighters and such need to be the most populace unit category (Archers, Knights and Footmen); At least have one of each with an herbalist. (For the three, high Body and Mind. Mostly so they don't run like cowards) Herbalist and Cleric; Have one of each. One heals while the villagers sleep/get into beds, one heals just by walking around/in combat. (High spirit for these guys is necessary) All "Worker-class" occupations need mind and spirit. All three are much so needed for the farmers than anything. ALWAYS. ALWAYS remember there's a pause button that lets you keep playing. Helps you plan things. Town watch; Love it, use it, learn it, remember to turn it off after everyone is done fighting. Always go after goblin camps/"stray monsters" after the next invasion summon (Ents/Golems/Etc), that way your villagers aren't defenseless.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have played stonehearth every now and again for a long time.If you asked me when I first got the game I would have said no, but the game has come a long way!This is in the core exactly what you'd want from a settlement city builder.You choose how you want to play, do you want to be creative? or create a strong military and fight monsters?The gameplay is great, and the building tools have improved a lot! There are still ocacional bugs and script errors, but it is way better than it used to be. Though I still hope for more optimization in the future. My computer is a decent pc, but since I have had a lot of problems with it because of age I'm not sure if this is true for other people. But around 20 villagers I start to get a fair bit of lag. I am sure a better computer would allow atleast 30 or 35. But don't go hoping for a massive village of 100 people with tons of activity.This is a slow paced relaxing game, that can be either challanging or creative, depending on how you play.

Posted: July 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								ALPHA REVIEWJust don't get this.  There's potential for days, but the UI and AI are both infuriatingly bad, which is made worse by the design decisions made for the game.  Wait until release so they can fix it up.  Right now, it's exactly what you should expect from an alpha build, and nothing you should expect from Early Access.  Wait a while, and this will probably be an excellent game.  The music - all nine minutes of it - is really good.  The art is charming.  The game is terrible.I backed this on Kickstarter and have been playing it off and on for months, hoping with each new alpha release that it will become enjoyable.  It never does.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I wholeheartedly reccomend this game. It's in Alpha right now, and it's fantastic. If it continues like this, the finished product will be a gem among god-like resource management games.Pros:1. Citizens (Hearthlings) that actually "think" for themselves. Feed themselves, clothe themselves, the whole shebang. Just assign them to a job and watch them go. They even run away from monsters, which I really appreciate. Unless you manage to strand them on top of a mountain, they're going to be fine.2. A really nice crafting system. Easy to manage, as precise as you want it to be. Personally, I like to set things up so my cook always has food on the table, but I let my blacksmith run wild between mining trips. Again, the Hearthlings do everything on their own.3. Building Construction. What I really like about this is the scaffolding the hearthlings construct around the building, consuming wood but giving it back after the building is complete. It's a really nice touch, in my opinion. The buildings are easy to design and look great when they're done. I would like a little tweak to one thing, but I'll talk about that later.4. Challenging Enemies. Basically, if you get into some deep trouble, all of your hearthlings are dead. I sacrificed one of my first footmen to a Varanus (the smaller variety) and it proceded to slaughter the reast of the town. The things that attack you in this game are genuinely terrifying, unless you watch seeing tiny litle people who depend on you for survival die.5. Actually a sort of story line. I won't go into too much detail, but there is some interesting stuff going on in the world around you. Goblin Warlords, Ogres, Necromancers, and something called Squirrel People? (They probably won't appreciate me eating their brethren) There's a prophecy and everything. I, for one, am fascinated.Cons/suggestions:1. Performance issues and low framerates. This is probably just my computer. It's pretty out of date. Beware people like me: this game does not run at even 30 FPS on older machines. Probably an issue that will be lessened as developement continues.2. Minor glitches regarding construction/buildings. The hearthlings will occasionally stop building things that are only half complete. As far as I can tell, this is an issue that occurs when loading a saved game. It doesn't happen very often now that Alpha 18 is in place. Also, game devs, I would like a tool to move up and down the floors of buildings while constructing them. So that if I have two floors, I can make the 2nd one invisible and just look at the first. It would make placeing things on the walls a whole lot easier. Please and thank you.This game is totally worth your money.(Oh, and whatever you do, don't place that decorative scout gong too soon. Trust me)

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								While still very much in the fledgling stages of the development, Stonehearth is still an amazing game that offers a voxel-themed sandbox/city-building experience that gives you plenty of direction with what to "do" next without being constricting about it.About the biggest concern I have about this game is the lack of micromanaging. If you're a fan of games like Dwarf Fortress, Gnomoria, or even Towns (or what you had hoped Towns would become), Stonehearth may leave you wanting for a bit more control over your individials and their priorities, or just the allotment of work between citizens.I hope to see Stonehearth grow bigger and stronger, particularly with things like Seasons, expanded climates and map varieties, and some additional aesthetic content, but that's no reason to not pick up a copy and try it out for yourself. Stonehearth has got a solid foundation, a history of active and attentive devs, and a bright future ahead.

content:
Posted: April 9
Early Access Review
								Nothing more frustrating than playin on hard... And you end up losing your fighters while defending the town because  several other fighters went to go sleep while the town is under attack. So your guys all die because they went to bed? THEN your game auto saves overwriting the previous auto save... WHILE in combat. Once all your fighters die, there is no coming back from it. They die, your town dies. Nothing can be done to fix it except revert to a previous save. Didn't realize that the autosaves overwrite the previous save... Or else I would have saved more often. But you know, I figured that was the point of regular saves so that you could revert back if needed.This isn't the first time this has happened. This, in my opinion, is a huge flaw in the game where instead of defending the town they would rather go fulfill their needs by eating or sleeping.I've lost everything one other time because my carpenter wouldn't build things... Unfortunately, when the game bugs out it can kill your entire playthrough if you aren't prepared.

Early Access Review
								From what I've seen, this game has amazing potential and is fun as of now.The good:graphics are cute and run fairly well,custom buildings are easy to make,fairly easy to pick up and playThe bad:BUGS, lots of emwhenever someone gets a new job their heads are absorbed into their torso!when crafting, I have no idea if I have the proper materials in storage. I hope to see good things in the future!current rating: 5/10

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game looking for a good city/town builder type of game with crafting and rpg elements. So far I've really enjoyed it. I think it really has the potential to become a very good game as development continues.The game looks great, has good replayability, and looks to be frequently updated. I love that there's a building designer! The crafting is good so far as well. The downside is that it's early access which means there are a lot of bugs, some of which require you to start a new game due to their severity (but the game is so replayable that it's not that big of a deal right now) and there are features that are not finished or not implemented yet. The UI is also a little clunky and there are some quality of life features I would desperately like to see rolled out soon. I would definitely recommend if you don't mind early access and bugs!

content:
