Early Access Review
								> In the middle of the desert with 5 other people.> Only had a knife.> One guy hunt for small criters for food.> Other collected prickly fruits from cactus, taste horrible and raw.> Slept on the ground with everyone else.> Everyone is upset about eating raw food, eating without table and sleeping on the ground.> Elected myself as their new leader and changed my name to "Mom"> Called our place "Mom's Basement"> Dugged deep under a small hill and made it into a house for everyone.> Strange little green man came by and asked for 3 hats and some clays we thought we were halucinating so we ignored them and pretend they don't exist.> Strange little green man became depressed and camped outside our place doing nothing.> Bunch of rabid canines came at us at night but we beat them to a pulp.> Everyone complains about lack of security and safety so we built a wall around our place and pray to the Wall God to bless it.> Nothing could attack us now so we started farming trees, vegetables and herbs.> We became an independent self contained ecosystem.> Traders came by to trade with us so we sold them a S**t load of pelts and bought bulks of Minerals because we're too lazy to mine for them.> Random people saw that we had lots of coins and joined us.> Conscripted half of the people in the group to become soldiers.> Trained the S**t out of them and gave them the best gear.> Became the strongest military force in the region.> Realized that the wall is actually protecting people on the outside from us, so we tore it down.> Went on a crusade and slaughter everything we see.> Build camps and place food there to increase the range of our crusade.> Tamed the entire region.> Got bored after a while so I went back home.> Play Stonehearth.> Ehh the game is alright I guess.

I understand 'early access' means you're paying to test but honestly this game is more of a concept/remakea than an actual game or early access.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Currently running the Alpha 18 build, game is heavily buggy when it comes to building, to the point that within the first major building I start, game bugs and can no longer build in the current game, even save/load wont fix it, must start a new game, and wait for it to happen again there. Very frustrating to have happen in a game that revolves around free form building. Another problem with building is hearthlings building up higher than the scaffolding is leaving them stuck up on some high peak waiting for someone to either build up to them or for you to make them a ladder. If you dont baby them, you could end up with multiple, or even all of your hearthlings stuck up there forcing you to use console commands to make ladders to save them.Currently the enemy difficulty peaks out very early, once you get 2 clerics along with 1-2 knights and 1+ archer combat just fades out. In other words, a leveled up blacksmith means you win. Archers never want to defend high ground and will always run to the enemys level and fight them there. No establishing patrol routes, only defend locations.Another bug I have found that seems to be constant lately is the starving of my hearthlings, they will have 0 tasks other than harvest food and will just stand around and starve to death instead of gathering the food.Game has amazing potential, the mod community is growing and has some good ideas and the devs seem to care and are constantly trying to improve things. But with the current build problems and building be a core part of the game, I wouldnt recommend paying for this game until its more consistently functional.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played this a bunch last night, and plan to play a bunch more in the future. This is a fantastic little game. I can tell it still needs some work, but so far, pretty fun. Things I wish were better:-The camera is a little awkward, and I wish I could get on a lower perspective to the ground sometimes, since the animations and art are so damned cute, it would be nice to be a little closer to the inhabitants.----It would almost be worth it to have a 'walk around' mode, where you can 'be' one of the characters-When you have a blueprint for a building, and don't build exactly the required item for your specified blueprint there is no way of knowing, and the workers will not override one door for another, and if you decided to manually place items into the build, the ghosty blueprint remains-Items like fences don't 'auto complete' the way I wish they would, and leave gaps-I wish you could follow around a specific character, and their overlay wouldn't cover up the entire screen.Anyway...that is what I noticed so far....I will be building adorable little towns soon...and I am sure I will find little irksome quirks. But, that won't stop me from playing.UPDATE: just picked it up again...still really fun. It seems like some kinks were ironed out. I really like this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								I once did a review of this game around when it came out explaining how the game was a little glitchy. But since then it has been updated a bunch. Im normally not a town builder type game fan but I really love this game. You have to use your people wisely and give them correct jobs. Such as a footman who protects the others if the footman's spirit is not very high they will run away or get scared in battle, if their body is high they are most likely to not take much damage. Once my footman took down 3 wolves without getting hurt because she had high body. Also there are specific tools, if you gave everyone a job and you want to mine some ore you wont be able to because only workers (people with no jobs) can use pickaxes. Although I agree that the price for this game isnt cheap I still highly recommend buying it.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								$25 will buy you five large cups of coffee. I would rather have the coffee than this game. +An interesting game that has potential if the devs come through on their promises+Lots of possibilities for creative projects+The best minecraft clone out there that isn't trying to be minecraft+A nice aesthetic-Characters move super slow even during fast forward speeds-You start with a map of the generated world, then must choose a terribly small section of it to be your entire game world.-The building system is difficult and unforgiving. Small mistakes means you have to scrap the entire building plan (alpha issue)-Very unstable with frequent bugs ending entire game worlds (alpha issue)-Currently a very real lack of content outside of the buggy building system (alpha issue)-The game has been in dev for five years but they are still in the alpha stages and they have announced that they intend to start making other games. They've really done a good job keeping frequent contact with the community but I'm worried they will eventually abandon this project all together if the seams cant hold it together.

content:
Posted: January 1
Early Access Review
								Well i have played this game for aprox 10 hours and i can say that at its current stage its not worth to buy it. The reason is that the game doesnt have enough features implemented to it and a lot of bugs.The good:+nice graphics+the gameplay is verry fun+the combat is ok (the enemary archers kitting you is verry annoying since you might end up chasing them to the enemy base)+the crafting&gathering system are verry well doneThe bad:-a lot of bugs-horrible UI for building stuff like walls and bugs out often. Editing a building is verry difficult since it doesnt always take your commands and its unintuitive.-at the moment building any kind of buildings its pointless. Your people can sleep verry well outside even on a bed for example. So its mostly decorative and to increase your value as a town. I really dont see the reason to build anything because they dont provide any bonuses and they are far to little buildings at the moment.-Mining or digging is verry poorly implemenred as well. For example if you want to mine in a mountain for example and then decide to go up you need to manually build ladders for them to go up or down for that matter otherwise the order to mine will not be done. Why cant this be done automatically by them? Digging also requires ladders to be built manually for every layer you go down because otherwise they cant haul what they have mined and they cant get out to eat and they will soon die. So you need to be carefull.-Poor ui and inuititive. For example it took me a few hours to finally learn how to edit a building and when, i had to google on how you can build roads or walls etc. These are just a few examples but its an overall feeling.-Verry ppor AI pathing. For example a lot of time i see my workers doing a hauling of an ore just to put it down and go pick up another ore imediatlly next to it and haul that one instead. Also they tend to take the longest paths when building anything or just leave their work completly do something else and then come back.-Another bad thing is that devs are pushing updates at a verry low rate. This game is from june 2015. so for over one and a half year the game is still in alpha. Also the last update was October 2016. That means that the game development will go verry slowly and you wont be able to enjoy it at its full features.My recommendation is not to buy this gama at its current state since it doesnt offer a lot of depth to it. Its fun to watch your people them build stuff, gather and fight but it seems shallow as you get depper into the game and the fact that a lot all of the buildings are useless and just cosmetic doesnt provide any depth to mid to late game.I would wait untill this game goes into beta before buying it unless you really want to try it or support the devs.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been looking at this game for a while now, something told me to stay away from it, but I gave in and grabbed it on a city builder binge. I'm sad that I did.I like the defence/survival element of Stonehearth, where camps of enemies will spawn around the map and periodically attack your settlement, you can either attack them early and risk your guards, or just wait out the attacks for the XP. There are also loot boxes and such around the map to be discovered, usually guarded by some mini-boss creatures. That part they did right, it's fun.For a game that's been in development for such a long time, I really wonder why there are so many bugs. I understand it's a early access game, but that's not really an excuse for the really terrible building mechanics. It's a city-builder game, if i was developing a city builder, the first thing i'd get sorted would be the building mechanics, at the moment they're extremely frustrating and unintuitive. You have no ability to change things once you've placed them, so if you want to extend your wall out by 2 squares, you need to undo everything you've done to get back there. This is really frustrating when building and planning complex structures.I'd like to see defensive walls (properly) added, or at least the ability to create stand-alone walls outside of the custom structure editor, for a simple project like a perimeter wall the player shouldn't be forced to stuff around too much. I noticed also that it's very clumbsy at sticking to things. i tried to incorporate a pre-existing structure in my town into the wall, instead the custom structure editor decided that the sections of wall touching that building now belonged to it, and not my wall, so the only way to get rid of those walls was to destroy that building. Annoying to say the least.Along with numerous bugs that caused my workers to get stuck on window ledges, placing objects is a real pain. I've been forced to build a cobblestone fence piece-by-piece because if i try to place more than one at a time, the workers freak out and wont complete the task.At this point I can't reccommend the game, I feel like I was ripped off, to be honest.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
Please note: This is an early access review.I tried Stonehearth on a whim after I had sworn to myself that I would never play an Early Access game ever again. This game has simply reaffirmed my convictions in this matter.This is not to say that this game is terrible - it's not. It has potential, and there are a lot of good things about it. It has cute animations, enchanting music, and a nice crisp graphic style (although I must admit that the minecraft-esque aesthetic is getting a little old at this point).As for how it plays, it is a minecraft derivative (not necessarily a bad thing), though instead of building and defending your settlement by yourself, you must order AI-controlled peons to do it for you. This is an excellent premise on paper, and sometimes it works beautifully. Watching your peons work, collect, harvest, eat, sleep and fulfill their tasks is sometimes very rewarding.However, in many other ways, this game leaves something to be desired. The UI is confusing, tutorials are nonexistent, the camera controls are clunky, the building tools are even clunkier, and the minion AI is so glitchy that they will fail to build even the simplest of structures. Even the basic building designs that are shipped with the game will be left incomplete by your peons once they start building despite having all of the materials available. This forces you to scrap those structures in an attempt to build them again, and of course, there's no guarantee that your peons will actually finish them the second time they try.Other crippling bugs include peons who will simply freeze in place and refuse to move. Even when they become exhausted and start to starve, they won't move even to help themselves. The only way I've found to fix this is to reassign them to another job, but in doing so, they lose all of their accumulated levels. Not fun!Issues like these are a bit concerning, considering that the game is over halfway through Early Access by now. But even with the bugs aside, Stonehearth seems to be sorely lacking in content. The plain, empty expanses of the landscape really aren't very stimulating and there's very little to do out there. Once you get your settlement up and running (and it's not hard to do, despite the fact that most of your houses will be missing the odd door, wall or roof), you will simply repel invader attacks over and over again, collect whatever loot they drop, and continue to farm your crops.This might actually be fun if the inventory management was enjoyable, but it's not. You can't really manipulate the objects in-game directly, so you have to rely on your peons to manage the plethora of items that you will craft and collect. Usually this means that they will throw them into an unsorted jumble within your stockpile; other times, they will squirrel it away in crates and boxes. If you have more than one, it will be anyone's guess as to which one they've put it in. If one of your items is missing and you can't seem to track it down, good luck finding it!Stonehearth gave me a few moments of fun within the hours that I played it, but mostly I just felt bored and frustrated. It's a shame, because I really like the idea behind it. I may revisit it once it leaves Early Access, but if what I've seen is indicative of the final product, I could probably take it or leave it.The good news is that the developers are providing regular updates and are obviously very dedicated to this project. It should improve over time. I really hope it does.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								While I love these type of sandbox/management games, this one seems to fall a little short. Originally, I bought this around the time I was playing Towns, and liked the idea that it was graphically superior to Towns and had a few more features in planning. Many features were still in development, but I don't mind supporting independent developers. Skip forward some months, and the problems inherent to this kind of development become self-evident. Even easy-concept games can be a nightmare when you start adding in features. While the community is very strong and supportive, the developers communicate frequently and consistently, the game itself is fundamentally flawed. Gameplay is only tenable for about 12 hours, from there it's the same thing in a new setting. At the moment, many core features of the game are either uninteresting or broken. The engine itself is unsustainable or poorly written. AI still breaks itself after enough time has passed (or becomes so inept at tasks they become useless). Town areas are by default limited to 20 citizens, because the engine really can't handle much more than that. The map bogs down after about 10 in-game days with very little activity (2 gb ram and 16% of a decent quad-core processor on PAUSE). If you're looking to purchase this game, wait. See if the developers iron out the bugs, but even then know that it's likely not going to be a game you're going to come back to or play for too long. It'll be something casual when you've got nothing else to do - download, install, play, get bored and repeat in a couple months. Pros:- Good looking UI and general landscape - blocky but tastefully done.- Good conceptual design of core elements.- Good balance between difficulty vs. reward - easy enough for new players, but can't immediately make everything.- Consistent small updates, if a little slow for what the updates usually are.- Consistent and constructive communication from developers and community.- Implemented crash reporting that actually means something will get fixed eventually. Cons:- AI bogs very quickly.- Processor hungry for package size. - Gameplay can get repetitive (not talking about unimplemented features).- Spend much time after initial rush just watching your citizens do things.- Buggy as hell, but to be expected in Alpha.- Gameplay is geared to non-expansion - there's no reason to really expand much beyond starting area. Just pick a good one and wall yourself in. - Gameplay itself is very short. When you've done it once, it's the same thing on a different map. tl;dr:Wait a while if you're following this game. It's buggy and VERY casual. Devs are slow, but do communicate.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I was one of the original kickstarter backers. This summer will be the end of the third year (going on the 4th) since this game has been in development. To say the progress has been slow would be an understatement. Triple A games take less time to develop than this has and it is still far away from release. Very little content because so much time has been spent constantly fixing things that should have been fixed in the early alpha's.A lot of the bugs have been with this game since Alpha 1. Especially with AI. They have fixed AI building at least 3 or 4 times and it still doesn't work right. They have to keep going back and rewriting code over and over again.They are nice developers but watching this game being developed has been amatuer hour. I was really into this game the first year watching all the dev streams and such but then it became obvious that it was going to be one of the longest development cycles in the history of gaming and I lost interest. Here it is - March of 2016 and they just had another stage of Alpha dedicated totally to bug fixing and fixing AI - Again! This game is very charming and the music is top notch. It has such great potential but many of us have been waiting a very long time to see it realized and we are still waiting....EDIT April 2017 - I just checked the game out again after almost a year. Some really good improvements have been made. They added a lot more devs to the studio and things seem to be moving along a lot more quickly but considering we are going into the 5th year that is not saying much. The personality system for the Heathlings is quite good but limited. It is a great start though and I am liking the direction they are moving in. Game is also pretty stable - it was running smooth although I did experience quite a few bugs. The new combat and classes are good - a lot better than the combat I was playing last year. The Herbalist seems like a total waste of a class. It doesnt do anything at this point and the only reason to have one is to make a cleric. They need a major revamp of the herbalist because from what I played it is totally useless.Overall the game seems to be coming along but it needs a LOT more content. I didnt get any stuck workers so it looks like they FINALLY got that problem resolved. Overall I am a lot more optimistic about what I played today then what I was playing last year but I still can't recommend it due to the low amount of content. Still no flowing water, weather, etc.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok, Picture Gnomoria, but with better graphics, better UI, and Papa Johns Delivers.Now you have your delicious or disgusting pizza, depending on where you live, and you can start your crafting and managing and building journey to keep your citizens alive. The crafting system is very simple and easy to learn, while still being of a good size for this early on in development. The raids on your town can be very simple and easy to fend off, to brutal cavity defiling, child sodomising, soul endingly devastating. So always make sure you have a Fighter or two ASAP. Focus on getting them better equipment over getting your next crafting milestone. Your people can live on without a Trapper for a few more weeks. They won't be living if a horde of goblins kill your Defenders and then your people because all they have for equipment is still padded armor and wooden sword and shield.This game is very much still in progress but I like the progress thats being done. Most games in early access that say they are still in Alpha (Which this one tells you it is right at the start) have half the content, and 1,000 times more bugs and crashes. All this has that I've noticed so far is a couple of UI and AI bugs and logic loops, and a small tendancy for data leak. So restart your game every hour and a half or so and you will be fine. Also you have to turn on Auto Save, which was weird. Sometimes your Citizens will go to move an object you designated to be moved elsewhere and someone else will get to it sooner and that previous citizen will still go to where that object is. Though once they find out the object is there they move on to the next objective which is nice. Sometimes in Gnomoria (A finished and released game) Gnomes will do the exact same thing but instead get stuck in an AI Loop and you pretty much have to wait for them to get hungry or tired to reset themselves. So far the majority of negative reviews about this game are about buildings not being able to get fully done. In my opinion since I have a fully functioning town with 12 buildings, 5 of which are custom design, roads, pastures, lengthy defensive works and what not, all of them 100% completed. That the complainers are idiots, and that they try to do multiple projects at one time, run out of materials and then complain that the game is broken. Much like that meme where a guy rides a bike then puts a stick in his own tire and complains about someone else doing it. Your citizens will do multiple projects at a time, and the game will tell you that you have enough resources for a building if the resources are still in your stockpile. That means that if you pause the game, and try to construct 3 houses, each time it will tell you that you have enough resources in your stockpile. If you are that tired and don't notice that logic issue, please go to sleep. Or stop being a moron.A couple of suggestions that would be nice in my opinion.-Make it to where when digging a mine tunnel, they auto construct ladders, since people will sometimes forget and well there goes 3-6 of your citizens. -Possibly already in development but if there could be some sort of food preservation thing. Like an Ice box or something that will keep my fruits and veggies fresh longer would be nice.- Lower the amount of food it takes to get a new Citizen at ALL levels. I am currently sitting at 15 Citizens and producing enough food for 80. Still can't get a new Citizen. I realize this may be due to the developers wanting to give people a possible Siege supply incase they take heavy losses to Food or Food production capability from a raid, but there is an option wether or not to accept a new Citizen. Let us take the risk.-Developers. This tip more than all the others is the most important and I hope that if you read this review and take anything from it, that you take this one to the heart. Give yourselves a pat on the back, and some high fives all around. You state clearly that this game is in alpha and its already so well done. I don't particularly enjoy games like this. Gnomoria is a bore and I couldnt stand to play it for more than 30 minutes. Any other game like this that involves city management with no Army management or Cities to pillage and conquer leave me bored and moving on to another game. YOU got me to play this for 4 hours so far, and once there is more content I can happily say I will gladly add 100 hours just to explore and enjoy this finely crafted game you have made. Good job, and keep it up.

Early Access Review
								I bought this game because I truly love the genre. Now that ive put a few hours into this game here is my two cents. the game concept is reaally cute, watching my hearthlings struggle to survive and build a town is about the most fun I think I can have with this kind of game, however, struggling with the interface to design buildings.. having my game crash, redesigning my buildings, crashing the game yet again. redesigning my buildings only to get the camera stuck beneath a tree I think.. finally giving up and just making nothing but boring square one floor buildings, was about the most ive ever cursed at a game in my life. Now im not a game designer but from the comments ive been reading these building design bugs have been lurking about since day one of EA, you would figure they would have at least made the building designer functional and mostly bug free.in all honesty I cannot recommend this game at its current price of 24.99$ you would be better off spending an extra 5$ and buying rimworld, which although is also an EA title seems to be way more playable than this and offers most of the same concepts as this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok, Picture Gnomoria, but with better graphics, better UI, and Papa Johns Delivers.Now you have your delicious or disgusting pizza, depending on where you live, and you can start your crafting and managing and building journey to keep your citizens alive. The crafting system is very simple and easy to learn, while still being of a good size for this early on in development. The raids on your town can be very simple and easy to fend off, to brutal cavity defiling, child sodomising, soul endingly devastating. So always make sure you have a Fighter or two ASAP. Focus on getting them better equipment over getting your next crafting milestone. Your people can live on without a Trapper for a few more weeks. They won't be living if a horde of goblins kill your Defenders and then your people because all they have for equipment is still padded armor and wooden sword and shield.This game is very much still in progress but I like the progress thats being done. Most games in early access that say they are still in Alpha (Which this one tells you it is right at the start) have half the content, and 1,000 times more bugs and crashes. All this has that I've noticed so far is a couple of UI and AI bugs and logic loops, and a small tendancy for data leak. So restart your game every hour and a half or so and you will be fine. Also you have to turn on Auto Save, which was weird. Sometimes your Citizens will go to move an object you designated to be moved elsewhere and someone else will get to it sooner and that previous citizen will still go to where that object is. Though once they find out the object is there they move on to the next objective which is nice. Sometimes in Gnomoria (A finished and released game) Gnomes will do the exact same thing but instead get stuck in an AI Loop and you pretty much have to wait for them to get hungry or tired to reset themselves. So far the majority of negative reviews about this game are about buildings not being able to get fully done. In my opinion since I have a fully functioning town with 12 buildings, 5 of which are custom design, roads, pastures, lengthy defensive works and what not, all of them 100% completed. That the complainers are idiots, and that they try to do multiple projects at one time, run out of materials and then complain that the game is broken. Much like that meme where a guy rides a bike then puts a stick in his own tire and complains about someone else doing it. Your citizens will do multiple projects at a time, and the game will tell you that you have enough resources for a building if the resources are still in your stockpile. That means that if you pause the game, and try to construct 3 houses, each time it will tell you that you have enough resources in your stockpile. If you are that tired and don't notice that logic issue, please go to sleep. Or stop being a moron.A couple of suggestions that would be nice in my opinion.-Make it to where when digging a mine tunnel, they auto construct ladders, since people will sometimes forget and well there goes 3-6 of your citizens. -Possibly already in development but if there could be some sort of food preservation thing. Like an Ice box or something that will keep my fruits and veggies fresh longer would be nice.- Lower the amount of food it takes to get a new Citizen at ALL levels. I am currently sitting at 15 Citizens and producing enough food for 80. Still can't get a new Citizen. I realize this may be due to the developers wanting to give people a possible Siege supply incase they take heavy losses to Food or Food production capability from a raid, but there is an option wether or not to accept a new Citizen. Let us take the risk.-Developers. This tip more than all the others is the most important and I hope that if you read this review and take anything from it, that you take this one to the heart. Give yourselves a pat on the back, and some high fives all around. You state clearly that this game is in alpha and its already so well done. I don't particularly enjoy games like this. Gnomoria is a bore and I couldnt stand to play it for more than 30 minutes. Any other game like this that involves city management with no Army management or Cities to pillage and conquer leave me bored and moving on to another game. YOU got me to play this for 4 hours so far, and once there is more content I can happily say I will gladly add 100 hours just to explore and enjoy this finely crafted game you have made. Good job, and keep it up.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you've ever wanted to create a village/kingdom with control over crafters and defenders, farmers and the sizes of farms, locations and the ability to move those fields. This is for you.First let me start with the cons -1) This is Alpha and does not represent the end product.2) It's not finished yet and has bugs.And now the pros in my opinion -1) Ability to set where you want to start your village.2) Ability to determine who is right for the jobs available.3) Ability to change jobs of your Hearthlings (townsfolk).4) Ability to custom build any building and save the template.5) Ability to place stockpiles inside of buildings for protection against raiders.There are many game aspects that I have not listed, but I hope I have at least touched up on some important deciding factors for potential backers. I love the game and can't wait for the release.With that in mind, every Tuesday they have a post "Desktop Tuesday", it's a great place to see what the team has been working on, and don't forget to check their website for additional information.


Alpha 14 (Latest Branch) 
A Screenshot of Stonehearth
By: Ryvucz




Alpha 14 Update -There has been a lot of new content and improvements since my initial review.New enemies, new jobs - herbalist (that makes potions and bandages for healing and buffs), cook (self explanatory).New crafting stations which allow a more unique look and feel to your crafters including more crafting options, more armor, weapons, decorations.They still have a lot more planned and coming, they still do their Desktop Tuesday so be sure to check it out!


New enemy territory, a crypt. 
A Screenshot of Stonehearth
By: Ryvucz




It is now possible to have saves from previous versions.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth as a game in its current state is an enjoyable playing experience. It has a mix of City Building, RPG, Crafting, and RTS elements that mix well together. The blocky art style is interesting and makes for interesting building designs. The terrain is destructable, and moldable to those with the imagination to shape it. The two main factions and later the other 2 main factions, along with the npc faction and all the enemies the games developers will be adding, offer a diverse gameplay that is enjoyable and will be even more enjoyable when they finish.Normally, I do not buy early access games because I don't feel like buying unfinished games is worth my money, particularly when there is the chance that the developer could just take my money and not complete the game. I have had an incident where i bought an early access game and the developer abandoned the project. However, that is not a justifyable reason not to buy stonehearth, The developers do regular updates and even stream their work on the game occasionally. They are fully upholding their end of the deal when it comes to early access and are model company for others in their line of work to follow.In this I must give Stonehearth my recommendation. The game is not complete, no, but I have no doubts that it will be eventually completed, and when it does it will be even more enjoyable than it is to play now.

content:

Early Access Review
								There are too much bugs in the AI which make the game unplayable. Your "Heartlings", or "Lazylings" as how I call them, go idle after a certain point in the game. Mostly when you go above 17-20 heartlings what i've noticed the past months. They stop mining, stop collecting resources and when you want to build a new building, they build it up for a part, then stand idle for many ingame hours... As a gamer you want to make progress but this game lacks a good enough AI to let you make progress. You can only build up a little, then the AI fails. Only thing you achieve here is stress and irritation, dont pay money for that.When the game has a proper AI I will probably update this review. You still want to buy this game after reading this? well, thank you, hope that money goes to the AI coder so I can finally play this game in the future since a refund is not possible anymore.

								Seriously I cannot say enough good things about this game.  The best early access Fort-like experience you can get in 3D.  This game and Gnomoria are the best Fort-likes on Steam.  The  dev's on Stonehearth are constantly adding new content and the recent update with a new playable Kingdom type and terrain just reminded me how much I love this game.  There are a few more playable races in the pipe if I'm not mistaken, and multiplayer! Oh I cannot wait till MP.  (It is not MP right now to be clear.) I'm an EA who ore but this is one of the ones I would recommend with no reservations. In the game you plop down a group of curated settlers in a hospitable or inhospitable landscape and have a solid town building survival experience.  Give Hearthlings jobs and watch as they level up, then you can promote them into higher tier professions.  With awesome mods like Candledark you can really add some variety to your game.  The community is great and I've got nothing but respect for these devs that regularly live stream their work on ye old Twitchbox.Edit: They added more classes!!!!I (still) love this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Cute, funny and interesting little game, with a dedicated, wonderful developer team.It's pretty addictive to play, just make sure you save every now and then.(especially before you're about to attack the enemy AI, if you are unsure) - because you might lose interest if you even lose one citizen, i've experienced many times. Also save alot if you keep using the experimental max speed, it could crash the game eventually.Sometimes it's a big unforgiving, but this game's kind of challenge doesn't want you to quit permanently, at least.It's always fun to see the game waiting to be updating in the download tab of steam, and I'm really curious on where this game is going. I had hoped for snow here in december :'(

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really like this game. Seeing the rate of content added with respect to the roadmap that the developers have made available on their website at http://stonehearth.net/roadmap/ gives me an inclination as to how much effort they are willing to put into this game, and it looks promising. The blocky and simplistic style of the game really contributes to the charming, cozy atmosphere of the game (when enemies aren't attacking of course) and gives you something that you want to protect, if that makes sense. The music itself is also charming, and fits well with such a simplistic style.However promising the game looked and looks, I believe it still requires a tonne of bug fixes, for example the soldiers going off to attack enemies without your command, and the unfinished building bug, however I am yet to check after the latest update whether that has been fixed yet. Another downside is that the normal difficulty seems way too easy as you progress further into the game. The attacking of small miscellaneous enemy camps can get quite repetitive and pesky at this point too, but I suppose there isn't really any better alternative, and it makes do for gameplay.At the time when I bought the game, I regret paying as much money as I did for it, however from another point of view involving contributing to the growth of the game I am glad that I took the gamble of it not being another abandonment in the piles of steam early access games. £18.99 is a little overpriced, even though I enjoyed it. Despite having addressed the negative side of the game, don't misunderstand me. I really enjoyed it, and await to see further development.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has a lot of good things going for it, and I think it'll get better.  The villagers and enemies are stylized in cute manner, and the little plot dialog that exists carries the cute theme as well - but that doesn't stop some battles between the two from being deadly serious.  Combat is simple once you figure out how to develop your battle team to survive with the difficulty curve (two tanking armored characters, backed by archers, with a cleric thrown in will get you by the majority of the battles).  I can easily see more event battles being added as this game progresses but it would be nice if enemy bases  spawned more often around the map - perhaps sending their own raiding parties.However, the real bread and butter of this game is customizing your village exactly the way you want it.  This is the most complex part of game play and it takes a while to get the hang of.  Editing a blueprint is tricky and time consuming at first but I highly recommend saving one to greatly reduce time later.  If your Hearthlings stall during mid-construction, check your available recources needed, then try manually placing ladders in case they cannot reach the upper construction areas.  (I highly recommend a building blueprint that has doors and window frames, but no other furnishings or decorations which can be added later.)  What's really needed here is more terrain options like adding soil blocks for leveling surfaces and undo'ing building mistakes.  Far too often I found myself relying on back-up saves because nudging a building over 1 or 2 blocks or fixing an errant click while digging is not very forgiving at this point.This game is good so far, and it's going to get better.  Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								An another videogame with potential.Created with the style of Trove and from the ashes of Cube World, Stoneheart is a strategy version of the two games and taking inspiration from other famous videogames like Imperium Civitas, Imperium Online and the Sims series.You can take care of your settlement (if you keep up the good work you can make it into a real city), of your citizens, promote them to different jobs, making everyone of them an indispensable member of your progression and your city; however (if you choose the right mode) there is not always peace around here: train some soldiers to defend yourself from any menace (wolfes, goblins, undead, animated stones?!), kicking their butt or send a raiding party in order to loot and destroy enemy camps.This game is still on Early Access and on the Alpha development and that means the develop is still open with ideas and I'm pretty sure that the final result will become a good rival and a strategy version of Trove

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								After the tragedy of the game Towns, there was no real replacer for that game. This one is quite the spiritual successor to that game, with a far more responsive dev team and prettier graphics.The buildings, if you haven't guessed, are customizable down to the very block. If you create a custom building during one game, you'll be able to save its blueprint for all of your other games. Yay!Despite the nice graphics and smooth gameplay, bugs do exist. Sometimes they are game breaking, but the devs of this game usually patch it within the next update, which is ~2-4 weeks. Considering that this game has been out for over a year already, I'd say the development has come a long way.You should probably wait for a sale, however. Whatever amount you spend on this game, it's going into good hands.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								After the tragedy of the game Towns, there was no real replacer for that game. This one is quite the spiritual successor to that game, with a far more responsive dev team and prettier graphics.The buildings, if you haven't guessed, are customizable down to the very block. If you create a custom building during one game, you'll be able to save its blueprint for all of your other games. Yay!Despite the nice graphics and smooth gameplay, bugs do exist. Sometimes they are game breaking, but the devs of this game usually patch it within the next update, which is ~2-4 weeks. Considering that this game has been out for over a year already, I'd say the development has come a long way.You should probably wait for a sale, however. Whatever amount you spend on this game, it's going into good hands.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been around since the beginning of this games origins on Kickstarter, and this game has evolved so much since then. While true, this game AS OF NOW is a little shoddy in some places. However, even with those problems the game remains to be a fun and enjoyable experience. The devs spend countless hours fixing bugs and moving the game forward, relesing beta updates on a weekly basis and constantly keeping the players informed, even taking in their suggestions on their dev stream and the Stonehearth forums. The game is, unlike most, being molded by not just the developers, but the players aswell. These qualities make me certain that this game will travel from the state it's in now, which is still a good game as is, to even grater heights.4/5 would recommend AS IS.5/5 would recommend for the future.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is Great, The AI is stellar for an alpha, (though some rudementary things could be fixed, like not trapping yourself in a roof and starve to death when you build a large building) the graphics are great, and the enemies are tough (in the begining) However There are a few things that could be fixed, and i have some ideas for the developers (if they read Steam Reviews)Game Mechanic Complaints/Ideas:1. Unless i'm stupid, the insta wall thing could be a click and drag(Like the Sims games), instead of a set spawn on the floors. It's Incredibly frustrating trying to jerry rig the walls to do what i want.1a. Make vertical single block placements count as walls(once they reach a certain height) And make walls able to delete SINGLE BLOCKS (or in general) so you can make better looking walls, Also, its incredibly frustrating too.1b. Allow Floor placement allowed to be clicked on the inside of a wall not just ontop, it makes the outside looking a tad weird1c. Allow the entire map to be accesible when you spawn (unless thats a bit too Pressing on comps) at least make it optional.1d. Make AI run a bit quicker (or notice the enemies from farther away) so they have a chance to run when they are far from the village and the guards1e. Make guards patrol roads, not farms and storage plots.1f. There are more, but their minute1g. Ability when creating your new town to go back in the menu when you change your mind.General Ideas:2. Have an optional giant invasion to happen at the extreme late game (for the sake of seeing if your awesome defences hold, or having an awesome dramatic slaughtering of your village)2a. Have hearthlings make the childrens (And see they're Genology so you can have a cool history)2b. Ability to make a mayor/lordly job (not sure what it'd do, mabye make hearthlings more efficent?) just want it for awesome RP purposes2c. New races to play (Orcs, Dwarfs, Elfs, etc.), More lands to choose (Swamps, Snowy tundra, Oceania Islands, Rainforest, and my personal favorite, Underground cave biome)2d. Fishing Jobs So docks have uses instead of just being decoration2e. Hearthlings(and monsters) have the ability to climb two block high walls2f. Green Stone option.2g. option to have the Ability to make muliple towns (on different maps) and have them interact with eachother somehow. (Trade? war? join together in an empire? Merely existing?)2h. DRAGONS!2i. demons and hell portals2j. Undead invasion?2k. Disease, and plagues (Optional for those who hate those mechanics)Those are some of my ideas. Such a great game even without all of this. keep up the good work!

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								     It's another early access, but why should you take the risk of buying the game before release?  This game is receiving updates every Thursday.  An update usually includes a new entity or two (some new content) and a lot of bug fixes.  While the pace seems a little slow, the updates are frequent and the two developers have a reputation of interacting with the community and effectively implenting feedback.     The developers are talented individuals with computer science degrees and related career experience.  Check out their website: http://www.radiant-entertainment.com/     They're not your average joe indie developers working out of their parents basement to make a quick buck.  These two are passionate individuals that want to create something truly enjoyable and worth playing.  That being said, Stonehearth still has many bugs and is definitely not as enjoyable now is it's destined to be.  And Stonehearth is destined to be the best Dwarf Fortress-like game of our age, that doesn't require a nerdy learning curve to actually enjoy.     Stonehearth is promised to be a depth-filled, fun adventure of building a village.  But unlike Banished or other village-builders, you will find yourself fabricating stories about your villagers as you explore, survive and build.  Just watch half the youtube Let's Plays if you don't believe me.  It's that imaginative element, that makes games like Stonehearth more than just another city-builder.  Stonehearth is not just another game, it's a journey into your own imagination as you build a village.  So, if the experience resonates with you, support this young and promising studio, as the developers craft a gem in the indie gaming world.  Personally, Stonehearth rubs off that feel-good aura, that this early access is an investment that's worth the risk!

content:
Posted: January 3
Early Access Review
								Wow, no reviews for this game? Stay a while and listen!This one, this is a masterstroke in a careful and delicate balance between the game being a city builder / user interface hell. Yes, it is still early access and you'll probably hit a bug while playing, nothing has crashed the game for me in 30 hours so I'd say this is in the better half of Early Access (though I had not purchased the game sooner so I'm not aware of initial foibles. There is so much to love here: Likable residents, cute formatting and design. The UI is clean, the layout does pop over itself but that is trite in comparison to the data you're shown / what you need. What you need is where you'd expect to find it with a very responsive layout. Basically, you can get in and play without having to dig through where you were or push F1 to research many words to explain a simple concept. Well executed devs.Cheerful would be one word to describe this game. I haven't found a single annoying aspect, and willingly will put many more hours into this game with content that is sure to come.You do not need a wiki to play this either, if you need help you can surely find the answer here or in a wonderful community base posting your question.This game has brought the best aspects together in a very clean voxel format that does away with common issues that has will take away from the experience of the game. The difficulty can be scaled in game through use of items (placing trophies), and you can pause to collect yourself if you're in trouble. I eagerly await content and consistently return to an enjoyable experince each time I load up StoneHearth. It is one of my favorites, and an answer to what I seek in a city building game. Thank you for putting this idea out there to make me realize what I'd been missing in this genre.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is great as a concept.  It's fun, engaging, challenging at times, and downright infuriating.  It's plauged by bugs that have been around since the beginning.  Ask anyone who's played this about unfinished buildings, hearthlings standing around starving for no reason, or crafters with a full crafting queue that are idle for days.  It's maddening.I really want to enjoy this game, and sometimes I very nearly do.  However, I cannot reccomend it in it's current state.  Too many game breaking bugs to be any good.

content:

Early Access Review
								I Just want to bring to light what has been my experience while owning this game... I bought this game before it hit steam, for $30 USD. After it was released on steam, i noticed it was $5 cheaper, when I created a ticket to the Devs, explaining my situation, and asking for some sort of compensation. They reponded back by saying there was a post on their website telling people it would release on steam for cheaper. Thinking to myself that i was an idiot and feeling kind of down, i let my friend know about what had happened, he went on the website and found out that they had actually created that post AFTER the date in which i bought the game, and lied about it. The Devs have yet to repond to any of my numerous emails. I just wanted to let people know what kind of Devs they are getting in bed with. ***Thumbs Up so people can see***

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Cannot reccomend as a core mechanic of the game is completely broken. Building is attrocious. There are 4 or 5 prefabbed template buildings (ugly and boring) you can get away with, but any sort of cuztomized building whatsoever and the game just breaks. What's more... this is the central mechanic of the game for improvement of your tribe and village... you need to craft buildings for your population to grow. The game has charm and potential, but week after week I see zero improvements to this game breaking flaw. Please fix buildings and I will change my review and start reccomending (and even playing) your game.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Its a buggy mess. Not saying that it wont become better, but at this point and time Stonehearths biggest appeal for me, the building, doesnt work well. Its hard to build what you want. Its more work to acctually get something to build than it is acctually designing something. Also the performance is sub par. I often have to reload to get a game to run decently. I would like to comment on what the later stages of the game are like but all my games have bugged out impeading my process and halting my progession. At the moment dont buy, but if you see this in a few months check it out. I have no doubt that this game will become something amazing, all the deves seem very passionate about the project and i have the best of hope for it.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Very fun and addictive! Alouth i feel i've brought this a few years ago and it ended up going abandonware and resurfacing here, so i brought it again and almost every mechanic is the same just totally different textures and a way more simple world generator. From what i can see already devs are getting sloppy and the building system is currently bugged. once i tried to use to dev tools to fix stuff, things would really break lol as you would expect so im going to give it a month or so and try it again and hope for a better experience. The game itself is very fun, extremely cute and ridiculously unforgiving!!! The ui overlays are very nice and easy to navigate. Units are very responsive to commands although i did feel a little clustered at some points latter on. Being able to move individual workers would be nice to control them when there being attacked or walking into a pack of wolves, saves me calling everyone back to safety because of 1 idiot who wanted to pet the wolves pup. BUT the biggest let down, The tutorial left me hanging -_-concept 9-10mechanics 7-10 (please fishing) graphics 7-10 textures 5-10 performance 4-10 building 3-10 gameplay 7-10 overall 5-100GL Deving!

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
Early Access Review
								3/5The game is alright. I really enjoyed the 24 hours I played it, and finished it. It was super cute and I found it refreshing. However the game lacks depth. So you go to the game's official forums and talk about it, and any ideas that introduce an idea of depth other than building little houses that after 4 hours all look the same, and harvesting loot and trying to get the max amount of villagers--they are all met with the same retort."Mods."I do not suggest this game to anyone unless they are a modder and want to learn how to program and make this game for the the devs. They don't even have Steam Workshop enabled, yet are relying 100% on mods to keep people interested in the game. It's a fun game, don't get me wrong, but if you buy this game you're buying "Mod Simulator 2017"I hope they change this mentality before leaving Early Access.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Game has taken way too long to make. It's still in early access after years of development, and they haven't even added many of the main features they promised to add. It's very dissapointing honestly, the game has so much potential but they are developing at the pace of a 2 man team even though they've made so much money off of it. I wouldn't reccomend buying it unless you can wait another 4 years to see if they ever finally finish the game. I check back every 5 months or so to see if any new features have been added, but it seems as though they've only worked a week.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's got quite a game-breaking bug where many (basically all) custom buildings will not get completed. They just bug out and your villagers don't work on them anymore. There's no fix for it aside from cheating to instant-finish them.And the bug has been around for awhile. Not really worth playing until this gets fixed. unless you don't want to play for the building aspect. You can just lay out all of your stuff on the floor. But where's the fun in that?Should I not give it a thumbs down because it's still in early access? Of course I should. I'm giving a thumbs down to the early access because it's severly broken. Steam handles beta reviews when games are released, don't worry about it. I'll reconsider when the bug is fixed.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great Game! Fun!Very, very, very, very, very buggy.It is in early access, and they are open about the bugs - but I have to admit, this *could* be everything I've ever wanted in a game. Absoultely a total blast.I have a very beefy computer as I do dev work too. This game uses just under 9gb of RAM on a consistent basis... very impressive, and scary at the same time.Good work Devs! You have a fantastic concept here - one that is well wanted. You mix Warcraft, minecraft, city builder, sandbox, RTS, and Sims into a single package.... And it's incredibly well laid out and easy to understand. Kudos.

								Stonehearth is a great game with a lot of promise. It could be great if it weren't for a few things. One: The building mechanic is great yet is a bit limited to what you can decorate with (this is excusable as its till in alpha). Two: There is a bug with building where your hearthlings stop building a structure halfway through no matter how many materials you have. Three: Some hearthlings refuse to function and stand still and slowly starve to death slowly killing your population. Other then that stonehearth is great yet don't buy it at this stage as it is incredibly frustrating when your village refuses to function and starves to death.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is not a game to buy at this point. The devs make excuses to some very long time game breaking bugs. If you like restarting your game every 10 to 15 minutes to make it work, or losing whole towns because of errors.. then maybe this game is for you. In its current state it is unplayable and all the devs focus on is new content without correcting the game breaking bugs. What good is new content if you can't play the game?Your town people will idle for no reason (stop working).There is pathing issues that will make your town people die of hunger.They will not complete buildings early in the game, this is for the simple designs forget trying to build complex buildings.Restarting the game every 10 to 15 minutes in hopes it corrects the issues ( and most the time it does not).It will use up your ram at high velocity and spam you with error messages (got over 5k a few times on error messages).This is just a few examples of the state of this unplayable game. If they had a report game button I would hit it in a minute.Be warned before dumping money into this game.Steam forums are not important to these devs. I am sick and tired of devs thinking we owe them something and have to use their forums.. because it is easy for them, not the customer..

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								So, I have been playing for 40 hours as shown, included about 4 play through, I really love the concept and art work, but I can not recommnad this game.This game has 2 critical problem and 1 of them is greatly affecting the core of game play, and I believe both problem been exsisting since alpha 17 began or even earlier.The building system is either coded badly or the whole coding design was wrong in the very first place.When I encounter a gaming bug I generally try to assume why it happened and try to work around, but I just dont understand why the hearlthlings would just stop building the already planned stuff so suddenly.When player confirm the build, the building plan would be executed and set as first priority, it is a do until done task.I'm confused becasue the hearthling's AI doesn't seems off at all, they can access even just 1 single block, they know how to switch around between build and collect. It doesnt make sense for them to just stop building.A few possibility would kind of explain but a bit stretch. For example I started my latest 2 buildings together at the same time and put it real close.They eventually stop at 50%. Maybe becasue not enough room? but they build both to about 50% for no problem, I even mannually asked hearthlings to put up stairs to see if it's spacing prolbem, but nope, they went up normally and got down without any hardship and ignore the half way done building. Now only 1 possibility I can think of, hearthlings got confused by getting 2 building order, whitch I cannot explain why if this is actually what happen...Another bug is, hearthlings will not put down stuff when told to. But there's a fix, whitch is when they refuse or ignore the order to put down certain stuff, just go and build a new item. They will start putting stuff down when the new stock come into inventory. I assume this is some sort of data lost whitch the items in the inventory was not visible to the hearthlings.The invaders also got some problem which I just discoverd today.Goblin Kings Dialog show up said that army was arrived, but they did not... and never did after days... It only happen once.I really wanna play more hours but I can't when I cannot build up my town... The whole game is about fighting the invader and build your customized town, 1 of them is 80% broken.I understand this is an early access game, but alpha 17 has been out for 1 whole years, I watch the video for last year and compare with my game there were so little different to be honest. Dev. really need to work harder on both coding and debugging.

content:

Early Access Review
								If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.But for the review's sake, 9/10. The game is great, but pike all games it can be buggy.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								You know those over-ambitious games that you hear about and think they'd be amazing, but then you play them and are immediately dissapointed?  That's this game.I got suckered in by the Kickstarter, and it's been the same glitchy mess for three years.At its core, the game wants to be a city-planning, strategy, completely customizable dream of a game with strong community support.  The problem is that, at the moment, there's very little customization, no strategy, and no real city planning.  Towns rarely last long enough to build more than a handful of homes before glitches break a save.The new features that have been added over the years have been nice, but they'd be nicer if I could actually enjoy them without having to restart because of a game-breaking bug.One of two things will happen.  Either your adorable hearthlings will simply stop doing anything, or some problem will arise when building a structure and nothing will be accomplished as all citizens will get stuck on a ladder or permanently be stuck holding materials or literally lose their head.Some bugs are fixed, but the game hasn't progressed nearly far enough while in development, and now that Riot bought the company, I sincerely doubt anything will come of this game.tl;dr - If the game didn't break so much, it'd be a fun little time waster as it is, but that's a pretty big "if" at this point.

Early Access Review
								I would love to love this game, but it is incomplete, clunky, and boring.  The "voxelated" graphics are a poor and cliche aesthetic choice.  Progression is slow and meaningless.  Building design, though quite intricate, ultimately adds little to the game mechanic and ends up being mostly a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  (You must pre-design buildings rather than construct them block-by-block as in Minecraft or Dwarf Fortress.)Yes, it's an early access title, but the only material change in the game in the last 9 months seems to be breaking save compatibility.  Give these guys 2-3 more years to put out a finished game before you pay anything for it.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								While I haven't yet put in a lot of hours into the game, I will say that what's there is quite fun to play.It's an ideal game for anyone who likes Dwarf Fortress or Towns, as well as anyone who enjoys the whole "minimal input" genre of games. You can designate a plot to build on, then watch your little workers get to work. There's also resource management, combat, farming, and lots of other stuff that you indirectly have control over. Presentation wise, you can see that the creators of this game have put a lot of love into the detail and mechanics of the game. There's leveling up, skill progression, exploitation of resources, and all the fun stuff you'd expect from this genre of game.All in all, a worth it purchase.

								This is a good game. This game takes alot of ideas and throws it into a bowl without any part overpowering the others. It all blends really nice. It is worth it.9.8/10 (Early Acess, it'll be 10 soon enough)

number of helpful: 19 of 44 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								The concept is fantastic, and there's a lot of potential in the game, but...There's far too many issues with its current state. Building custom buildings is near-impossible, the controls are often non-responsive, there's a nasty memory leak (this game should not require +6 gigs of RAM), and that's only the biggest problems. Workers that don't work, ladders and furniture that can't be deconstructed, etc. There's many small things that combine to make the game very hard to enjoy. Putting aside the bugs and building problems, the game is well designed. The progression of your minions is simple but effective, the resource harvesting likewise. My only quibble is that it takes a very long time to do anything with only a 2x speed option. I'd like the ability to go up to 8x at least.Given the strength of the underlying design, I look forward to playing the game more once it's had some bug-fixing done. However, I can only review it based on what it is now, so I cannot recommend this as is.

content:
Posted: February 25
Early Access Review
								I participated in the kickstart and got two copies from it because of my pledge. I played several alpha versions up to A20 and finally quit trying. If you watch the Kickstarter and earlier videos and then you play the game as it is now, it is like water and wine. The original seemed a lot more casual and about building a nice town and eventually castles with aspects of crafting, hunting and so on. However, the game grew in complexity so much that it is now not only too complex to be casual, but it is too complex for the developers to keep it up and follow up on the infinite bugs that it has. This game will never be complete IMHO because the development team forgot their basics and went for a too complex approach to be any good. When you get stuck over and over trying to build a single building, you will notice it won't go far.They should have left all the detail and minimalistic things and gone FIRST to the big game: place buildings, structures, etc... make enemies, little wars, little raids. Get the game WORKING, allow you to make any city or castle you wanted without worring if the door is aligned to the freaking wall or will even work. THEN elaborate the minimalistic things.Clearly, a team with no programming experience. Shame ...

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								So far, after a few of hours of play, I think the game has potential but gives me the feeling that Alpha projects like this shouldn't be "Early Access" or more so paid for. Though I feel good about the developer and hope things update often. Hopefully weekly. If I get updates often and ones that pay off like I'm used to with the Early Access games I'm currently playing, then It should be well worth it.The art and sound all seem pretty good. More so for an Alpha... so much so that it worries me. I won't say anything bad about it... just that it seems like that energy could have been used to make better gameplay. Maybe they had more artistst durring development. I understand they have a plan and all but I'm not sure what they are going for.I'm looking at my red LUA error window, and it's up to 3000+ errors. I can sometimes still play but the window likes to pop back up a lot. I think this already exists sort of, as some kind of building error so I technically would be submitting a duplicate report... so I don't report it. Not even sure which or what of the errors I'm supposed to report.  If I could just push a button and send off a report, that would be fantastic. Alas, I have to navigate to the bug forum and search through a bunch of other existing errors to make sure mine don't already exist as posts. 3000+ of them. This just turns me off and discourages me. I came in with the concept that the game would be test-playable and easy to report problems, but that's not the case. Make it easy to report problems and a lot of that frustration goes away. I'm all for helping debug and I wouldn't have minded paying as much if there was just a little bit more attention to problem reporting detail before the Steam release. Feels bad to have to pay and do grunt work to get bugs worked out. Maybe there is a reward in it somewhere if one plays long enough. If future mod support is superior, that might make me feel better. Speculation and promises don't at this point.The other thing that is boggling and disappointing is that the game has fully featured building elements but no way to demolish the buildings that are made. Seems like someone is missing something important. I don't know if the developers are locked in some strange dimention far away from logical game mechanics... I don't want to sound mean, but this seems very dumb even for Alpha.The other things, like villagers not finishing buildings properly, idling when stuff could be done... I think these are already reported a few times in the "bug tracker". And most of the time I can close/open or just save and re-load and that seems to fix some weirdness and the error spams. So I got a bit of fun out of it but the problems seem to crop up frequently, killing the flow and feeling more like developer work than gameplay. It seems worth giving it time, or rather I want to feel like it's worth giving it time, but if I don't see a good bug fix in a week I'll probably have to ask for a refund. I can't recommend paying for this yet and I feel dissapointed considering what I paid.

content:
Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								The bulk of their updates have been color swaps of already existing items. Two years on and the game still tanks with around 15+ hearthlings. Two years on and the game still doesn't really have a story. Two years on and the maps are still extremely small. Two years on and we've only gotten a handful of classes and new items. Two years on and we've only gotten a few new enemies. Two years on and the game is still plagued with bugs and errors, the same ones in many cases too. Two years on and the building tools still haven't really been improved. See the pattern? The development for this game is as slow as Interstellar Marines.Avoid, this is one of those Early Access games that will likely never be finished and they'll just rip the EA tagging off of it and abandon it. Regretful purchase. Most people I know who have it only put a few hours into this sandbox game and abandoned it. It was a great idea, but unfortunately it's the wrong developers. Play for 3 hours and you'll experience all that the game has to offer, which is pretty much the same as what it offered two years ago.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								As far as potential goes I think this game has quite a bit, and while I would not reccomend the game as it is due to the reasons below, in time it should reach the point of being a worthwhile game for the current cost. Which is another thing..this game right now at most should be 15-20, since its not a game with a lot of content and with some major fatal bugs. Currently most lot of the planned content is no where near being in which makes me question the pricing decision. Right now only 1/3rd of the intended jobs are in.During my five hours of gameplay I consantly ran into UI crashes and system failures, which would result in parts of the UI or game becoming unusable forcing you to reload. Twice now it has nearly crashed my pc to the point I was forced to do a false restart where the computer shuts the program down since you hit the power button but you then cancle the restart when it asks you to close your notepad. The game draws more ram then needed from your system causing sound glitches. Also combat in it can be frustraiting, having to use a badly designed party/designated area targeting system. And a warning, do NOT save when one of your characters is in direct combat, when you load the game takes a while to load the ui and seems to suddenly jump a minute or so ahead in combat, often instanly killing any non guard character without giving you the chance to react.

number of helpful: 1 of 12 people (8%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay, this is fun. Heavily racist, but very fun with a mod. :-/ Danger zone maybe? Nah, heres how it is:It's a Banished/Minecraft clone essentially with the diffrence that exploring is limited to a smallish area and it's purely a town ownership and creation type game gathering resources etc with ikkle people/hearthlings, but it's enough to keep you hooked for endless hours once you realise that you can actually create your own building designs from literally the ground up. Forget the standard builds you can just select and place in the world for the Hearthlings to work for you, honestly, I recommend creating your own 10>20 person dining hall with a sleeping area on a second floor for the same amount in the beginning of this, then create walls etc.There are still some bugs that need ironing out, but for the price at the moment, it's a very enjoyable game and the devs are working hard on this continuously.Now, if you havent already fallen asleep reading this boring review I will get to the racism part...........We all like Multiculturism to a level where certain religions are NOT concerned, but if you choose "The Ascendancy" and want to have your town based on European based medievel type era castles etc you have to go through the randomise option a hundred times before you can get a full set of ginger, brown or black haired WHITE Hearthlings and 9/10 times they will all have rubbish stats, so you are forced to relive history as some kind of reinvention where all other nationalities were magically "transported" in like a bad star trek episode, where in the early year 1000's there were all colours and nationalities in old blighty and Europe. Yes I know, it's fiction with regard to stone monsters etc, but the castle walls and weapons etc are based on historical European designs.Not racist on my behalf, I want to recreate my tribe as per my historical descendancy!Now, however and the MAIN point here.........if you choose 'Rayyas Children' to play on either the Forest or Desert biomes and decide to import your white Hearthlings through that randomise button, you will spend eternity clicking and clicking to have a WIlliam Wallace white, brown haired hardcore dude as a hearthling because you can only play that sect as people with coloured skin! See where I am going here? ;-)Luckily there is a non dev mod available in the Steam store I eventually found, but really? You shouldnt have to use a mod to recreate a castle and medieval atmosphere! This is a game for the paying customer after all and everyone is scared of pointing this fact out due to being branded racist against colour of skin. This is racist against whites in my opinion!All that being said, with the mod it's a fantastic little gem this and worth under 20 quid in my opinion. A lot of work to be done ESPECIALLY with the system resource it requires even though its a tad basic (Needs optimisation in the code), but it's already worth that asking tag at the moment.Great work you racist bunch of devs, but mods shouldnt be needed! :-D
