I think there are different between adding addition features and debug VS problem of game mechanic and functionality. Browsing through the developer website and forum, there is no mention about putting this feature in the game at any stage of development. Probably the game engine is at fault and building modification is not possible. Hope the developer or those with deep insight with this game can help answer my question. For now, I do not recommend this game due to the problem I mentioned.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Update: 8-3-2015Current version is even more unstable than before. It seems that the development team is going backwards each time they add a new feature.-Multi-story housing construction nearly impossible.-Roof construction causes severe Lua errors.-Almost every game I've started becomes unplayable after a few hours of gameplay.Avoid this title at the moment. I'd hardly call it Alpha.Although I would normally recomend this game, I just can't justify recomending it for now. The idea is there, and the foundation of the game is more or less built, but it seems that the developer doesn't know what they want to do.-Very little content. The addition of goblin packs and wolves have extended gameplay somewhat, but at best it is a bare minimum for your average game.-The content in game is very repetitive.-Extremely slow development schedule. It seems to me the developers are working on this either part time, or are severely short staffed. It can take months for systems to be completed, and usually once implemented are extremely buggy.-Extremely buggy. Be prepared for constant crashes and damaged saves. I'm not certain with version 10+, but every new version requires a whole new game.-Game is not what was advertised and has switched focus/goals. What originally was intended as a city/realm management game, has turned into a village micromanagement game.-Game has lost focus in that it wants a combat RTS element, but still relies on its old villager micromanagement foundation.It's a good idea and so far a solid foundation for what could be a great game in a few years (think Kerbal Space Program). I strongly recommend against purchasing at the moment or at full price. I would wait until it is either on sale, or it is much further along.

number of helpful: 37 of 129 people (29%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Almost all of the reviews so far are from people who have played the pre-Steam Early Access version a ton (I mean it was on Steam, just not publicly available) and I get why the like it, because it is a good game for what it is, but I'm going to not recommend it, not yet, because of what it claims to be, what the Kickstarter explained it to be, and what it is now. TL:DR it is nothing like the Kickstarter pitched it would be, which might be just fine, but it isn't what I backed. One of the first tags you will see for Stonehearth says city builder and when you see that tag do you think of something like Gnomoria or Towns? Probably not. Those are more like town or village builders with some micromanagement and customization of each individual villager, which is great because you you start with maybe half a dozen and build up from there, but even if you end up with 20 villagers (which is a lot for this game) would you say that is a city? You might argue that I'm just talking semantics and being trivial, but let me quote what the Stonehearth Kickstarter summarized the game to be, "A sandbox strategy game with town building, crafting, and epic battles!" It certainly does not have town building and crafting at the moment, but a strategy game it is not. At the moment the game is very much like Gnomoria, Timber & Stone or Towns. You start with a few villagers, build a few structures, place stockpiles, farm, mine and craft things while also defending from random attacks from enemies. I've seen the game grow into something that has some level of polish to it and visually looks pretty good, but never has the game seemed like it could technically manage anything like an actual city. Once again, my focus is that this is meant to be a city sim with light micromanagment for people and focused more on the large picture, not the small. Like, the original explanation for multiplayer was, "Share a living world with your friends and family! Build sprawling empires of towns, cities and castles, and unite in mutual defense against the towering threat of ancient titans." There was this huge focus on building cities, castles and fighting off these big factions and threats, as a city with some level of strategy and more like a city sim mixed with a game like Dwarf Fortress. This isn't that and it has going in a direction that makes me think it will never be anything like that. It will certainly be a good or great Dwarf Fortress, Towns, Gnomoria, style of game at some point and that is fantastic, so if you want another one of those then good, but if you were an early backer like me who wanted something with strategy and a larger scale then I think you will be vastly disappointed. I was drawn in by early screenshots of cities with over a dozen structures, a castle in the background, large statues and tons of moving citizens going about their work, and that's just not going to happen. Which is fine, but I don't want anyone else to think it is that game either.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I like this game, but there just isn't much gameplay right now in the game. You'll chop down some trees, farm a bit, build some buildings for sleeping and then the game mostly dies off. They've just started integrating a "goblin campaign" wherein your settlement is supposed to be attacked by increasingly dangerous hordes of goblins, but I just sort of killed them all. The game developers need to focus on how they are going to challenge the player within their simulation. Right now, that focus just isn't there. Instead, they're doing things like advanced programming to make water flow realistically, but water has precisely zero significance for gameplay. This, I believe, exemplifies why I'm concerned not just for the state of the current game, but future development as well. If the game eventually reaches a point where gameplay is enduring and well-thought out, I will gladly remove/rewrite this review.

								So far so good I'd say. It's pretty decent for the price I'd say... If they would lower the price a little further I'd give this game 5 stars. content:

Early Access Review
								Its a fun little game. Not much going on now, you build up a city and then eventually you get it to where you want it and restart, or monsters come in and kill all your people and you get annoyed and restart. It's a bit pricy at $25 which is a lot to ask for from a game "in the works" but I think the price tag is due more to the donors backing up the game than people actually paying for content. Either way this game is making good progress and honestly I am happy to pay full price to support this game and its development team. Pro: Game making good progress in developmentKeeps the public up to dateYou can spend hours and hours doing nothing but building the perfect cityHas the basics and some of the more advanced features already includedCons:Pretty repetative after a whileOnce your town is constructed theres nothing really left to doA few bugs (To be expected from Early Access)Price v content isnt the greatestOverall Opinion:If you want to support a game and its Development team, this is a good investment. There is no keeping people in the dark here, this is Early Access but you know where the game is going. The game is constantly being updated to include bigger and better things but currently if your going for content your overpaying. The game is a big time killer though so if your going for hours of gameplay this is the game for you.

								   Although it is still buggy in its early stages, this game has a certain potential that few games seem to achieve. Such games include StarBound, Dirty Bomb, and of course, this game. You should get it now to experience the growth of the game as it develops.   This game is tons of fun and really in-depth. All they need to fix is the inevidable bugs, and this game would be one of the greats. I reccomend this to anyone and everyone looking to create something.   Another neat feature that some games fail to achieve is having your structures that you build have a purpose, and they do. You can have a dining hall, sleeping quaters, a workshop building for your hearthlings, and more. This game greatly influences meaning in your buildings. I am willing to bet you will love this game!                                                                                                                                                  -9/10

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
Early Access Review
Potential and CharmI purchased prior to early access, Fall 2014. If the videos appeal to you, and you are willing to put up with bugs then I feel comfortable recommending this game now. As of 11/2015 the primary issues I have with the game are bugs. Many are fixed weekly, but I still can't quite build what I want or I have to game the AI to keep whem working.  If the developers deliver on everything it should be considerably better.This game has a lot of potential, and I respect the developers for being very open with the community. They communicate through their blog weekly, and often push a non-stable build weekly or every other week. This game has not been abandoned like some other early access titles. Pros:Responsive Dev TeamOpen for ModsGreat visual styleFun personality in the writing Extensive replayability (no two games the same)Building interface has great potentialCons: Buggy... it's alphaLong dev cycleMany features that give the game legs are not in yet (MP,Co-Op, more factions)I purchased this because I wanted to support the developers, and I'm glad to see they are still going strong. This little game has a lot of charm, and potential. As it stands right now I check the game once a month or so just to see all the new stuff they've put in. I hit a few show-stopping bugs on my town and leave it for another month. Looking forward to full release.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is so addicting i cant come off it i play this more than any other game i have.First time Experienceat first i had no idea what to do (I know there is guides but im going simply from the game itself) it doesnt really explain what you do. Then i when i figured out what to do i felt quite stupid (Personally).At first i was just gathering resources but wasnt sure what to do, but then realised you have to set you people jobs, after that i started expanding, defend my self from goblins, then built a wall round my town and have just expanded on.Although it can be quite annoying to play due to the bugs and what have you it is only and Alpha so dont expect bug free.ProblemsNow yes it is only and alpha im not hating on it i understand but im only sharing a few bugs people should know about.Buildings with more than floorThis can be a pain as they will get stuck on the inside of the top floor if your not planning on using the second floor.UIIts written in C++ json files, similar to Minecraft. so yeah can expect the kind of bugs from it, if your changing a Person job and your looking at the list it can crash and stop you from setting Jobs, saving, crafting, and other things that require the UI to pop up a menu.(To fix this just press F5 to reset the UI)Lagyou wont notice this till you have explored your area a bit and have at least 20 people in your town. When this happens prepare for all the Bugs. The UI system comepletely fails and stutters the game due to the all the for loops and the while scripts (Basically 24 FPS is coming your way).(I have found a way to sort of delay the lag, when its happens Reset the UI by Press F5. this resets all the Loop Scripts causeing it to refresh all the code thats waiting or looping in the game it wont cause any harm that i know i do it and i have no problems)ConclusionYes there are problems but its an alpha and this game has insane potential im sticking around for the updates and playing it daily you ignore the bugs and just get on with it. i still recommened getting this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								For being a early access game, I'm pleasantly pleased.  Other games I have purchased in early-access were a disaster; unresponsive devs, focus on pay-elements #microtransactions, while the game is more-or-less unplayable.  While this game isn't free of bugs, the overall game play mechanics are here and there is easily 10-20 hours worth of quality game-play.I've been looking for a game of this type for sometime.  Minecraft is too much like 'Toil-craft' and this game gives a lot of thought to how to get the great parts of minecraft (city building, resource management, warfare, politics) but multiplayer hasn't been executed yet.  My personal hopes is that they make a persistent world for multiplayer where multiple player-controlled towns can be built and trade established between them. If they can knock multiplayer our of the park, I imagine a large group of people will put down toil-craft for Stonehearth (where you're NPCs do the toiling and leave you to planning / management). Worth a look!

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								When I first picked up this game I thought I wouldn't like it, but I was completely wrong.Despite having a long way to go, this game shows some very unique concepts of which I haven't come across before.You play as a band of settlers trying to make a home for theirselves in the wilderness. If you want your town to grow you need to increase food, morale, and wealth. There are a few features that need refining, like for example, if you want a farmer you will need a carpenter to make a farmers hoe, but unless you bought a carpenters saw at the start of the game, your screwed.All in all a brilliant game, and the feature I love the best is the fact you can design your own houses! I love city builders so for me this is a dream come true, but this also may need refining

								Early Access should always be about wanting to be a part of the game's development. To share the stories and developments, the good times and the bad. They are evidence that some of the best games come from the smallest teams.The game is fun, isn't that enough? If you enjoy chilled out, creative games then you'll enjoy this. Build your own village and make it your own. Plus, it's easy to mod!

content:

Early Access Review
								I love this game. It allows You to build up a kingdom and fight off monsters as well as promoting people (hearthlings) to several jobs such as a carpenter, farmer and blacksmith.You can design buildings that are then created by the hearthlings that you can then use for houses. This is the best simulation game I have played so far.Whilst there are still some bugs and the game can be annoying when your saves bacome incompatible, it is an amazing game hence why I recommend it.It is a nice and stress free game (most of the time) that has been developed to be a sucess.This game is also frequently updated therefore fixing bugs and adding in new content making the game more fun and interesting

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hi there, I am playing Stonehearth since Alpha 5 or 6 I think - not regularly, but whenever a new alpha version comes out (which is roughly every 1-2 moneths).As all the posters before me already said, it has elements of a city builder, of RPG and visually connects to titles like Minecraft, Timber and Stone etc.What I like about this game is the cuddliness of the Hearthlings, which sets a very light tone. When my children saw the first fox to scratch its ears, I had to let the camera on the critter for at least ten minutes. Music is great, day and night cycle works fine, even monsters are cuddly in a way.If you are a hardcore strategist, you will probably miss depth in the skill tree and challenging campaigns to crush your adversaries, but if you love building, designing and a little melee fight every now and then, give it a try.Sure, there are a few bugs in the game, but hey, thats alpha, and usually they are fixed quite fast. Devs communicate a lot with the community via the forum, and each tuesday and thursday, they even stream their work, so you can look over their shoulders.I'm glad the game is in my collection - still a demo version would be nice to allow people to enjoy the ambience and understand what I mean.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Oh i love this game. It's so much fun but really developers, 25$ for an early access game? For the content at the moment i think either 15-20 would've been better. But other than the cost, bugs and occasional crashes (of course the game is still being made), and lack of content (again still being made) it's fun. I would not recommend buying it now unless it's on sale because it just doesent have enough late game content. My town survived more then a month and i already had an almost infinite supply of food and steel armor and weapons for my three soldiers. The game's just a little too easy at the moment. So in all, i think it's a good game 8/10. Really fun early game with tons of stuff to do, but once you hit about a month in game there's nothing left for your people to do. But remember it's an early access game so i'm doing this review with a little slack.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even in the early stages, I'm finding Stonehearth to be incredibly addictive. Watching your Hearthlings build and thrive as you direct their actions is endearing. Though the characters are adorable, watching them slaughter adorable Goblins is great.Still, there are a few things that could be improved in this game. Keeping in mind that, as an Early Access title at this stage, there are improvements and features yet to come anyway. Regardless, here are a few things that I feel could be worked on:- The 'Build a Custom House' feature is in dire need of a more reliable 'Delete' tool. If the changes I wanted to make to an existing blueprint requires replacing something that has already been placed, I'm out of luck. I'd just have to tell my Hearthlings to undeploy an object and deploy the one I actually want there. (Like an improved bed.)- I would like to be able to either see a queue of actions and be able to to change the priority or simply have a click-and-drag tool to call the Hearthlings to a certain area to work on it right at that moment. I have seen far too many crops wither and die because they become neglected by my farmers. Not to mention, the buildings that become abandoned in the middle of construction because my workers suddenly feel that everyone mining at once is more important than finishing another wooden dining hall.- Please bring back the Name Randomizer for towns. I honestly liked seeing the sort of names built into the game and I'm horrendous with naming settlements in the first place.

								As good as you'd imagine!Fun sandbox with defined purpose to expand. It isn't exactly as easy as one would think, which makes it enjoyably challenging. Hopefully as the updates come more features/objectives will be introduced to keep the replay value high; Goblin villages? Other human villages to compete with? Multiplayer PvP??? Only time will tell.It's not without bugs as there are plenty which include game crashes, engine crashes, ui crashes and the irritating building glitches. It's all worth the patience though with the cool and active devs and community that aspire to make the game as good as it should become. content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								In short, don't get this... Yet. The main gamebreaking bug for me was that my class-based 'Hearthlings' did not do their tasks, instead being idle or collecting random stuff lying on the ground, followed by more idling. There are a small number of other core bugs at the moment, and it saddens me that I have to refund a game that has so much potential. If you're interested, follow this game, as the positive comments bestowed upon the devs suggest this will be getting fixes and content.Here's hoping I can change this review to positive in a few months' time.EDIT 14/08/2015Okay, so the things that 'break' the game are easily fixed: Craftsmen who don't work don't have the resources (although the UI as of yet does not tell you that, so your workers simply don't do the job). A workaround is to press 'i' to open your inventory and make sure you have what you need. The same goes for a building's requirements.And so, with that, I'm putting this up to a recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is an amazing game and the developers at Radiant Entertainment do an excellent job of listening and responding to the player base as they move foward with Stonehearth, keeping players updated and giving them a say in mechanics and additions. That being said, Stonehearth is an EARLY ACCESS game, it is by no means complete. The essential game mechanics are in place, and the game is a ton of funas is, with the promise of adding content for a long time coming. The finished product will be an incredible game about sprawling civilizations and gameplay suited to your playstyle. As is, the gameplay is fun, and inviting, with a low learning curve and instant reward as your Hearthlings run around your small village, doing various tasks like farming, mining, building, trapping, masonary, carpentry... you get the idea. The goblin campaign is developing beautifully and the zombies are great combat fodder to boot. Bug will appear from time to time, but are rarely more than cosmetic such as a scaffolding not disappearing. This is a great agme, I enjoy the frequent uodates and new content as it trends more and more to a game I can pick up and play for hours.BUY IT NOW!!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a town building micromanager. If you like the idea of building a town from the ground up, harvesting resources, protecting your community, upgrading your village and leveling villagers to unlock more potential... this game is for youThis game... This isn't your usual early access. These devs are serious about bringing a quality game to the market. They don't want to take your money and run, they want to make a work of art for people to enjoy. Even in it's current state(no idea how many more updates are to come) it has gripped me - like no games seem to do anymore. I have played around 10 hours over the past two days and I'm pushing the limits of what is left to do, besides expand more. I will come back after more updates because at the moment I don't want to ruin the fun. It is more of a casual game at the moment, where you would play here and there. Not in 5 hour runs like I have done. I highly recommened buying and supporting the devs, it's seriously worth it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ooof. First off I'd like to say I play a lot of early access games so I know to expect bugs and issues. You'll need that mind set for Stonehearth. For time's sake I'll just say there are ALOT of bugs still, some rather serious. There is almost zero in game help on how to do even the most basic game functions, thats ok it is a alpha stage game after all, but here's the next issue that finally made me have to turn the game off and write this review. When you look online how to do the super basic ABCs its old outdated infomation that no longer has any bearing with the current game. Assuming very few readers made it through all that complaining I'd like to end the review on this note, its still pretty fun (when you aren't pulling your hair out) and while the developers aren't pumping out updates like crazy they do seem to be plugging away at steadly which is more than you can say about a lot of early access.P.S. Bottem line is Stonehearth has a ton of potential and I'm glad I could support the developers. I just hope they keep working hard to make the game more stable to play.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hi there, I am playing Stonehearth since Alpha 5 or 6 I think - not regularly, but whenever a new alpha version comes out (which is roughly every 1-2 moneths).As all the posters before me already said, it has elements of a city builder, of RPG and visually connects to titles like Minecraft, Timber and Stone etc.What I like about this game is the cuddliness of the Hearthlings, which sets a very light tone. When my children saw the first fox to scratch its ears, I had to let the camera on the critter for at least ten minutes. Music is great, day and night cycle works fine, even monsters are cuddly in a way.If you are a hardcore strategist, you will probably miss depth in the skill tree and challenging campaigns to crush your adversaries, but if you love building, designing and a little melee fight every now and then, give it a try.Sure, there are a few bugs in the game, but hey, thats alpha, and usually they are fixed quite fast. Devs communicate a lot with the community via the forum, and each tuesday and thursday, they even stream their work, so you can look over their shoulders.I'm glad the game is in my collection - still a demo version would be nice to allow people to enjoy the ambience and understand what I mean.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
Alpha 10.5: Pros and ConsPros-Fun and addicting gameplay-Charming voxel graphics-Decent soundtrack/audio (although a bit repetitive at times)-Excellent dev team and community-Surprisingly good mod supportCons-Extremely buggy-Quite feature lacking-Crummy performance at times (crashes, memory leaks, low fps)-Unoptimized for a lot of PCs-Hefty price tag for an early access gameAll in all, it's a great game with lots of potential.  Sure, the constant occasional bugs and lack of features is a bit annoying, but it's to be expected with an alpha game.  Definitely a game to keep your eye on - I'd recommend buying it if you've got $25 to spare, but otherwise you might want to wait until the price goes down and the game itself is more polished.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								* I AM WELL AWARE OF THIS BEING EARLY ACCESS*      This game has a very interesting idea. I was so excited to get it, and build a city that flourished with Hearthlings I believe they're called. Right away I had issues starting up the game, and had to fix them with stuff that I usually don't do. Changing the compatability to see which one launches correctly. x64 bit doesn't work for me, and I'm pretty sure not for anyone else. Once I was able to launch the game I actually enjoyed the features I was getting to see and play with. I began to have a crashing issue. I still have this issue, and I turned my settings down, and it helped a little bit but it randomly crashes currently. The 3.5 hours I have on this game there's about a total of 45 minutes of solid gameplay. The other is just me starting it up and then figuring my second issue which is saving my game. I don't mind having the game crash as long as I can save before (they have an auto-save ability which is nice) and be able to relaunch and continue slowly but surely. This is the only game so far where I've had an issue that hasn't been resolved with trying every solution on the forums. Onward to the pros and cons (as much as I could gather). *THIS WILL CHANGE OVER THE COURSE OF DEVELOPMENT*Pros: -Ability to create/maintain a city -Having different classes of people you can promote your Hearthlings to-Being able to create custom buildings with a purpose of your choosing-Having the option to build into a mountain as a cave type way of living-Ability to trade with people who come through your town-Fighting mechanics with enemies-Auto Save ability Cons:-Crashes every 10 minutes or so (UPDATED)-Save does not work at all ( Pointless to play really ) (UPDATED)-Poorly optimized ( I don't a terrible PC but I am sure it can handle this game ) -Poor response time from anyone on the forums, both Steam and their forums ( Still haven't heard anything yet; It's been 4 days ) (UPDATED)     So all in the end I do NOT recommend this game, but this will hopefully change soon enough. I will edit the review accordingly. That's if I can get the help I need. As of 8/31/2015 the game was a waste of $24.99. The reason it's not reccomended is because I personally can't play it.EDIT (September 1st): After recieving help for my issues which they were nice about. I played the game a bit more. The game needs to ran in windowed mode to not crash and save properly. The game is actually good. As I figured before, but now I have seen it first hand. I do recommend the game. They are coming out with more features soon enough. For the money I think it's worth it when it's playable.

Early Access Review
								Its a fun little game. Not much going on now, you build up a city and then eventually you get it to where you want it and restart, or monsters come in and kill all your people and you get annoyed and restart. It's a bit pricy at $25 which is a lot to ask for from a game "in the works" but I think the price tag is due more to the donors backing up the game than people actually paying for content. Either way this game is making good progress and honestly I am happy to pay full price to support this game and its development team. Pro: Game making good progress in developmentKeeps the public up to dateYou can spend hours and hours doing nothing but building the perfect cityHas the basics and some of the more advanced features already includedCons:Pretty repetative after a whileOnce your town is constructed theres nothing really left to doA few bugs (To be expected from Early Access)Price v content isnt the greatestOverall Opinion:If you want to support a game and its Development team, this is a good investment. There is no keeping people in the dark here, this is Early Access but you know where the game is going. The game is constantly being updated to include bigger and better things but currently if your going for content your overpaying. The game is a big time killer though so if your going for hours of gameplay this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								In short, don't get this... Yet. The main gamebreaking bug for me was that my class-based 'Hearthlings' did not do their tasks, instead being idle or collecting random stuff lying on the ground, followed by more idling. There are a small number of other core bugs at the moment, and it saddens me that I have to refund a game that has so much potential. If you're interested, follow this game, as the positive comments bestowed upon the devs suggest this will be getting fixes and content.Here's hoping I can change this review to positive in a few months' time.EDIT 14/08/2015Okay, so the things that 'break' the game are easily fixed: Craftsmen who don't work don't have the resources (although the UI as of yet does not tell you that, so your workers simply don't do the job). A workaround is to press 'i' to open your inventory and make sure you have what you need. The same goes for a building's requirements.And so, with that, I'm putting this up to a recommended.

Early Access Review
								As a kickstarter backer, I've seen this game grow from a game where all you could do was watch your "Hearthlings" eat berries, to a game where you can grow your population, build magnificant structures (kind of :P), dig mighty caverns, and slowly build up your tiny 7 man town into a flourishing city. With things like multiplayer, new crafting classes, archers, town pets, mac and linux support, and many, many, many more good things coming, I see nothing but greatness for this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Update 10/10/15 -  The game is really coming along and doing so a decent pace.  I actually think one of the coolest things for me is watching the entire game develop.  You don't log on for a few weeks and now you have a new class to try.  New enemies pop up.  I've definitely enjoyed this game already, despite some of the bugs.  Even in alpha, this game has a lot of positives to it.  You can see where they're going with the job system, and they make your units mattering, which is very different then some similar games I've played.  To give an example, you can't switch a unit to a shepard until it has reached lv. 3 as a trapper for the unit.  That makes things like goblin attacks actually matter, because your lone trapper in the woods will die.  It's little ideas and notions like this that make the game good.As some people have mentioned, the content isn't all the way there, with a large amount of the jobs missing, and several bugs that can be annoying. (units not finishing a house, i.e. laying the groundwork but not actually completing it.)Overall though I really enjoy the game so far and I would definitely recommend picking it up.  It's definitely shaping up to be a successful title.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm in love with this game. Don't get me wrong, it's not fully optimized, has some glitches, and is nowhere near complete.... but the gameplay is right up my alley! I love the sandbox feeling but with still having some structure involved. I love that you have full control over city/town building but that the inhabitants actually physically carry out your orders and you don't control them directly! I love the cute art style and the class system, it's all great.My only beefs are some of the annoying UI and citizen pathing/building idling glitches but I just save often and freely use the console commands to delete problem objects. ALSO, this game is far from complete so don't expect to get anywhere close to 100 hours of novel gameplay out of it... that isn't to say that if designing custom buildings/towns are your thing that you couldn't put 1000 hours into it though. The devs do an update every Tuesday on their website so progress is being made towards expanding the game. It's awesome to come in now as it's slowly growing as opposed to all the disappointed Kickstarter campaign people who expected a completed game already.... but I'm not complaining.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Overall Stonehearth is a good game with HUGE potential. First and most importantly, as of January 2016 this is still an EARLY ACCESS GAME.  If you want a complete game with all the bells and whistles then this is NOT for you. If, however, you don't mind playing a game while it's in development then you will benefit from playing Stonehearth.The game is playable but with it's not without issues. That's what the Alpha players are for; they find an issue, report it to the website and the developers get to working. (unless it's DayZ lol)Secondly, there will be updates!!! The more people to get involved the more WE get to influence the final outcome! To actually have some say in the development of a game is most excellent.So with that being said, here is a list of pros and cons, and these are PURELY my opinion.PROS:Stated before, the game has huge potentialEven in early access it is still very enjoyable, it has an adventure mode as well as a leisure mode.It allows you to actively manage and maintain villagers and their actions WITHOUT having to micromanage.The graphics and character types are reminiscent of Bomberman (Nostolgia effect if you like that kind of thing).Overall a good way to enjoy some downtime.Time control that allows you to pause, resume or speed up gameplay.CONS:Sometimes the villagers are OFP (Own F***king Program) and don't respond to what you tell them. Im not trying to raise a Tomogachi with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ attitude, you know.The layout for menus seems to be counter-intuitive until you get the hang of them, once you go through the ringer you learn where the items/options are. Sometimes it feels like a "Where's Waldo" search when trying to close out a window.The Goblins... THE F**KING GOBLINS!!!! Their fingers are stickier than my keyboard. They seem to have an invincible leader that will absolutely annihilate your villagers. (Perhaps this is a good thing though).As the game progresses, depending on your equipment (IRL folks) the game could get some lag going on.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummarizationThe game is still in alpha, so of course you will find an idiot who is quick to review and say "Meeehhhhhh, the game isn't complete, it has bugs and i want my allowance back". These people are either dense, ignorant or just didn't read the product before purchasing, OF COURSE AN ALPHA GAME IS INCOMPLETE. The more people who purchase, the more input and the more the CUSTOMERS get to influence the final product. I can think of several things that I want added and have read many other great suggestions as well. While the game has it's problems, these problems are not, by any means, fatal. Get involved or not. I do not feel like I wasted my money, and this is maybe the second game I actually took the time to review, so thats gotta say something.Overall I RECOOOOOMENDsorry bout that, sticky keyboard...

content:

Early Access Review
								This, is the game I truly looking for my entire lifeABOUT THE GAME AND ENGINE:this game, is a mix from minecraft x stronghold crusaders, my both favorite game. they have "collecting resource" that i like, and the most important thing, hearthling, i love to see my hearthling running everywhere, working, fighting, mining, crafting, etc., the AI is surprisingly smart, although sometimes they got stuck on something and i need to remove the furniture so he/she can back to work, also some bugs made their head misplaced, moving while sleeping, sleep standing, etc., it's hillarious tho XDABOUT THE GAMEPLAY:although I just played about 5 hours in steam record, actually I already played 48 hours. So you asking where did the 43 hours go? mostly because of bugs, all my saved village is gone, or after 3 hours of playing got some bugs that force quit your game before even saved, or sometimes the auto save didn't work, you guess what the cause...first few hours I played this game is only to figure out how things work, it would be nice if they added some tutorial, but the only tutorial they add is just simply how to move your camera and thats it. after I figured out how things work, I starting to build my own village, some were lost because of bugs, and it's really frustating. after building village, it's time to create my very own structure, because they just give a few model for house such as dinning hall and sleeping quarter. they said if hearthling move faster on road, so I created some, and and don't see any diffrent, but still worth it because now my village looks prettier.ABOUT GRAPHIC:I have the minimum requirement for this game, windows 7 32 bit, intel core i3, intel HD graphics 3000, 2GB memory, and still laggy. it would be nice if they add some graphic settings, so I can set it at "extreme low quality". I am into the game quality, not the graphic quality. mostly any game creator failed to understand this, and they failed to get more player to his game, only because quality problem. there is so many game that i liked to play, but got limited by graphic, this game is almost became one of it if they set the quality any more higherSo, after all my writing, now it's time for score, and the score is...........7/10, pretty nice for an early access gamealthough there's still so much bugs, this game still worth it, keep it up and i will give higher rating

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
Alpha 10.5: Pros and ConsPros-Fun and addicting gameplay-Charming voxel graphics-Decent soundtrack/audio (although a bit repetitive at times)-Excellent dev team and community-Surprisingly good mod supportCons-Extremely buggy-Quite feature lacking-Crummy performance at times (crashes, memory leaks, low fps)-Unoptimized for a lot of PCs-Hefty price tag for an early access gameAll in all, it's a great game with lots of potential.  Sure, the constant occasional bugs and lack of features is a bit annoying, but it's to be expected with an alpha game.  Definitely a game to keep your eye on - I'd recommend buying it if you've got $25 to spare, but otherwise you might want to wait until the price goes down and the game itself is more polished.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Well, I bought this game as a Christmas Present for myself.  I saw the trailer and thought it looked amazing, so so I picked it up.  I'm glad I did.As of now, Jan 21st 2016, Stonehearth is in an alpha state.  This means that features are not yet implemetned and the game is bare bones.  That said, it manages to have all the implemented features work well.  There is plenty of annoying things that happen, but the core gameplay is solid.  The bugs and glitches were relatively minor and did not destroy my experience.The developers for this game seem amazing, and they have weekly blog posts detailing the new content they developed.  They are in touch with the community and support the game, as opposed to many early access developers.  This is a great thing.  The art style of the game is fantastic, and the music is delightful.  The theme that plays when you turn on the game is great.This is the lightweight version of Dwarf Fortress that I have been waiting for.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm only recommending this game because I'm a big fan of Dwarf Fortress and DF clones.  Stonehearth is a simplistic take on DF and Gnomoria.  I've yearned for an animated version of DF and I found Stonehearth so I had to try it.  So far, I'm impressed.The game starts by selecting your tribe, (only two for now) and then select your location (either a forest or desert, again...for now).  Your starting tribe affects your beginning workshop. (Wood or clay).Game appears to be VERY early release.  Too early for my likes, but it's addicting.  What I do like is to watch your little workers go to work, building scaffolding to build a building, chomping away at mining or defending your little outpost from the baddies.What I don't like is it's too easy.  The enemy AI is kinda wonders around your town until they decide to strike.  It seems when they spawn, they have a specific town member in mind to attack, then go for the target.  During my latest play through, I only lost one tribe member.  Only because he/she just cowered in fear as the armed goblin was slashing away.  Excellent defense if I must say so...fetal position and hope you get saved.  Overall, I'm not too impressed with the combat right now.I do like the experience aspect for your tribe members.  Example, when you finally unlock the blacksmith, he/she has to gain experience before they can make a better weapon or armor.  Same goes for most other work shop members.  I don't like the chain of jobs.  For example a trapper has to level up before he is eligible for a shepherd.  That doesn't make sense to me.  But that part of the game is not nearly finished, as many "?" fill the chain of jobs in the job screen.  I'm excited for this game and it's addicting to some extent.My biggest concern about the game?  Updates are slow.  Very, very slow.  I'm hoping development doesn't stop on this game.  (I'm looking at you "Towns").

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I wanted this game since I saw a Youtuber called 'The Innkeeper' play it. He did a great series and I'm grateful now that I have the game. I only have a few issues though.For example I play this game on a laptop that runs quite slow and because it is difficult for me to customize and create my own buildings I use the templates. Unfortuntly there are only four to choose from which means that my town doesn't look very different since I have to use the same buildings. If there were a few more templates to choose from I'd be much happier.Also I think a good idea for the game to make it more realistic is to have children in the game. Like if your hearthlings could start families. I think that this would be good because I often look at the journal and a lot of the time it says that the Heartlings are enjoying their time here with friends and family. However there is no family connections.I think it would just be cute if your Hearthlings had personalities and could start their own families. It would also be a challenege in its own because obviously one of the parents would have to look after the child. If your Hearthlings could get married as well because as they get older and pass away their family carries on and you can get a real emotional feeling to your town knowing that they aren't just expanding with buildings or crafters but as like little indivisuals in your computer. It would also mean another job avaliable like a priest. He could marry the Hearthlings who want to be married. It would also mean that the Blacksmith could create rings, not only to sell but for personal use in the town.However when it comes to kids I don't mean that one day there is just a child there and you get a little notification informing you that there is one. I think that your Hearthling could get pregnant. Of course keeping the game PG so you dont see any of the nasty but it also makes it harder as well, especially since if you've just started and there is already a married couple with a pregnant woman, she shouldn't be able to build or do much work since she is with child. I do enjoy the game but I think that these adjustments would help improve the game because you'd be able to see each indivisual Hearthling grow.It also works especially well because everyone has to have their favourite Hearthling. It would also mean that there would be more journal entries, from crushes, to planning weddings or even finding out that one of the Hearthlings is pregnant. Because the Herbalist could check up on them to make sure that they're healthy. A lot like a midwife.

								As good as you'd imagine!Fun sandbox with defined purpose to expand. It isn't exactly as easy as one would think, which makes it enjoyably challenging. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even in the early stages, I'm finding Stonehearth to be incredibly addictive. Watching your Hearthlings build and thrive as you direct their actions is endearing. Though the characters are adorable, watching them slaughter adorable Goblins is great.Still, there are a few things that could be improved in this game. Keeping in mind that, as an Early Access title at this stage, there are improvements and features yet to come anyway. Regardless, here are a few things that I feel could be worked on:- The 'Build a Custom House' feature is in dire need of a more reliable 'Delete' tool. If the changes I wanted to make to an existing blueprint requires replacing something that has already been placed, I'm out of luck. I'd just have to tell my Hearthlings to undeploy an object and deploy the one I actually want there. (Like an improved bed.)- I would like to be able to either see a queue of actions and be able to to change the priority or simply have a click-and-drag tool to call the Hearthlings to a certain area to work on it right at that moment. I have seen far too many crops wither and die because they become neglected by my farmers. Not to mention, the buildings that become abandoned in the middle of construction because my workers suddenly feel that everyone mining at once is more important than finishing another wooden dining hall.- Please bring back the Name Randomizer for towns. I honestly liked seeing the sort of names built into the game and I'm horrendous with naming settlements in the first place.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you like building games with an RPG style for your citizens, this is quite fun. It's still in alpha state, but they working hard on it. I won't compair it with the most ambitious and genius builder game there is: Dwarf Fortress! If you do not know what that game is...you not really a building game fan...honestly you are an idiot if you do not know DF. But FF you are drifing offshore...- The style is a bit like Minecraft...everything is made of square blocks. It has it's charm and it's done very nicely. I even got some ideas from this game build in Minecraft.- The game has two kind of races and maps: Dessert and forrest. On the forrest map it's too easy, chop trees build wooden houses and mass produce wooden swords for trading. On a dessert map it's more difficult at start and you need clay to continue, build houses and so on.- The RPG element is limited: If an citizen has no tool equipted it's a worker, that digs,chops and carries stuff around. If you equipt a tool it gains experience for that class. To a maximum of level 6. This is done very easily and imo far too fast to gain a long live expancy of this game. You gain a special skill once you reach this level. If you pick another profession for that citizen after level 6, it virtually must reach level 7. Leveling up opens up different kinds of classes and items it can make. For instance, a farmer needs to be level 2 to become a cook. And a level 4 cook can bake bread etc. Also some experienced classes have a change to make a nicer version of that item.- Buildings are premade or you can design it yourself and even save them! This is great idea and very easy to use. Some bug here and there... If you want to change the colour of the walls, while the construction is already started, will leave the building unfinished. But I do not doubt they will get rid of that bug asap.- Interface is easy to use, you can select for every citizen what he/she must do. (like dwarf therapist for DF) You can look at the map several ways, closed buildings, half open or x-ray. Which are very good and handy to place items or mine.- To gain new citizens you need an amount of placed items and building and gold. And if you reach it on the start of a new day a new citizens will arrive. This is very cool and you will need to keep trading and building to gain new citizens. Also this amount will be raised once you reach it.So in overal it's very fun to play, but it's way too easy! (especially if you expect a difficulty of DF) Also you can reroll your starting villagers till they all have six for the 3 stats they have. If you save just before sunrise. So when an new citizen arrives you can reload if you do not want that one. It's ahs some bugs but very good support and most bugs are gone within a week. Now that's something other developers can learn something about. Combat is funny to see but enemies are again way too easy...even giant skeletons are killed one on one by your 1 lvl soldier with a wooden sword... So I hope there will be more challence. Also I miss interaction between your citizens, they are just walking around, eating,sleeping but there is no communication between them...that's something they must implement asap! Cause now it's fun but boring after a while. Ohw yes I want a trader that drinks too much or goes to sleep while the traders are almost leaving! I want citizen that gossips about another citizen or even falls in love...if they put that into the game...wow!

								Sims. Minecraft. Majesty. Elements of three games rolled into one for a combination that is... quite good. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR Lovely game with problems, but highly recommended.This game is similar to Gnomoria, there are some important differences:- graphic is much better (I like retro graphic, but Gnomoria was too much for me)- game mechanics are simpler, or at least it is much easier to understand- buildings!!!I don't deeply know Gnomoria, so excuse me if this is not a correct list. In my opinion these were the three most annoying things in Gnomoria, so I was really happy when I found StoneHearth.Pros:- lovely graphic and atmosphere- the settlement looks pretty cool with all the interesting buildings- classes and abilities are interestingCons: - still alpha, so lots of features are not finished (I hope underworld will be improved, ores will not be just a random drop), there are bugs, balancing issues. But development is active, there are releases every week, so I don't worry much about these.- biggest issue for me are the buildings (this is in the same time the best feature of the game). So you first have to design the house (or use a template), and then your hearthlings will build it. First problem is that quite often they cannot build the house (this unfortunately happens with the templates as well). Second problem is that the game won't give you any warning or error message, the only thing you see is that the building is just paused. There are scaffoldings around the house, some walls are missing, but no one is doing nothing. I couldn't figure out what is wrong. The best thing I could do is that I built a few ladders here and there, maybe they were not able to reach some parts, but that didn't help. But the worst thing is that there is nothing you can do, you will have a half ready house with scaffoldings in the middle of your nice village. If you don't like that (I didn't) then the only option is to reload an old save where the building wasn't at all designed. That wasn't really a viable solution for me. There is a console command which erases a building, but it won't clean up the scaffolding, and also the base of the building will still be there (the hole in the ground). My feeling is that the devs were too optimistic about this type of building, I guess they think that there are problems, they can solve it easily for the next version, no need for error message or any tool which would help players work around a failed building. And then the next release comes, and there are still lots of buildings not correctly building. I think this is not a new issue, many recent releases had this. But I thrust them, I hope sooner or later they will be able to solve this, and players will be able to build a very nice village.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a very fun and innovative twist on the classic city builder genre. Rather than only being given templates or static buildings, you can make your own. There are a lot of interesting details that make this game one of my all-time favorites.Pro's:1.) There is plenty to do, many playthroughs can last a long time. (My current play through has 95-ish realtime hours invested into it as of this review.)2.) There is plenty of strategy involved with this game, even with a town of 49, 15 devoted to Military, invasions can still be very threatening.3.) You can show off your creativity in this game,as stated above, you can create your own buildings, which is very nice to put your own unique touch on each village.4.) The job system in this game is very good, and the more time a hearthling puts into a job, the better payout you will have in the long run.5.) Despite being in Alpha, the developers have done a great job pushing out updates, fixes, etc.6.) This game is a lot of fun, even if you only plan on playing for an hour or so a day, you'll still make good progress in your town.Cons:1.) Hearthlings can get themselves stuck very easily, and it's important to keep a close eye on them when they're building structures, and if you aren't careful, they could starve to death.2.) Despite being given a job, often times hearthlings won't always perform that job, or task that's been assigned, and a restart generally fixes the problem.3.) The game has optimization issues. I have 32GB of RAM with an i7 processor and I still receive significant lag spikes.(granted this is with 50 Hearthlings, max graphics etc.) 4.) Difficulty ramps up but becomes static at some point, and if you're established, it takes a very significant misplay in order for your town to become in danger. (Currently I'm running 2 Knights, 2 Clerics, and 11 Rangers (all masters) with BiS gear.)5.) The invasions, generally speaking, are very predictable because invaders don't have much to throw at you that you can't deal with.Overall I give this game a solid 8/10. It's a very well-made game with a lot of love put into it by it's developers. There are a few hiccups with this game yes, but it's in Alpha, it's to be expected. There isn't a whole lot I would change about this game. And if you're on the fence about purchasing this game, you should, you can play this game to relax or to put conscious effort into it, either way, Stonehearth is a phenomenal game that deserves more attention than what it's received.

content:

Early Access Review
								Ive been playing this game cause its addictive like cocaine. Its ridiculous, but development seems a little "stumped". I'm sure the devs are able to get this game finished eventually.A couple things i would desperately recommend adding:The ability to assign homes to hearthlings, or rooms. OR make it to where only 1 hearthling can open up a certain door ( or just make doors assignable, like beds! ) Assignable relationships: ie; brother, mother, father, daughter, grandfather, etc.You should add a family tree type system and aging, so our town has a history and a fully stocked graveyard hahahaAnother thing is customization, i feel like our hearthlings are anchored to this Blue empire!Instead of adding factions we can play as, why not just make it to where we make our own factions? Custom colors / and at the beginning where you choose to embark, you can choose either the carpenter saw or the potters cutter.I also think you should make it easier for us to roll for citizens without wiping the entire colony at the beginning before embarking. We dont want all women or all men colonies, or a majority of either, which brings me to my next point!REPRODUCTION! I don't like the way we get new hearthlings! Daily update is very unrealistic, You should make it to where a male and a female hearthling are drawn to eachother, or you can choose who is in a relationship, and they mate in their own house/room and after a certain number of ingame days, a little baby hearthling pops out!A couple of other fun ideas, cause for me it seems like you guys have the potential to develop the game but are running out of ideas! Maybe im wrong, but i dont care! haha!queen beds that are assignable to 2 hearthlings (and bunk beds like this for barracks)more animalsmore types of placeable itemsmore jobsability to assign farmers to certain farms ability to assign patrols for footmenability to assign archers to the top of a wall ( to combat invading goblins )easier ability to become a dwarf-like fortress, because the 4x4 tunnel mining doesnt seem optimal for hearthlings in regards to space, which makes them so glum!You have a road builder, but how about an auto path builder? Like a worn dirt road.ability to place dirt on rock, or maybe PLANTERS. so that we can have indoor cave gardens, or farms on the mountain.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								As someone who has a high standard of gaming, I can say that there have been quite a few Indi games that have caught my interest only to never be fully developed. After playing Stonehearth, I can say, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that this is one of the best Indi games I have seen in a long time. Even in the alpha build, it's easy enough to understand, yet open enough to allow so many more options to be added. I cannot say how much I love this game, and the idea behind it.I will even go so far as to say that this is a game that NEEDS to be made. Speaking not only as a fan, but as a gamer. This is a prime example of people making games who truly love making games; and who can set an example to other game developers out there to stand by their work and see it through to completion. Radiant, I implore you to see this game through to the end. Not just for me, a single fan, but for all your fans, and all the Indi developers out there with uncompleted or unrealized games. Set a standard for Indi gaming, one that future generations can adhere to with pride.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								While still a bit buggy (what can you expect from early access, right?) this game is fun, and a good time killer. Some of the recent updates have introduced food going bad (be careful of production, consumption, and cooking!) and better pathing support for your hearthlings (workers) so they freak out less when multiple things are going on.A little bit frustrating when you want to custom build some awesome buildings, especially with multi-story buildings, but you can have them build basicaly whatever strikes your fancy. It's like minecraft, but you manage a town full of minecrafters, instead of being one. Deal with extorting goblins, angry wolves, thieves, and the occasional raid by the undead, all the while making sure everyone is well fed, housed, and your soldiers get the best armor and weapons.I can't wait to see more updates - unlocking all the jobs, building y castles and towers (without having to stage things floor by floor) and the implementation of magic, it seems?Worth the money and the time!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								 pretty awesome game where you take control of a town of blocky individuals, who can take on quite a few different roles depending on their stats. They build buildings, mine, and craft items. If you want a game that is cute and you can design your own buildings and control a little town then this is the game. That said, there are some glaring issues I see with it. The whole way you design a new building is in my opinion quite badly done, you can't choose how high you want the walls and they are all encompassing, so you can't really have a 3 walled kind of thing. The main issue with it though is once you've designed a bulding, and then set it to be built you cannot edit it or demolish it. You'll need to use a console command just to do so, which is far from ideal. So the building system is:-Kind of basic, it really could be a lot more in depth, maybe being completely single block placement designing instead of the parts and pieces you can choose from. -Dodgy. I didn't like that I could only "undo" something, instead of having a proper deletion tool, the erase tool only seems to work on slabs and furniture. This can be frustrating at times. What's even more frustrating is slabs can actually clip through items and it does look quite terrible, but you don't notice it 'til the building is fully built, thus having to either deal with it's glitchy look, or demolish the entire building using cheats. The building system isn't the only thing that is annoying about the game, the mining can be just as annoying sometimes. Say you wanted to have a mined out grand hall in a mountain. Now though it may be difficult to see the ceiling in this game due to the camera being physically incapable, you do notice that the ceiling of a mined out area is quite low. If you want to have a higher ceiling it's near impossible to accomplish. Because of the fact you can't look up at the ceiling you can't select it to be mined, and even if you can the hearthlings have a great deal of trouble doing so. I planned on making a tunnel just over the room I wanted to heighten the ceiling of and one of them got stuck on a single block. So either players will need to have foresight or ingenuity to raise the roof or the devs should add a horizontal slice mode perhaps, which really would make my dwarfy self and brethren happy. Combat is quite great and the hearthlings themselves are pretty good at most activities. Though whenever they run away from battle it's only for 1 second, at which point they forget their♥♥♥♥♥kicking and return to fight the giant ogre they have no chance at beating. I'd suggest having proper retreats, perhaps to safety zones if the hearthling needs to run from battles, it would make micro managing them a bit easier. SPEAKING of micromanaging and combat. It at least for me is kind of unintuitive. Having groups is fine and all but then I have to select the combat tab, select the group, select what I want them to do and then send them off to do it, which is quite tedious. It's such a simple game yet so mindboggilingy hard to control at times.it really is a good game apart from these few things which make me almost pull my hair out sometimes, but that's probably just me. And it is in early access, hopefully they iron out all the bugs and the terrible building system in future. Otherwise there's alot to love about the game, and I think I'd recommend it at this time due to the devs updates, hopefully they continue to or I'll be changing my mind.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								The cure for your heartbreak about abandonware. Stonehearth keeps getting better. It's good as it is right now, and has potential for even more. It is adorable, humorous, and ultimately relaxing despite butting up against the occasional flaw. While still in alpha stage, the developers go to great lengths to try to keep the community happy, and that shows. Harvest, mine, build and farm, care for your little Hearthlings and protect them from the harsh world beyond. Grow a community and help them play to their strengths. There's very little I could ask for in a little town sim like this beyond fulfilling the potential of their intriguing skill-tree, and as I've followed this from early alpha that's exactly what they've been doing. When I started there were barely any jobs on that tree available, and this game was still a lot of fun. Now it's well on its way to being filled in completely, and every new job has enhanced the game experience. The flavor elements like dialogues and encounters keep getting more amusing, and the whole game just has a lot more character than any of its competition on Steam. Crashes are variable, and they've implemented various means to limit the crash potential (such as being able to self-cap the total population, turn off lighting and shadows, etc) for those who are weary of restarting while awaiting the next patch. Animation bugs are sometimes hilarious but rarely game-breaking. Hearthlings still get stranded from time to time, but we're given console tools to help keep them from starving to death in unreachable places. It's easier to take these moments with good humor even when they do die. Even potentially game-breaking bugs don't seem all that bad when you can trust the team to respond. So far, I trust this team. All in all one of the most caring, courteous developer teams I've ever encountered in beta testing, much less alpha-- and I fall for 'early release' far too often. This one redeems my faith in the idea. Glad I bought this early and got to see the result unfold.Definitely worth our time and attention. This is not a game to miss.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is like a previous game but 2.5D called "Towns". You lay claim to some land and thriving place were your villagers can live without fear of the zombies, goblins and anyother terror that can come from the woods.I seriously think this is a huge step up from anyother type of AI run villager system too. They seem to have been able to make it smooth and also the villager AI are very smart and intuitive. If they have some wood with them, and are trapped in a whole they will build a ladder to get out. Also when you ask a worker to make somethings, or a traders person to make a specific item, they actually do it and don't just eat all day like other AI villager systems I have been subjected to in other types of games like this.For a Alpha this is a very good start even in somecases almost close to a beta when it comes to graphics and gameplay. It does however need the rest of its trade's classes made in it and also some tweeks when it comes to eqiuping villagers with trait specific items that are already in the game. Example, better clothes to increase your worker speed. Can't and don't know or atleast haven't found a way to equip it. This holds for almost all items. The ones it doesn't are the items needed to change the job of your villager.All in all this is a awesome alpha in my opinion but the price seems high for a alpha when the finished product isn't made yet and could possibly be a few months to a year away.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								Let's get this out of the way up front: I'm not in a hurry to try Early Access games after some of the stuff that's happened with those. (It's a shame for the good ones that the stink of the bad apples has rubbed off.) So I resisted getting Stonehearth for months. That Early Access tag made me avoid spending money on it, even though a friend of mine couldn't shut up about it and it did look like fun. (And cute. Have you seen the Geomancer loading screen/concept art thing, with the bunnies? Adorable.)  In fact, I dithered for SO long, that same friend got me the game as a gift. (You rock, friend, thanks again!)I played it. And I played it some more. And some more...Okay, I can admit when I was wrong. Alpha or not, Stonehearth is fun.It's exactly what I needed to scratch that itch I get when playing Minecraft and longing for a sense of greater purpose within the game. In Stonehearth, that purpose is building and growing your settlement and becoming a proper town, but it's still sandboxy enough to suit my desire to proceed at my own pace and wander off onto side projects (while being mindful in monsters-on modes that the monsters don't wait for you to finish that building project you're working on). If not set to monster-free Passive, the secondary purpose is making sure your Hearthlings and their property and goods don't end up in the backpacks and bellies of equally-ambitious (or just flesh-hungry) monsters. You can outfit and train them to better their chances of survival, and build wisely to make the settlement more defensible. Stonehearth does have micromanagey elements, some of which are more so than others as Hearthlings can be dumb as rocks sometimes. Workers build ladders when commanded to do so, but don't expect them to think to do this on their own after they've mined themselves into a hole. You'll find them gazing mournfully at the sky as they slowly starve to death, rather than digging themselves out of the hole or building a ladder. I expect this will improve somewhat as the Alpha progresses. In the meantime, prior proper planning prevents pathetic pixel-death, as does the occasional head count to be sure nobody's stuck on a floating ledge you were trying to clear, because they dug their way away from the ladder. Now, Stonehearth IS Early Access Alpha, so there are optimization problems, crashes (so far only one crash-to-reboot, not bad on my unimpressive PC), game freezes (quite a lot of those -- save early, save often, turn Autosave on. If you play multiple playthroughs and turn Autosave on, you should know that while you can make lots of separate manual saves,the game won't make separate autosave slots as far as I can tell. If the game crashes and your last save was an autosave, load it and manual-save it before switching to your other playthrough).  There are bugs, and things not implemented yet. (FE: I accidentally manually saved just as the game autosaved. That manual save was stuck perma-Paused even after restart. The Autosave was OK.)Potentially spoilery bit to follow, with workaround: Pet feeding is an example of a work in progress. I made a bunch of rabbit food before discovering that the current kinds of Cook-crafted animal food are apparently for Farmer-raised rabbits, not the pet animals Trappers can tame. Pets don't get food out of storage bins, nor could I find a way to get food out for them or make my Hearthlings feed them. So I had sad hungry bunnies hopping around begging for food with no way to feed them. I made a pair of small fields with a row of ground storage in between, so my Farmers would leave a little harvested food where the pets could get at it. The raccoon seems to prefer meat, so I put a couple of squares of storage near a nearby trapping area as well. It works, but it's exasperating; welcome to Alpha. *(I'm told that pet kibble is in the works to resolve this problem. Looking forward to it! Hungry pets are sad pets!)--(/end spoiler-type-thing)--So, stuff is not fully implemented/tweaked, or not in yet, as is to be expected in Alpha, although it's looking pretty solid so far. The game WILL sometimes freeze or crash, because Alpha. And like any Alpha, there's always the chance that a meteor will strike Earth and support will stop. So far so good, though, looking at the update history.The fact is that even with the game freezes, Stonehearth has been really fun to play. It has multiple modes, including two different biome types, and a Peaceful option if you want to just play and build, and not have cute little monsters come stomp through your town. Having played both monsters-on and monsters-off, I like both so far; my most stalwart Hearthlings became the town guards, and aside from an incident where I regretted giving one a two-handed weapon because he was taking too much damage without a shield, they're mighty and courageous in defense of the town. (Spoiler-ish/Test pending: going to see whether I can use the destroy object option to ditch a weapon once it's equipped, as it looked like held weapons can be selected by clicking on the weapon in the Hearthling's hand. There seems to be no way yet to instruct them to "downgrade" to sword and board from a higher-damaging, two-handed weapon. I didn't want to revert to an older save, so I worked around that by granting Halberd Boy a knighthood, which forced him back to sword and shield. Item deletion would waste a few gold worth of metal, but beats losing a sturdy and courageous Hearthling as monster chow if promotion isn't workable at the time.)--(/end spoiler stuff)--Performance-related stuff:  Because of my less than awesome computer, I'm leaving my more advanced saved Stonehearth games to pick up later on, or start over, as at around 20 Hearthlings and a sizable hoard of goods, my PC begins to make emphatic complaints about running the game. (More frequent game freezes, flickering menus, framerate problems.) That's actually not bad for a game that only just had its first big optimization effort, on a computer that's several years old and was mediocre when it was new.Stonehearth is cute witout being too much so, Minecrafty without feeling like an attempt to capitalize off of Minecraft's popularity. I like Minecraft for the design-and-build stuff but it does make me long for a sense of direction I don't need to make up for myself, sometimes. So the feel of "Minecrafty elements and freedom, but with purpose besides that which I invent" is something I really like about Stonehearth. It has more of an "adventurey" and "questy" aspect in ways that are fun and useful, and hopefully will continue to balance sandboxiness and RPG-osity. I like the "from a far-off land" trade-quests, as far as "useful quests" go. Hopefully they'll make quests/merchant alerts/attack alerts stay onscreen longer or fold into an openable alerts menu. Unless I'm missing a way to call them back up again...? It's a little too easy right now to miss one because it came up while I was in the middle of something, with 3 other menus open and a placeable object on my cursor, or a gang of zombies trying to eat my Hearthlings' brains. More stuff to add to a future feedback post!I realize that this post's mentions of Alpha issues may read like damning with faint praise. It's not meant as such, I enjoy the game a lot. But it's Early Access, so, better forewarned and forearmed. If you can deal with the expected hiccups of Alpha and the facts of Early Access, I recommend it. Have fun building your township, as well as helping an already fun game improve!Oh, and, watch out for those pesky Goblins.  ;)

content:
Posted: April 4
Early Access Review
								I bought this game having high hopes for a sandbox where i could create just about anything i could imagine. I was not dissapointed. At the time of this review the game is still in early access which means that it is not a complete game. Knowing this, be prepared to encounter bugs and glitches that haven't been quite ironed out yet. Dont buy this thinking its a full finished game yet, because its not.Here are a few pro's and con's of the gamePro's Fairly constant updates which allow for new mechanics and bug fixes to be addedTwo types of biomes to choose from each varying in different main resourcesbuilding templates to help you if you need themA quest sysyem, currently rather short but i beleive they plan on expandingdifferent classes for you little villagersthe game has nice music and a very nice art styleConsSometimes the ai of the viligers can be a little wonky causing them to get stuck oftenBuilding can sometimes be a pain because sometimes they glitch and wont get finishedthats honestly all i can think of for cons at the momentOverall i really enjoyed this game and i would recomend it to anyone who can deal with a few bugs and crashes now and then. Make sure you put the autosave option so if it does crash you dont lose all your progress. This game has a lot of potential and they are adding new aspects to it with every update.
