Early Access Review
								STONEHEARTH:  EARLY ACCESS GAME w/ GREAT CUSTOMER SUPPORT!!Voxel Building, Crafting, Exploring, Surviving.. all around fun time SINGLE PLAYER game... My son bought this game, showed it to me and I secretly giggled and thought; I'll never play that game... then a few weeks of watching him play... yep you guessed it... I bought the game and then I really liked it!!  That 'simple' looking game kept me busy, on my feet, alert, paying attention, building, crafting, fighting, exploring, mining, and moving upward and onward to bigger and better things.  I was addicted. Hooked almost instantly upon loading.  This game does not come without its quirks, but what I can say after over 200 hours of gameplay is that I am not slowing down anytime soon.  The Community here is great, friendly, and upbeat... they listen to their peoples... they are active and upfront on a daily / weekly basis check out their YouTube channel... follow them all on Twitter, and keep up to date on Facebook... the Tube is the best spot to keep up to date weekly on new things being implemented, new designs being worked on and other peoples builds... not to mention Twitch *thumbs up there* and GitHub.  EARLY ACCESS GAME: Please look up and understand the full meaning and understanding of that term before purchasing.  I can say though the developers are always working on correcting, fixing, helping, and adding new things all the time.  GOOD SUPPORT TEAM HERE!

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Update 10/10/15 -  The game is really coming along and doing so a decent pace.  I actually think one of the coolest things for me is watching the entire game develop.  You don't log on for a few weeks and now you have a new class to try.  New enemies pop up.  I've definitely enjoyed this game already, despite some of the bugs.  Even in alpha, this game has a lot of positives to it.  You can see where they're going with the job system, and they make your units mattering, which is very different then some similar games I've played.  To give an example, you can't switch a unit to a shepard until it has reached lv. 3 as a trapper for the unit.  That makes things like goblin attacks actually matter, because your lone trapper in the woods will die.  It's little ideas and notions like this that make the game good.As some people have mentioned, the content isn't all the way there, with a large amount of the jobs missing, and several bugs that can be annoying. (units not finishing a house, i.e. laying the groundwork but not actually completing it.)Overall though I really enjoy the game so far and I would definitely recommend picking it up.  It's definitely shaping up to be a successful title.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								A very promising city-builder game. As of this review, it's still on its alpha version, so expect bugs. I get my hearthlings stuck here and there when mining and I've always got to put a ladder to "rescue" them. It's annoying. I hope they fix that. Here's what you get:Hearthlings - a collective name for your citizens. In order to gain more citizens, you've got to make improvements to your town to reach daily goals. Hearthlings have stats, and depending on those skill points, they could be suited to a particular job/task. It's still up to the player to assign what kind of work a hearthling would be doing, though.Enemies - you can get attacked or stolen by enemies. It's funny to think that these enemies could have their own camps/towns, too. I haven't played enough to the point of seeing a very good "monster town". But defeating them, you can pretty much loot their things.Resources - it's either you buy your things or you craft them from your own hard-earned materials. To get your raw materials and craft them into something else, you've got to rely on your hearthlings.Build Mode - there are a few building blueprints you can choose from and these pre-existing blueprints depend on your hearthlings' ancestry. Heck, if you don't like them, you could always customize your own! As your crafters become more experienced, you'd get to see new items you can use for building your buildings. So, it's not all laid down for you. I find that neat. We'd probably see more items for buildings as the game grows. It's unfortunate that once you finished constructing a building, you can no longer edit it. :(Quests - just a few, really.Opportunities for Trade - these pop out randomly as messages? You could always refuse if you don't like the deal. I wonder if we could have other towns to trade resources with? Even enemy towns? Haha. That'd be neat.Hmmm... I don't know if I've got everything down but those are the features I remember as of now. Anyway, you should check this out!

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a fun town building game with some performance issues that are slowly getting patched out. You start with worker settlers until they slowly become more specialized. Your worker settlers will build houses that you design (or one of like, five prefabs) where they will live, and eat, and get massacred by goblins if you are a noob like me. Even in the game's current state I can recommend it for the price they are asking.On top of all of the gameplay features, it really makes you realize that you have been taking the autosave feature in about every other modern game for granted when windows decides it wants to shut down your computer to update, and you lose 3-4 hours of progress. SAVE OFTEN. Or you will regret it.EDIT: I just realize that there is a periodic autosave function that is disabled by default. Disreguard the 2nd paragraph.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								My only other experience with this genre is RimWorld. I really enjoyed that game but there was something missing from it for me. I think I found it in this game and that's design. I won't try to compare the two games that much but its just going to happen. +Pros++Personalized building designs that allow you to create your own buildings from scratch +Job progression through experience working with certain tasks (ie. a Farmer can become a Cook once they reach level 2 and have the necessary tool)+Progression in the fact that you will be approached once your village becomes big enough to establish yourself as a town. You even get rewards for it( Edit: Tier 2 building templates, Tier 2 Random vendors, TIER 2 BGM!! )+Random events that aren't too overpowering(on Medium difficulty) ++Bonus point for a goblin wanting some of my stuff then actually getting mad and attacking me for not letting him have it-Cons--With cons I have to get nitpicky and this is where my RimWorld comes into play. Trust me I know its still EARLY in developement. Edit: A serious Con for me but I know its just a bug and bugs will go away but since it's happened more times than once is this: You build a building. You put items in that building, chests, beds, etc. You get down to the last piece you want to put in the building and you get a stacking error where the outline of the piece goes into the building but that's it. The only fix I have for it? Save the current configuration of the building, name it whatever you want, and destroy the building and start over. Its a bit frustrating but once this gets fixed I'll edit this part out.-Not being able to combine same stockpiles into one larger pile. You have to create multiple piles in order to cover an area. -I think it needs a layout tool so you can put grids on the ground so you can plan out your village a bit better. I've just been using stockpiles with it set to none but a simple layout tool would be awesome. -Not being able to edit buildings after they're built. I'm sure there's a reason for it but for the life of me I can't see it. Even if you limit the options of editting like floor and wall color. I don't think we should have to tear down the building because I want a new coat of paint on the walls.For the Cons section, I truly had to reach deep within my nitpickery to come up with personal negatives. I can get over those things rather quickly honestly.All in all this game is amazing for where its at. I want this game to keep continuing in its production and I will support it any way I can until its fully developed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is so addicting i cant come off it i play this more than any other game i have.First time Experienceat first i had no idea what to do (I know there is guides but im going simply from the game itself) it doesnt really explain what you do. Then i when i figured out what to do i felt quite stupid (Personally).At first i was just gathering resources but wasnt sure what to do, but then realised you have to set you people jobs, after that i started expanding, defend my self from goblins, then built a wall round my town and have just expanded on.Although it can be quite annoying to play due to the bugs and what have you it is only and Alpha so dont expect bug free.ProblemsNow yes it is only and alpha im not hating on it i understand but im only sharing a few bugs people should know about.Buildings with more than floorThis can be a pain as they will get stuck on the inside of the top floor if your not planning on using the second floor.UIIts written in C++ json files, similar to Minecraft. so yeah can expect the kind of bugs from it, if your changing a Person job and your looking at the list it can crash and stop you from setting Jobs, saving, crafting, and other things that require the UI to pop up a menu.(To fix this just press F5 to reset the UI)Lagyou wont notice this till you have explored your area a bit and have at least 20 people in your town. When this happens prepare for all the Bugs. The UI system comepletely fails and stutters the game due to the all the for loops and the while scripts (Basically 24 FPS is coming your way).(I have found a way to sort of delay the lag, when its happens Reset the UI by Press F5. this resets all the Loop Scripts causeing it to refresh all the code thats waiting or looping in the game it wont cause any harm that i know i do it and i have no problems)ConclusionYes there are problems but its an alpha and this game has insane potential im sticking around for the updates and playing it daily you ignore the bugs and just get on with it. i still recommened getting this game.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
Early Access Review
Potential and CharmI purchased prior to early access, Fall 2014. If the videos appeal to you, and you are willing to put up with bugs then I feel comfortable recommending this game now. As of 11/2015 the primary issues I have with the game are bugs. Many are fixed weekly, but I still can't quite build what I want or I have to game the AI to keep whem working.  If the developers deliver on everything it should be considerably better.This game has a lot of potential, and I respect the developers for being very open with the community. They communicate through their blog weekly, and often push a non-stable build weekly or every other week. This game has not been abandoned like some other early access titles. Pros:Responsive Dev TeamOpen for ModsGreat visual styleFun personality in the writing Extensive replayability (no two games the same)Building interface has great potentialCons: Buggy... it's alphaLong dev cycleMany features that give the game legs are not in yet (MP,Co-Op, more factions)I purchased this because I wanted to support the developers, and I'm glad to see they are still going strong. This little game has a lot of charm, and potential. As it stands right now I check the game once a month or so just to see all the new stuff they've put in. I hit a few show-stopping bugs on my town and leave it for another month. Looking forward to full release.

								I've spent so much time in this game already and it's not even finished.Stonehearth is a voxel based city builder game that scratches the same kind of itch as the millenaire mod for Minecraft.The studio is also really good with their communication and transparency.  They are always in touch with the people who kickstarted the game, and take the time to respond to people who arrived a little later like myself.  Development is even interactive through a Trillo Board and through the official forum.In terms of modding there is an active community and a really well supported forum if you find theres something you want but the game currently lacks.If you're looking for a city builder or building game and want something a little different, then I highly reccomend this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a very nice and pretty looking game with a big potential. It's an excellent game for players like myself, who would like to play Dwarf Fortress, but find the whole thing too imidating. Then graphical style might not be for everyone but I like the cute voxel people working the land and doing their tasks in a cute voxel world with their cute voxel tools. The game is getting better and more complex after every update and the UI let's you do all kinds of neat stuff that isn't possible in other games of this genre.The biggest problem though is the bug that makes workers building a building idle before the construction is finnished. This bug has been pretty persistent and been there since the earliest versions. It is quite nasty and makes the game allmost unplayable, since it's hard to find a workaround that would help in this situation. It's not so nice to have a village with a load of unfinished buildings...But the game is still in alpha and, as I said before, improving nicely. I am certain that the team will be able to squash also these major and difficult bugs.So but yeah, thumbs up for Stonehearth.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Berry nice game, I must admit. Tickles my fancy in more than one way.You will like it if you've ever played and liked:- Minecraft- Settlers- Banished- Dwarf Fortress (albeit you might find it a tad less complicated)It is a mixture of town building, resource management and roleplaying. The player is tasked with founding a new settlement with only seven settlers and limited equipment. One will have to provide means of getting resources and food and train your specialists to improve the quality of your settlers' lives and to keep your town safe from baddies that share the ground with the Hearthlings (albeit this could be turned off). If the town is doing well, it will attract new immigrants, which can be pressed into new roles. There is also an rpg-esque quest line (I believe one or two so far - more is promised), for which you will need to train and outfit a team of adventurers militia.I particularly like the building system: - building templates for quick placement. Your workers will queue required components automatically;- every building can be customized to your liking and built to exact specs (ie. 'carpenter's house' template can be easily re-purposed for stonemason's workshop);- each construction is built brick-by-brick, complete with wooden scaffoldings, which are de-constructed after the job's finished;- multi-storey buildings are a thing.Clichés and subtle jokes run throughout the gameplay. Couple it with cute 3D pixel art and the result is rather refreshing.Yup,it is still in EA, it is still buggy, it is still incomplete. But nevertheless, so far, it is a lot of fun!Just don't take it too seriously.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has pro and cons... I wish it didn't have cons but it does have SERIOUS Cons.This game has a great idea and story, starting off with your civilians or "Hearthlings" as the game calls them trying to survive in the world. Very inviting and always bringing you back to the game and continue to play more. There are a few faults that make you skratch your head and question "Why isn't this fixed already?"Pros  this game brings you back to it. Always replayable even, randomized events, world  and characters.  A very elaborate building designer. Elaborate in ways and not in others, but this game does allow you to build your own buildings, design them from scratch.  Constantly being changed by the dev team, updated and fixed.Cons Has probelms with building, and some bugs that well frankly, shouldn't be there still. Quite basic stuff that should be done. Been in development for quite sometime and I would say, Not Done. Things that need to be fixed are show everywhere. Even to the point you can save and the game may not realize you did and your hours of work that you did is now gone. The game doesn't auto save as frequent as it should.Overall this game is still one of my favorite games. I would give it a total 7/10. I recommend the game as long as you are willing to have a few problems and watching the game develop more.

content:

Early Access Review
								Honestly? It will be the best game in its genre, toppling its many predecessors (Dwarf Fortress, Gnomoria, etc.). However, it's currently lacking late game content, as well as needing a lot more FLESH to the game itself. Mechanics are pretty flawless, but it also experiences some minor progression "obstacles" and balance issues. I only encountered one bug, which left a permanent "cloud" in an area, which doesn't even bother me, signalling that this game is MOSTLY bug free. Some settlers might get trapped, and mining/tunneling needs some changes, but other than that and the lack of FLESHING OUT? Perfection.It it's current state, it's an amazing game. I played nonstop for hours, over multiple days. It's fantastic. It's an amazing game, so much so that I felt compelled to write this HONEST review.In a year, it will be even better. These guys know what they're doing.(If a dev is reading this, please add a lizard race, faster structure building, and combat magic, pls and ty. love you.)

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Finally! i've had this since the pre alpha (when you could barely have them build anything and then again when you had to tell trappers how to do their job)  Even when it became purchaseable on steam i thought it was way too early. I finally fired this up today, and my usual hour-max play time before crashing out was epic... They have changed a great deal of things to either make them automated, slightly more intuitive and overall a joy to play. The profession and task mechanics have come a long way while still retaining everything i liked about them initially, there feels to be some real meat on the bones of this and while there are a few more things that take a little practice, it has just come leaps and bounds ahead of where it was seeming to be stagnating.I very much recommend this for anyone wanting a DF-lite with graphics. It's not going to replace your dwarven stronghold any time soon, but it will give you your money's worth in game play. I strongly recommend giving this one a shot. and while you're at it probably throw a few bucks toward the toady one, keep him inspiring developers of this calibur.Overall i am extremely happy with my original decision to back this project and am looking forward to what it will become.

The biggest one is the slowing down once you get a certain size of people. just because the game cant handle it. people not working benches because they are indoors. nothing is blocking their path, the buildng is huge and empty. 6 doors. but they wont work it inside. so you put it outside ikr but still. gaurds will attack people when you tell them to cancel. then they go right back to it. but only that one person goes. so he basically kommikazii himself towards a hoard of goblins and wolfves. or beetles. people will NOT PICKUP LOOT EVER. ive only gotten them to loot things like the hats. and they will walk past everything. i turned auto loot on. nothing it just ques it up. and even if you cancel all the loot tasks and loot indiviual items it wont work. as stated later, its in its alpha, its implied. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Was a Kickstarter backer of this back when it was first conceived, and have played it periodically as they have made improvements on it.The game still has a ways to go to reach the goal state, but they have been doing a fantastic job along the way.  The game has been fun to tinker with since day one, and has only been getting more rewarding as they improve and add to it.  The devs are absurdly transparent about how things are going, and have been both honest and cooperative with the fans.I prefer reviewing games as-is rather than how they may someday become, so I would say this game is currently a decent buy.  Not fantastic yet, but fun.  That said, if you are willing to make the investment, I strongly believe this game will improve to the point of being amazing by the time the devs are done.The game supports both peaceful, and combat senarios, though you will still find plenty of tranquil and peaceful days on the combat side.  The mechanics are intuitive and fun to use, and you will quickly find yourself enamored with your village as it grows from a group of misfits around a camp fire into a teaming hamlet.  The devs provide fantastic support, and the community is welcoming and pleasant.I solidly recommend this game to fans of the genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Meh.  It's cute; like you might think you are going to get something like minecraft but it's really not.  You can dig blocks out of the dirt but that's just to harvest randomly placed ores.  And, you have to be really attentive to how you give your dig instructions or they will dig a hole they can't get out of... and starve without warning.  Beyond that it's kind of like any other crafting game; you have to have your tradespeople level up before they can build certain things, or unlock more types of trades/specialties. What you cannot do is control any of the villagers.  The only controls you have are your build queue, you can designate areas for mining, loot collection, you can set up zones for farming plants, animals, trapping, (much like Sim City)  and you can order an 'alert' where all the villagers run to your designated safe-zone, marked by a flag.  You can relocate the flag as your village changes.  The only villagers you can slightly control are the footmen, which have 3 or 4 basic instructions that really all amount to the same thing... "move here and fight any threats".  The threats are nothing too severe... the occasional zombie, golem etc that wants to steal your stuff or kill your villagers.  Oh, and don't forget to cancel your footmen's orders when the fighting is done or they will stick to their new post, and starve without comment.The pace is ponderous... it has 2 speeds, neither of which is fast enough to make the time go by, but the accelerated speed is too fast to be able to react well to some of the hostiles that show up.  It'd be nice if it had instad of 1x/2x, it had 5x/10x and option to drop to normal speed when a zombie alert shows up.So... it looks like a good game for younger kids but I think the crafting system and build-requirements are just a touch too complex for them.  Anyone else may enjoy it until they come to the realization... this is really all there is.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								10/10This game is great and is totally worth your money. I played it for a while now and I just can't get enough of this game! The developers are very close with the community and bring updates about the game every single week (on tuesday). I really think they care about us gamers.I like to compare this game with, The Sims, Simcity (or cities: skylines) and a little bit of Age of Empires. It is a citybuilder with a lot of micromanagement and sometimes you get attacked by scary monsters, that you need to kill with your small army of footmen (hope to see archers soon! They will be there!).The game is, ofcourse, because it is early access, somewhat buggy. But since the last update (alpha 14) a lot of them are fixed and great new content was added. My Pro's-Great micromanaging-citybuilder.-Lovely graphics, lightning effects and looks.-Perfect music (would love to hear more!)-Fun enemies and encounters.-Cool development team.-Roles you can assign to your hearthlings.-Easy to use building greator, but you can make it as impressive as you want. (block for block)-Great landscaping, water physics.My Cons-Bugs (duh! but I assume this will be temporary)-Only 1 combat musictrack, gets annoying after a while.-Some performance issues but I am sure they will be fixed. :)I am really looking forward to the Dwarves as a playable race, the winter biome aaaannddd.... MULTIPLAYER! I know it will be there eventually!This game is very promising and super fun!

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ooof. First off I'd like to say I play a lot of early access games so I know to expect bugs and issues. You'll need that mind set for Stonehearth. For time's sake I'll just say there are ALOT of bugs still, some rather serious. There is almost zero in game help on how to do even the most basic game functions, thats ok it is a alpha stage game after all, but here's the next issue that finally made me have to turn the game off and write this review. When you look online how to do the super basic ABCs its old outdated infomation that no longer has any bearing with the current game. Assuming very few readers made it through all that complaining I'd like to end the review on this note, its still pretty fun (when you aren't pulling your hair out) and while the developers aren't pumping out updates like crazy they do seem to be plugging away at steadly which is more than you can say about a lot of early access.P.S. Bottem line is Stonehearth has a ton of potential and I'm glad I could support the developers. I just hope they keep working hard to make the game more stable to play.

								A very good game.  This ALPHA stage is more stable than many of the BETA stage games that I play. True there are many problems with crashing, glitches, and other things but the Developers are puting out fixes for most if not all the major problems within 48 hours of finding these problems which is faster than any other game I have BETA or ALPHA tested except maybe Minecraft.  The Developers are constantly asking for player input on new aspects and not only listen to suggestions but make counter suggestion when something isn't possible because of how the game is programmed.  For all of you out there who want a game that has no bugs at all I suggest waiting until after the BETA test has finished which at the current pace will be probably 2019 or 2020 depending on how much more the Developers decide to implement and how long it takes to debug multiplayer when they finaly add it in.  If you like Sandbox City or Civilization Builders this is a game that you will greatly enjoy.

								Even when it points out it is alpha and missing things I still find myself enthrawled by gameplay alike to others like the Kefling games from Xbox. If you've played dwarf fortress this is almost exactly like that.All in all even how it is, I'd say a definate buy.

Early Access Review
								I like this game and I am excited to see where it will in the future. While this remains in early access, I would like to point out that there are a dozen or more games exactly like this on Steam and other platforms. For me to keep playing, I need to know how this game will be distinct amongst the others. How will this game be it's own thing and not just another one of these games.

Early Access Review
								It's not a complete game yet, but it's playable and a great deal of fun. There's a lot of satisfaction in building a thriving community and keeping it running smoothly in the face of golems, orcs, lizards and the odd wandering necromancer. Every update it gets a little better and a little less buggy.Well worth a try.
